Update/Disregard below line of "*****" until further notice.

DO NOT PAY FOR THIS.
EVERY UPDATE SHOULD NOT BE 100+GB, AND ON THROTTLED AZURE SERVERS.
I will be "yar harring" this to avoid Microsoft breaking my ability to launch the game for several days (even with gigabit fiber internet.)


*************************************************************************
Slightly above casual flight game.

Pros:
Graphics. If you have the processing power and stable internet for the streamed scenery, it's beautiful.
If you lack either of those things, you're going to have a bad time.
I did not personally have an issue in the graphics department, but your system may vary.

Control(s) binding.
Overall a great system for having modifier keys/buttons to perform different tasks with a limited/restricted number of controls.
Only gripe is the controls menu that sometimes seems to get mad at you for not specifying a class/type/group and resets the controls menu to everything at once.

Cons:
The flight models are insanely underwhelming. This has very reminiscent feeling of Flight Simulator X and it's predecessors, where external/additional software was necessary to give you more realistic physics.

The updates. Holy hell the updates initially where for some reason the Xbox style distribution was the choice was awful. I've noticed lately they're more reasonable, but when using a platform like Steam, the launcher for the game counts as playtime, so you may have several hours "played" while it was all just updates is a hard pass.

Support. I'm guessing Microsoft is doing business as usual treating games as a service, so now that FS24 is on it's way, I can only imagine "DLC" to upgrade your game to the newer version, instead of I don't know, ADDING CONTENT TO YOUR OVERHYPED GAME.

Overall:

5/10, not worth buying unless it's 75% off original pricing. Even then it's still a hard sale considering the price of additional content from third parties (this used to be a problem in the days of FS9, FSX, but you could buy a cheap copy of the game from virtually anywhere.)

Gameplay: 8.5/10

The gameplay is definitively very nice, especially if you like planes like me, which this flight simulator has an expansive collection of. I personally thing that it`s quite nice to just [b]f l y .[/b] Also, there is tons of different missions, including discovery flights to take in the stunning graphics (we`ll talk about those later), various training missions to better understand the art of flying, and more. Perfect when you`re bored. You can also fly [b]literally anywhere[/b]. yes, anywhere from international hubs like New York to your own house without downloading anything, which is sensational. Though, there is a sizable catch: Some propeller planes, including the Cessna 152 and 172, Cirrus SR22 and more, like to just fail on me mid-flight, even with all assists, of which there are many. After the failiure, instruments suggest that the oil pressure is straight up gone, and I can`t get it back (probably because I`m not a real pilot.) And the Cessna 152, which is included in this list, is used in many flight trining missions, making them impossible.

Graphics: 10/10
The graphics here are an easy 10/10. They are just stunning, though they do sometimes fall short. For example, nuclear power plants get represented as round skyscrapers, which is quite funny. Ignoring that, the graphics are just beautiful and gefinitely fit for a triple-A title.

Download:0/10
The download process was absolutely miserable, chugging at 2 Mb/s on roughly 300 Mb/s internet. I started the download at roughly 2-3 PM and still had to do it overnight. Absolutely unacceptable.

Overall: 8.5/10
This is definitely a solid game, and it deserves its position as the best flight simulator. It`s quite expensive, but worth it.

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a breathtaking experience that takes virtual aviation to new heights. From the stunningly realistic graphics to the meticulous attention to detail in aircraft and scenery, every aspect of the game is a testament to its developers' dedication. Whether you're soaring over majestic mountains or navigating through bustling cityscapes, the sense of immersion is unparalleled. With its vast array of aircraft to pilot and the ability to explore the entire globe, MSFS offers endless opportunities for exploration and adventure. Strap in, take to the skies, and prepare for an unforgettable journey.

I have been a flight simmer since early 2000 and started with Fs2000. I graduated through FS9 and I have had FSX for many years now. Both in it's original form and as FSX:steam. I waited a while for this one to settle in and become established. I wasn't going to bother and stick with FSX and XPlane 11 (due to my clunky old cpu)
I downloaded MSFS 2020 on a bit of a whim (whilst on sale) as my computer is getting a bit long in the tooth ( 7 years old i5 with a GTX 970 graphics card and 16 gig of RAM). It JUST scrapes in on the minimum specs with a tiny bit to spare.
Disappointed? Flying a slide show? Hell no. I laugh to myself at the vast improvement over fsx. I can take off and actually recognise the area where I am flying without massive upgrades. i.e. I love Lanzarote, Tonight I took off from Lanzarote airport VFR and could easily navigate along the coastline of Puerto del Carmen and see the landmarks I know. This is with a vanilla, nothing added, install of FS 2020. it runs smoothly and I have not yet experienced any stutters or hangs 
Is it perfect? hell no ( I'm on the minimums almost, after all) Am i glad I took the punt at the sim? YES.
I have caveats: 
I have limited time in the sim and I have yet to try any of the big iron and yet to fly any of the dense environs, but so far so good.
Do I recommend to anyone in a similar position? YES you won't be disappointed. I love it so far

I wouldn't recommend it or not recommend it, it depends what you like and what you don't. 

Cons:

Other than that, the game is mostly pay to win in my opinion, you have to buy planes and liveries, etc. so I wouldn't recommend it when it comes to the selection of planes and liveries unless you buy a deluxe or premium deluxe pack.

The game is fully interactive, as well as you are able to set settings for which you can choose from realistic, simple and assisted. This game is really fun and time consuming, especially when playing on VATSIM where you can interact with real people in real time! Absolutely amazing. The views, wohhh!!! Listen- You should think about whether you want to download a literal simulation before you buy this game.

Say what you will about Microsoft's tactics, I don't believe their intent is to game the steam refund system- still, the result is the same, and they should catch flak for that. There are plenty of reviews that talk about that issue. As it stands, you literally cannot refund this game.

So, down to brass tacks. This is a flight simulation. Think "Train Simulator" but for uh... you know, plane "enthusiasts". You know the type. I'm their target audience. There are assists available for those inclined to explore interesting places, there's realistic settings for those inclined to get weird about flying planes and helicopters. There are... a *lot* of realistic settings, buttons, etc. Think of something, good odds it's possible to tweak it.

The game is stunning in most ways, and the fact that there are microtransactions doesn't bother me if the return is the level of quality displayed in the game. It's great how far flight sims have come since I was a kid. There are a few gripes that are solved with free mods, like tree height, or certain locations looking odd. Four years out, flightsim.to probably has a good enough answer.

You probably already know if you want this, and if you already know you want it, you're probably right. If you're not sure, plumb the depths of your mind and think: "Do I like the sound of the seatbelt light a little too much"

I got this game yesterday, it's been downloading for almost 17 hours none stop. It is downloading super slow and yes, I did a wifi download test. I got good wifi, a game of this size usually takes about 1 to 2 hours. Not this game tho.

This has been a very good installment of Flight Simulator. It is not for everybody even though it says so on the tin. More or less if you liked FSX you would like this. World is amazing to look at. Planes are impressive. Have a good enough computer to run it.

Downsides...
No accurate Crash physics...Game just stops and asks if you want to restart. Play something else if your goal is to smash planes together. Insane amount of Hard Drive space needed. Needs good computer to run ok. Also if game is choppy, the computer needs to reset, When I try to fly every plane in a day the cashes get full up, A reset of computer will restore performance. Also just because it is on the market place doesn't mean it is good, read reviews also any planes with weapons, bombs or missiles will not come with those visual options. To maintain a E rating they can not sell anything that has weapons, it is not a combat sim and even though you can get 3rd party planes with weapons they are visual and do not work. 
Upsides
Accurate ground textures I was even able to find my real life car...it was only drawn on the ground but from 4000' it looks good. Some areas they are LIDAR Data so you can see actual 3d cars and building faces, when it works it is scary how real it is. There are some building local to myself that have murals painted on buildings and they are visible in game. Good flight model. Very good for people who want to explore the world, and learn about aircraft.

Aside of this, many bugs in game, incorrect heightmaps, broken gates, etc. Sign in with Microsoft account often breaks, as expected considering the XBOX and MS Account sites are completely broken too. Servers for TTS and the alike are oftentimes down, not responding, so expect your ATC to be silent and to read a lot while flying your approach, switching frequencies over and over, before having to fly a go around because of a non-existent plane

Pretty expensive waste of NVMe space if you ask me, since I got barely a solid year of useful time out of this product, before they announced they were moving on.

What you get out of the box for a flight sim is quite a bargain for what you can pay for this software these days. Exploring cities in fine detail has never been more fun. You can also get a lot of the performance out of a fairly old and dated machine as long as you've got decent memory on the GPU and at least 4 cores for the CPU. It's not going to be ideal, but it's more than enjoyable. I recommend a decently powerful setup for playing this. nothing less than a 3070 if you can swing it.

After fixing the sdd i went back to resume the download to find i had to re-install the game from the start.

If my experiences off this game was actual gamplay & not just installing of game files I wouldn't have refunded the game.

*****To any NEW potential buyers know this******
You lose the right to refund this game the way Microsoft handles the download & install off the game files, while the game launcher runs in the background.

If in fact you do finish the install & have an issue with the game, you can't refund due to game launcher running in the background while installing the game files & yes this does count as game time on steam even tho you haven't played the game.

Am a little disappointed how bad the install process is & how it removes steam users right to refund the game without actually playing the game.

Updating review, as previous technical complaints have been fixed. MSFS currently receives regular updates, which on top of bug fixes and engine improvements, includes free content in the form of regional packages that add real-world details (to the point that you can accurately go on architectural tours in huge swaths of the world), and occasional 3rd party promotions that come with cool free aircraft and challenges: Maverick, Red Bull, & Dune all offer free aircraft and challenges (the Omnithopter is a special delight to fly over your favorite city in - big glass cockpit has open views and that thing can hover on a dime, fly backwards, do insane flips - so much fun...). All of this is in addition to the included flight lessons, discovery flights, landing challenges, the Bush flights, the historic flights, and the endless additional content in the Marketplace - it's staggering how much there is to do here. Where this hobby gets expensive is in the peripherals and add-ons, but adding pedals, a throttle, and a proper joystick makes it an immersive experience. The 5800x3D/4090 combo finally unlocked the level of VR realism that I'd been searching for decades - it feels like you're in the cockpit. The range of available aircraft is another huge realm of this experience - big, small, slow, fast - there is an option for everyone, but make sure you read reviews before buying Marketplace aircraft.
Real-world weather comes with fun Easter-eggs, like you can experience a solar eclipse in real time! 
There are add-ons that enhance the feeling of a living world (boat traffic, birds, etc.) that are worth it if you have $ to burn and hard drive space available. Once you download all of the free packages and start to collect aircraft, and you build up a rolling cache, your MSFS folder on your hard drive can easily go over 1 TB on it's own, but if you're into aerial sight seeing, then this is a must for you - it's a very good 1x1 map of the ENTIRE world to fly around in, and it can be nearly as beautiful, thrilling, and exhausting as flying is in real life.  X-Plane probably feels better in terms of flight dynamics, but it's no match on graphics; MSFS with all of that real-world Bing data - sometimes it's jaw-dropping how realistic it seems.

A lot of people were complaining that it took 3-294 hours (I know its a huge range) to download but I found that you may need to go to delivery optimization in settings (its under update and security) and make the download go on the local network and PCs on the internet along with going to advanced options and opening the bandwidth to 100%. If you have already started downloading then you should probably close the launcher and open it again and your download will work very smoothly. I had been downloading nothing for an hour before realizing this but then after I did this it took me about 1 and 1/2 hours to download.

100/10. Asobo and Microsoft knocked themselves out of the park with this one. This is one of the only flight simulators where you can take a trip in an airliner across the entire 1:1 globe that uses real time weather and traffic data. The immersion is so next level that sometimes you'll catch yourself staring out of the window of your 737 at a famous landmark forgetting that you're even in a game. It doesn't have to strictly be played for fun as a game either; you can use MSFS as an actual tool for practicing your flying skills, as well as standard operating procedures that airlines use, & even ATC communications which is its whole own thing. You can either use the default ATC in game or use a 3rd party software like VATSIM for real time communication with volunteered controllers for a more realistic experience.

Edit: One thing I'm not a fan of is this game takes 30 minutes to an hour just to load up (not even counting the time it takes to set up and load a flight) Sometimes it will crash (not because of my hardware) and it's so frustrating because I don't want to wait 30 minutes to an hour to load in, hopefully they fix this with msfs2024.

I get others have obviously gotten this game to work.  But after 61 hours, the game never finished installing - the MS installer just keeps deleting and redownloading/reinstalling the same files.    So it was just a perpetual update loop.  

And if I killed the installer, it would cause the internal SSD where I was installing the game to not be initialized on next computer reboot.   I had to move the motherboard SATA connection back and forth to get the drive to be recognized.  That happened 4 separate times - each after killing the installer from the task manager.  So whatever happened was real and related to the installer.

Fact is, this is clearly just a poorly written installer.  Yeah, it works for some.  But in my experience it was horrible.  And based on looking for answers on the web, I'm not the only one.

[h1]New review February 2024[/h1]

[h2]TL;DR:[/h2]
- 12 hours to download the 120 GB (on a ~120 MB/s line, running at a whopping 0.3 MB/s - sometimes 10MB/s but it never lasts), I don't know how many more hours to download all the free stuff available.
- I wish it was a microsoft game, they have decent servers. Oh wait...
- there's a menu to show the controls. Of course it's ordered very poorly, with shortcuts that don't make sense.

It says 17 hours play time at the time of this review. Don't be fooled, I've tried for the lasT 20 minutes to fly over my house, without success. And that is my entire actual "play" time.
The planes/helicopter behave weirdly, tiny tap on the controls, nothing happens, 2 tiny taps and they go into a spiral.
The mission planner or whatever its called doesn't like being told the altitude (good luck finding how to set it btw!).
That or maybe 500 ft is not acceptable so you end up at 5000 ft. So of course, you try and plan a slightly different mission. Guess what: it doesn't remember what you've just set, you can set it all up again. Whoever designed that: ugh.

As many other people on the net, I have super low download rates: 2 Mb/s, so around 300 kB/s (I'm feeling generous).
However, in the another steam-like downloader, I usually get around 1 Tb/s, which is around 100MB/s (yes, 500x faster).
It's not my computer, it's not my wifi, it's not my ethernet, it's not my DNS set to google or whatever, it's not my netsh config. I didn't try the VPN trick so it could be my provider but really, I don't think so.

Hell, at this download rate, I think they are pulling a prank.

It's been going on for years now so it will not be fixed.
Unfortunately for me, I have a special link to this game so I'm willing to endure this non sense.

[spoiler][b]Don't be like me.[/b][/spoiler]

Final word: after 22 hours of computer ON because slow downloads, I finally finished downloading 350 GB of game + free stuff. That's about 4 MB/s if I'm not mistaken. This is great - NOT.

I'm new to FS so I set it on easy, where you get a help that tells you what to do.
I selected mouse & keyboard to play.
I'm on the runway, about to take off, great. If I remember well, I chose the TBM plane.
Press Y for the outside/cockpit view.
Press B to release the brakes - doesn't work, I see that the handle didn't move in the virtual cockpit.
Then, the game tells me to press the "THROTTLE_INCREASE" key, without further information.
F3 after some research.
I'm starting to move, cool. I try to use the arrow keys to get the plane to move, nothing.
I press Y to get the outside view and the plane immediately stops from moving ???
I don't have time to painfully look the dozens (hundreds) of keys through the configuration UI.
Apparently, there's no official manual with all the keys either, I could only find some lists of keys of various reviewing websites.
Unfortunately, i didn't have enough space on my SSD to install it there so it was just a regular HDD.

I liked it. I flew a Cessna 152 that isn't rated for IMC conditions, no way to heat the windshield or even the wings during icy conditions... 

I live in Minnesota so obviously I had to fly out of my local airport MSP and Minnesota being what it is during this time of the year... I did't know any better and was flying about 5k feet of the ground, flying in clouds at the dusk of morning so barely any light besides cabin light which was a bitch to figure out lol, I had VR and it was immersive.

All if that was quickly ruined when I started stalling and the stall warning started me, made a beline back to the runway but couldn't even decend because the wintery conditions and wind or whatever kept pulling me back up. Figured in a moment of desperation I can loose altitude if I do a spiraling decend, done that and that came with more speed and by the time I was on the runway I was going to fast...

All in all it ended in a crash lmfao, fun game whether you want to learn about avaition or just like flying in general, must have if you ahve a VR headset and yolk/rudder

So far, it's true, I've been "playing" this game for at least 107 min, genius distribution of making you download an installer that would then download multiple small packages where the speed resets every time it starts a new package. Goes for 3-5Mbits/s then if it's large enough it will climb up by steps to 50Mbits/s then 100Mbits/s then to 209Mbits/s max. A little pause icon will appear next to XXXX.fspackageXX and randomly where the speed is displayed it will say "please wait". I know I'll actually be using the simulator but for the people who don't really know what flight sims are like they have no chance to refund it especially if you don't have an M.2 and 1gigbit down speed like me. One thing to pretend to care about being tracked while using a computer and probably a phone but it's another thing to make me spend two days downloading a game when Steam could have easily handled the download, weird to even let it be on the shop like this. The more reasons to make people sail the high seas, even just to try it out and then purchase it if you like it.

There is much to like about FS20, but it is flawed.

The update system is [i]infuriating[/i] and should be prohibited by Valve - essentially only the MSFS launcher is updated within Steam, all physics/general updates are done during launch, and then all scenery and world updates are done within the game. Conceivably, one could launch Steam, find a ~300 MB update for the MSFS launcher, load MSFS to find a 50 GB game update, then finally get to the menus to find 30 GB of world updates. I've clocked up tens of hours of Steam playtime just with the game sat running internal updates.  

It is a behemoth, hundreds of gigabytes with all the add-ons. It is clunky, confusing menus, slow to load and absolutely full of bugs and issues. I've completed challenges where bugs prevent them being recognised, I can't see some friends online but see duplicates of others, and so on, and so on. 

However, it is unbelievably beautiful. For ~¬£20 I would recommend just for the wow factor, flying around areas one knows in incredible detail. The regions with photogrammetry are mind blowing. As a fun game, it's also good, some fun challenges, not withstanding aforementioned bugs. It's certainly not worth it's full price (still ¬£60 as I write this review in Feb 2024).

If you are a serious simmer, and want something that loads in seconds, is physics based, has functional menus, detailed aircraft systems, and you can forgo the beautiful scenery (or afford orbx) - then X-Plane is the better choice.

I've played this a bit and I have several thoughts. For the most part it is a really fun simulator but the file sizes are pretty insane. If you have a beefy rig it will be graphically beautiful and I recommend an eye and head tracker. There isn't enough quality control in the marketplace so it feels like you have to research all of the dlc you might purchase. 

And I have noticed with the Steam version there is a bug that won't sign you into the X Box network, which makes the game unplayable at times and you end up having to uninstall, usually for a couple of weeks before they fix the bug, then re install. . Overall, I recommend it but with that caution.
me love it

2024 Update:
Asobo and MS have announced and plan on releasing a sequel to this sim, MSFS 2024. The 10 year update promise has been disregarded, ostensibly to address design flaws in the MSFS 2020 engine. If they address those key issues, like the launcher and its awful, slow download and installation process, then maybe MSFS 2024 will be an excellent sim. That said, MSFS 2020 will still have those major flaws. As it is currently, I typically reach for XP12 and DCS before MSFS 2020 because they have better flight models and I don't have to spend more time downloading updates than playing. Sure, they look worse but at least I can get flying. 

Original Review:
The best looking flight simulator on the market. The flight models vary from cartoonish to study level. Some of the aftermarket aircraft available have finally reached study level which is nice. There are some bugs which were present during the insider testing which have never been removed, such as the auto-pilot deciding to roll left and enter a suicide dive. This can happen in any aircraft, in any configuration, which is extremely annoying. Spend 10 minutes inputting a flight plan to the FMS just to have the AP try to kill you as soon as it's activated.

I need to express my frustrations with this product. As much as I want to like it, I can't help but experience a degree of buyer's remorse every time I open the game. My 152 hours played do not represent my actual in-game time. My views are built on a cumulative 500+ hours in previous MSFS entries.

[h3] tl;dr [/h3]
MSFS2020 is no more than a visually-appealing game masquerading as a proper simulator. The game's mandatory update policy and menu design are what I would describe as anti-consumer. The game is missing many tools that have been available since FS2002 (that I have observed). Avoid this product unless you need a shiny couch game.

[h3] The Good [/h3]
The game does deserve praise for it's visuals. An accurate world map being streamed to your session is an impressive technological feat, and it pays off in the flight experience. VFR flying is pleasant when you can identify real-world landmarks that you drive by every day in the real world. 

Flight physics feels... a little better(?) Than FSX. The juxtapose being I can pull the stick back on any given plane at stall speed and it will almost certainly hang at the edge of it's flight envelope indefinitely. I'm unsure how stalls are simulated with that said. This comment floats between the Good and Bad sections. Yes, my physics setting is set to realistic.

The flight plan map features a scrollable Earth to move around and select your dep/dest airports. If the map hadn't stopped being blank at high zoom in the past few months, this comment would be in the Bad section. Regardless, I'd call this feature an upgrade to previous entries' use of a panel with multiple dropdown boxes. Though it would be nice to have the filter options available here as well.

Airports don't look like copy/pasted tiles, as compared to previous MSFS entries.

G1000 is all-round great. Could use a Tetris button for those long-haul flights.

[h3] The Bad [/h3]

Edit- I've discovered that zooming in on the flight planning map too quickly crashes the game.

Edit- I've started dabbling with custom livery creation and am not surprised in the slightest with how inconvenient every step of the process is. The official SDK does not provide any useful information about livery creation, so I'm left to piece together information from various online sources. While confirming this statement on the SDK website, I found that the "How To Create An Aircraft" link 404s. I've nonetheless managed to create a custom livery despite the massive setbacks. The fruit of my labor appears to be somewhat spoiled, as my game now has random crashing fits while loading into the world or looking around too quickly. I can only deduce that this is related to the custom liveries but the behavior in which the crashing manifests itself leads me to believe otherwise.

Edit Edit- The game is now crashing before reaching the main menu even in Safe Mode. I suspect that I am being punished for this review.

Administration-wise, I'm not upset about the recent server issues causing a mandatory update to be unobtainable for a few hours. Downtime happens. What I'm upset about is players being unable to use their purchased software when an update is available. Leading to my first point:

Mandatory updates. For the love of god let me play the game that I purchased. Why is this patching not performed through Steam, like every other rational game? I allocate an amount of personal time to play your game, only to endure updates of 10+ minutes if I'm lucky. I've experienced a crash to desktop while in-game, and it then asks me to update when re-opening it. A customer should have the right to update their software when THEY see fit.

I'm pretty sure your flight information doesn't get logged if you're not signed into a Microsoft account. This is unlike previous MSFS entries where the sim itself maintains a logbook detailing every flight.

Content Manager is very difficult to find in the menus. How else am I going to update my scenery for <European country here> and jack up my MSFS2020 install past 200GB?

Flight planning is lacking a lot of depth. In previous MSFS entries, I had an IFR map in which I could drag my flight path onto VORs, DMEs, intersections and the like to form a complex route. Absolutely not a thing anymore.

Flight controls have just never felt right in this game. I've adjusted my joystick sensitivity curves any which way, but I've never found a good feel. Can't say the same for previous MSFS entries. Those just work. I won't deny this is probably just a me issue.

Differential braking in aircraft with free-castering nosewheels such as the DA40 is non-existent. Assigning keys to the Left and Right brake controls yields no results.

The Alt-menu featured in sims of old has been replaced by a developer toolbar that must be toggled on in settings. Absolute downgrade in every regard. The ability to take 4K screenshots is hidden in this toolbar, and having it enabled means you won't earn Steam achievements on your flight. No more flight replays, timescale adjustment, teleporting, fuel quantity changing, or in-flight failures. These are a huge deal-breaker to me.

Active Pause literally does not pause. It gives the appearance of pausing your game. When enabled, your aircraft stops moving but will continue accelerating according to it's current situation. Start a flight and ascend to altitude, then nose down and pause. The airspeed will continue to increase as if the game were not paused. I've accidentally had Active Pause enabled while starting up the A320 at a gate only to find myself unable to move. After some troubleshooting, I disabled Active Pause only to be flung forward into the gate at several hundred knots. This is a huge deal for me, as I'm usually unable to both manually fly the plane and be moving around the cockpit working switches. Severely affects the playability.

In-game cameras are not pleasant to use. In order to use anything other than the switch-through cameras, you need to navigate through that abhorrent floating menu in the upper-center of the screen and navigate through another menu that appears, then through several drop-downs. I want my right-click menu back. This wouldn't be so bad if the Active Pause actually worked, so I could navigate the menus without the pressure of possibly destroying my aircraft for a photo.

Camera "zoom" with scroll wheel is actually just changing the camera FOV. Entirely not useful when you're trying to move your camera up to get a vantage on something of interest. This is not how it's worked in previous MSFS entries.

ATC is just more limited and soulless when compared to previous MSFS entries. I'd almost expect voice synthesis to sound a bit better than prerecorded voices when the simulator controls the context.

Ground taxiing with AI traffic is laughable. They'll roll right through you as if you weren't there. Even FS2002 didn't do this!

The Bell 407 yaw stability is non-existent. Read up on some forum posts and was never able to resolve the issue. Unusable.

When using live weather, you'll occasionally encounter ridiculous spontaneous wind shifts. Sims in the past usually had pretty hard weather shifts, obvious by sudden cloud changes, but nothing like this.

Weather panel is more limited than previous MSFS entries, and I'm not entirely convinced the layers work properly, based off previous experimentation.

Water got a downgrade compared to previous MSFS entries. Any body of water is only a few feet deep, meaning aircraft do not interact with the water itself, but the land under it. Seems a very hack way of implementing this when previous sims had relatively good water systems.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
I'm just so disappointed. Thanks for reading. I will not be purchasing MSFS2024, especially considering we were promised long-term support on a jangly keychain. fuck Microsoft.

Pro:
> can use VR setup - can grab yoke, turn dials, and flip switches.
> more accurate landscape - easier to navigate by landmarks.
> has collision damage and engine stress - can fly your ride apart
> tame large aircraft physics.
> air traffic
> can fly the DC-3 included in standard line-up -- long live the legend.

Cons:
> less stable -- dependent on other auxillaries --- if one is not updated = program crash
> VR interaction is glitchy - imagine a touch and go - you're short and steep and you are irl flapping your arms up and down trying to get the flaps to step up.
> ghost collision - you are parked, doing a cold start -- suddenly collision / crash.....
> sometimes you start parked 2000 ft in the air --- pull on the yoke, see if the frame can glide from a zero velocity dead drop, and perform a cold engine start before you face plant.
> the larger craft handle well - but the smaller seem off... too tame.
> data hog -- over 80% of my current hours was downloading.

would still recommend as it has other options that brand X doesn't offer, everything on the plate is good training.

The game is mid for me, at least for a standard edition. I love the realism and graphics, but there are a lot of crappy things in this flight simulator. If you like fighter planes like F-16s, this is the game for you. If you like airliners, your options kind of suck. 

So here is what I really hate about this game. Developers, please fix some of these stuff in MSFS 2024, otherwise it just feels like the game is throwing money into a fire. 

1. The autopilot does not work. It does, but at a certain point the autopilot won't follow instructions or the flight plan. It is really frustrating and I overshot the airport dozens of times thanks to this.

2. Have more variety when it comes to airliners. I don't know if this a MSFS or small creator problem, but the options for aircraft suck. Several airliners don't even appear in the game, and if you hate one product for a plane, you don't have any option to buy another for the type (eg 737 MAX). 

3a. While on the topic of airliners, there are only three options for a standard edition. The A310, A320NEO, and 747-8i. And the livery options are really horrible for starting off. Barely any selection.

3b. And now I have to pay MORE money for liveries. 

4. I got into a stall a couple times and the flight assistance didn't help even attempt to recover. There were even 2 times where it nosed DOWN the plane at around 5k and 8k feet and wouldn't recover, even in an overspeed.

Those are actually my only complaints. I sort of feel like a Karen for complaining about this stuff, but 1 and 3a may relate to some. Also, if you want to buy this: Don't. Just wait for MSFS 24 to come out which (hopefully) should be this year. Unless you like fighter jets.

This game turned out to be one of the more disastrous games I have seen in operation.

Seeing my timeframe of 241 hours, it started fairly reasonable with little to no assistance needed to go places, to just go on a casual flight without needing to flight to nowhere. It was a nice casual experience to show people and to get awareness of what the potential could look like when having AI operate the game.

Today, you get the "No Takeoff" message anytime you want to go anywhere, have to risk starting your own airline venture, and risk having your plane crashing into the ground for no apparent reason because you didn't buy a ticket. I think after a while, it was okay at first, but now it's become an arm flex of pilots who know how to fly and do calculus with one hand.

In short, in its current state, it's not worth buying.

Embark on a breathtaking journey through the clouds with the Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition ‚Äì a celebration of four decades of aviation excellence that soars to new heights of realism and magnificence. This edition isn't just a flight simulation; it's a symphony of cutting-edge technology, meticulous craftsmanship, and the sheer joy of taking to the skies in a virtual world that mirrors our own.

From the very first moment, the Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition captivates with its awe-inspiring visuals. The level of detail in the aircraft, landscapes, and weather systems is nothing short of a technological marvel. Each flight becomes a panoramic adventure, whether you're soaring over iconic landmarks or navigating through dynamically changing weather conditions.

The 40th Anniversary Edition pays homage to its rich history with a fleet of meticulously modeled aircraft spanning the decades of aviation. From classic prop planes to modern marvels, each aircraft is a testament to the evolution of flight. The attention to detail in both exterior and cockpit views is unparalleled, creating an immersive experience that transports you into the heart of aviation history.

Realism is the hallmark of this edition. The dynamic and ever-changing weather patterns add an extra layer of challenge and authenticity to every flight. Whether you're navigating through stormy skies, witnessing a radiant sunrise, or experiencing the tranquility of a clear day, the weather system mirrors the real world with astonishing accuracy.

The expansive world map, powered by Bing Maps and Azure AI, allows you to explore the entire globe with a level of detail that is nothing short of revolutionary. Landscapes are recreated with precision, from bustling cityscapes to serene natural wonders. The open-world experience beckons aviators to explore every corner of the Earth in a virtual odyssey that knows no bounds.

The 40th Anniversary Edition is not just a game; it's a platform for community and creativity. The inclusion of a vibrant and supportive community, coupled with the introduction of the Marketplace and the ability to create and share custom content, turns this simulation into a living ecosystem that evolves with the passion and imagination of its users.

In conclusion, the Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is not merely a game; it's an epic celebration of aviation, technology, and the enduring spirit of exploration. Its unrivaled realism, attention to detail, and commitment to community make it a beacon in the world of flight simulation. Take to the skies, experience the majesty of aviation history, and immerse yourself in a virtual world that feels as real as the clouds above ‚Äì where Microsoft Flight Simulator continues to redefine the art of flight after four decades of excellence!

Short version: this flying game is a disgrace to the name "simulator", which it is not. If you want a simulator, don't waste a cent on this.  It looks like a sim but it really is a cheap Xbox flying game.

Long version: First things first, the interface is optimized solely for Xbox and is horrible to use on PC. Most interactions (inlcuding the most basic ones like looking around) require weird crtl-alt-shift-hotkey combinations, and some are even wrong out of the box (like propeller angle and mixture working in reversed order).
So your first job is to go through ALL the commands and correct them and map them to keys that are actually usable on a keyboard. If this is a console game, then why do they hype it as successor of one of the most important PC (not console!) flight simulators? Must be some neat marketing trick.

To the planes.. they look good and realistic at first glance, but most planes are equipped with the same Garmin G1000 glass cockpit, including the Beech Baron, the Beech Bonanza, and even the venerable C208B. Although it is realistic that all those planes did exist in G1000 versions in real life (not anymore though since the G1000 is discontinued in real life), it leads to all the planes looking, feeling and handling pretty much the same. And since there are no more 2D cockpits but only the 3D representation, the glass cockpit is very hard to read from the normal piloting view. That means in order to read or change something, you need to pause the game, zoom towards the controls, change what you need to change, reset the view, unpause the game. Very realistic flying indeed.

To the ground textures.. they are based on satellite images which actually looks pretty good as long as you're not flying too low. However, as soon as you start to log a few hours in the game and use different weather/season settings or even the "real weather" feature (which I already liked a lot back in FS2004),
you realize that there is only ONE set of textures. That means that when you use real weather and fly in winter, you still fly over lush green forests and blooming fields. And that looks so ugly and feels so unrealistic that I wish the old FS2004 graphics back, at least the scenery there would change according to the season.
It really makes this feel like some cheap flying game where they did not have the resources to implement changing scenery.

To the real issues.. boring planes can be replaced by community planes from the marketplace (there are a few good ones if you are willing to shell out the price of the game a second and third time),
and unrealistic scenery can be looked over. What cannot be replaced or looked over are the frequent crashes and the lack of some of the most basic and essential features.  Like saving and reloading a flight, which is not possible.

Because you're probably not going to believe it (I know I didn't), I'm going to say it again: yes, you cannot save and restore a flight. 
The feature does exist, but is horribly broken and seems to be broken for years already, but MS doesn't seem to care no matter how much the community complains. You may save in mid-flight, but when you load, you never know where you end up - sometimes in the air, sometimes on the ground, sometimes with engine running and sometimes not. What will be the same every time though is that your settings, autopilot and avionics configuration and flight plan are gone.
So you can forget about longer flights in larger planes.. all you can realistically do is short flights that can be completed in one sitting. And there is the cheap flying game feeling again.

And don't even think about just speeding up the sim during long flights with the sim rate feature.. that is botched as well since they didn't bother to put in a rate indicator. Happy guessing!

Don't think about just testing it either, since you can always refund.. you can't. Steam only gives you a small loader program, you then download the actual game from Microsoft. Their servers are so horribly slow that the download takes 10+ hours, which Steam conveniently counts as game time. So once you can actually
start the game, you are already way over the 2 hour refund limit. Another neat trick to prevent refunds.

So if you're ok with an Xbox flying game to take a few smaller planes for a quick spin in all-summer scenery, it's not even a bad game, albeit overpriced.
However if you want a real flight simulator, DO NOT waste your money on this one despite all the hype. You have been warned.

Boy, do I wish back the times of Flight Unlimited 3 back in the 90s.. working save feature, scenery changing according to season including moving animals (I'll never forget that moose on the runway.. ouch!), a working realistic damage model including damaged parts like a broken landing gear from a hard landing or damaged flaps from going too fast with flaps extended, and even realistic air traffic control responding according to the players actions (I'm still laughing about that tower controller yelling at me for making him spill his coffee after that daredevil close pass at the tower). THAT was a simulator.. and all that back in the 90s running smoothly on the simple computers we had back then. 
So Microsoft, what the hell have you been doing since 2004?

Microsoft Flight Simulator (MSFS) is a breathtaking testament to the advancements in gaming technology, delivering an unparalleled and immersive experience in virtual aviation. As a long-time fan of flight simulation, I find myself captivated by the sheer beauty and realism that MSFS brings to the genre.

One of the most striking features of MSFS is its jaw-dropping visual fidelity. The meticulously crafted landscapes, powered by cutting-edge satellite imagery and AI-driven technology, create an almost photorealistic environment that feels like a leap into the real world. From the sprawling cityscapes to the minutest details of terrain, every inch of the virtual world is a work of art. Weather effects are equally impressive, with dynamic weather patterns adding an extra layer of challenge and realism to each flight.

The attention to detail extends beyond the visuals to the aircraft themselves. With an extensive fleet of meticulously modeled planes, each boasting realistic physics and authentic cockpit details, MSFS offers a diverse range of flying experiences. Whether you're piloting a small Cessna or a jumbo jet, the sense of control and responsiveness is exceptional.

The world in MSFS is not just a static backdrop; it's a living, breathing ecosystem. Live traffic and real-time weather conditions further enhance the immersion, making each flight a unique and dynamic experience. The AI-generated air traffic and live multiplayer functionality add a layer of realism, turning the skies into a bustling and dynamic environment.

The user interface is intuitive and accessible, catering to both newcomers and seasoned flight simulation enthusiasts. The inclusion of in-depth tutorials ensures that even those unfamiliar with aviation can quickly grasp the basics and enjoy the experience. The various difficulty settings also allow for a customized experience, making it accessible to a wide audience.

The ongoing support and commitment from the development team are commendable. Regular updates and improvements, including the addition of new aircraft and regions, demonstrate a dedication to keeping MSFS at the forefront of the flight simulation genre. The thriving community and third-party developer support further contribute to the richness of the experience, with a plethora of mods and add-ons available to enhance and expand the simulation.

In conclusion, Microsoft Flight Simulator sets a new standard for realism and immersion in the world of flight simulation. Whether you're a seasoned pilot or someone dreaming of taking to the skies, MSFS offers an unparalleled and awe-inspiring virtual aviation experience that is nothing short of extraordinary. It's not just a game; it's a true marvel in the realm of simulation, and a must-have for anyone with a passion for aviation.

It‚Äôs complicated

I have had a lot of good hours on this game since its release in 2021. The game itself, the flight experience, the graphics and landscapes are beautiful and impressively accurate, thanks to live connection to Bing maps. Free addons can correct some minor discrepancies in the landscape and the sideload addon system is nice to use.

The big problem is the installation. The blunt truth is that the Microsoft installer is broken. Steam has a perfectly good installation system for large games, but instead of using this, it hands you off to the MS installer which just doesn‚Äôt work properly, redownloading the same files repeatedly, sometimes 50 times each. Crucially this bug affects updates as well, so you might be looking at 24 hours or more to install every update. It also affects the in-game content manager.

MSFS Support purports to attribute this problem to a bad connection. They have a list of 100 things to try rather than accept the problem is with their installer. None of my other internet usage is affected by my purportedly bad connection. There is a workaround for me: the problem appears to be an incompatibility in the game with wireless internet. If I move my computer to somewhere with a wired connection available, the installer works. But this is an unreasonable workaround. My internet connection is wireless.

The download bug means when I first bought the game, it took four days to install. I recently spent another two days trying to reinstall it, before discovering the wired workaround. When I bought the game I thought this problem had to be with MS‚Äôs servers, and would be fixed in a few hours. It still hasn‚Äôt been fixed. All this time has been counted in my played hours.

The game itself has otherwise been improved since release. There‚Äôs a fantastic glider now and a nice little Icon A5 floatplane. But every mandatory update spells bad news.

My opinion on this game is very positive. I've always dreamed of flying a Cessna and this game gave me that opportunity (I like small planes). I know a lot of other people in the reviews are complaining about the download time being miles long and such, so I'd like to share my experience with that... Firstly, when I got the game, the initial download on steam is about 1 or so gigabytes. Once you get into the game it may need to load for a bit, then the game will prompt you for a required download (the game automatically checks for updates every launch), which is a mandatory update being the size of around 100 gigabytes, which is quite a lot (It's downloading the whole frickin' world to your computer, so what do you expect?). So the time it took to download was a little over 3 hours. I've been having lots of fun with the hyper-realism for a few days now and I regret nothing with my hefty purchase. It's a great game worth the fair price it gives.

 Thanks for reading. =)

 Edit: I only play on VR because the default computer controls are wonky as hell and I don't bother changing them, but that's just me. Do as you wish (still an amazing game). I would recommend at least an I9 CPU, 24 gigabytes of RAM and a good graphics card for best experience in VR. I'm currently running on an I7 with 12 gigabytes of RAM and the game handles decently, but it could be improved.

Game has so many terrible bugs DO NOT BUY ·º±œÑ ‚Ç∑«ôœπƒ∏≈û ‚Ç≥‚Ç¥‚Ç¥
but when it works it's pretty fun

PART 1: ORIGINAL

The 18 hours I have spent on the game are actually spent downloading the damn thing. It keeps doing a chunk then resetting. I'm still trying to get help on this bug but so far none of it has worked, or the forums have been outdated. It seems that this issue has been around ever since release. Installing a f*cking game should not take this damn long. Do not buy this game.

PART 2: RANTING

After two days of downloading (most of the time spent troubleshooting), I got it to work. It works quite well and up until now I've been happy with the gameplay. THERE ARE SO MANY BUGS!!!  Most of the airports I have been to are PINK, you heard me right THE AIRPORTS ARE PINK?!?! I don't know how that's a possible error but it is shameful for a game that is so expensive and has been out for THREEE YEARS and more years before that going towards production I assume. I've played this game for about three days in total and every session has a bug or several. In the 747 when I load a saved flight, the throttle jams, the AI assistant dies, the HUD disappears (even after turning it on and off), and there isn't another soul unfortunate enough as I, to find a solution to these problems other than ending the whole flight.

Not only are there loads of bugs, the game design isn't nice either. I can't find any way to switch camera views other than pressing buttons hoping it doesn't do something unrecoverable. 

PART 3: THE TIMELINE

The thing that prompted me to write this is a long story. I was thinking "I want to see if they made my favourite place 3D unlike Google maps. Why don't I fly there from my home city Christchurch, in my favourite plane the 747!" And that's where the bugs start crawling. Just after pushing back from the gate, the ATC widget breaks and I can't stop the pushbakc until I re-tune it.

I brushed the first one off assuming it was just a weird scenario and it's fine. ((Note: The airport looks fine, it isn't pink)) On my way to Sydney, it was getting late in real life so I saved the game and went to bed. Next morning when I loaded up the flight (which took me quite a while to figure out due to peculiar layout), I tried adjusting the throttle and it didn't budge "Oh silly me I forgot about autopilot" Nope, even after turning off autothrottle it didn't move. I searched for ages online to find a solution but none worked. I really didn't want to lose my progress so I just restarted the flight hoping it would restart me where I was. While I didn't have to takeoff or anything, I was respawned AT SEA LEVEL. Rather inconvenient. If that was the only issue and it fixed my throttle problem (which it did) things would be fine. But.
Restarting the flight only presented MORE bugs, it hid the HUD, muted the ATC people (I have no idea how), and broke the autopilot completely.

After this  ÇhiœÑ Çh‚óåw I gave in and ended the flight. I set my departure to a custom location a while away from SYD, and when I added the pin, I can't change anything about it! I can't say what altitude, what heading, what speed, nothing! Anyway, restarting the flight fixed all of the immediate issues and I was happy. But then through the thick and low cloud, a Barbie styled eyesore loomed into view "What the F%^K???". Yep, it's Sydney. When I got within one nautical mile, the lag kicked in, and boy did it KICK. My computer can run MSFS perfectly fine with no hitches flying over a detailed city, but the short final to Sydney? Not a chance.

After touching down on the hot pink monstrosity, the lag started to ease off and I could taxi to the gate which was thankfully rather uneventful. I shut down my plane and ended the flight. Now for the next leg to Dubai! Not long after takeoff, the ATC chat stops dead, and then speeds up but without the voice, it's just sending the messages and not waiting for any would-be voiceline to end. It's just rapid fire and I can hardly keep up. Other than this, it's mainly fine.

On approach to Dubai, nothing abnormal happens. The airport is pink, and the ATC is fast and muted. It's all fine, I do a really good landing, I taxi to the gate, shut down, and that's another few more hours added to the logbook. But heading out of Dubai, something appalling happens. The entire right side of my aircraft doesn't work. It turns on fine,and it receives the orders from my throttle, but the engines don't do anything. At this point, I've had enough b ãllsh·º±œÑ and I have an itch to write an angry review. Here I am, pleasing that itch.

Looking back on my review I have no mercy for the guy who should be tasked with fixing these bugs. They shouldn't have existed in the first place. Thank you for reading this hand written review that is longer than all of my essay requirements ever, and please comment if you spot a spelling or grammatical error.

I really hate posting this, because MSFS 2020 is so feature rich it would be an absolute joy to run - if only it wasn‚Äôt still so riddled with significant bugs! I‚Äôm not a MSFS or Asobo hater - I still try to enjoy the simulator - but after four years it‚Äôs unbelievably frustrating to have to constantly deal with very basic feature bugs that can ruin the flight experience.

For four years I‚Äôve run MSFS on the same laptop setup. I only ‚Äúfly‚Äù with my laptop keyboard and built-in trackpad. So I‚Äôm not even looking for a perfectly ‚Äúreal‚Äù experience. But one thing I expected was for obvious bugs to gradually be eliminated - and certainly not introduced with each update!

A couple of examples: I set up some custom keyboard cockpit camera controls, just to make the flight experience a little easier. Sometimes they work, sometimes they don‚Äôt. On some flights they work initially and then all of a sudden not at all! If varies from day to day, flight to flight, despite not having changed any of the bindings! This behavior has persisted for years! I can‚Äôt imagine MS/Asobo is unaware of the problem.

Likewise, keyboard pilot controls are inconsistent. Sometimes a single keypress causes a reasonable bank to the left or right - as it should - other times it JERKS the plane one way or the other! This behavior is totally unpredictable. It often happens early in a flight, but can occur anytime!

Even the flight planner is inconsistent - you can select a time of day, then use the map to enter waypoints, but then discover the simulator has radically changed the time of day! What?

New features and options are great. The richness of the simulator is incredible. But continuing to ‚Äúenhance‚Äù the game while ignoring basic bugs is just inconceivable. Likewise, don't expect to see negative comments on the MSFS forum - the moderators will quickly remove them, despite how legitimate the comments may be. So MSFS 2020 had a great vision, but a horrible execution.

While there are still a significant amount of quirks/bugs that need to be or should have been worked out by Asobo Studios, MSFS 2020 is still a great title and IMO perhaps the most complete one to date. 

The graphics are stunning, the flight models are much better than previous title iterations and the navigation menu is friendlier. Again, these are my opinions only after having been involved with Flight Simulator since FS4 on 5.5 inch floppy disks on a Commodore 64 PC. 

With that said, bring on MSFS 2024!

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 has garnered widespread acclaim for its stunning visuals, realistic flight mechanics, and expansive world detail. As a virtual pilot, you're treated to an immersive experience that captures the beauty of real-world landscapes and cities.

One of the standout features is the game's use of Bing Maps and Azure AI, providing an unparalleled level of realism. The meticulously recreated aircraft, airports, and weather conditions contribute to the game's authenticity. The attention to detail is commendable, with everything from the play of sunlight on the aircraft's surfaces to the accurate representation of cities and landmarks.

The flight controls are highly realistic, catering to both beginners and experienced aviators. The game offers various assist options, making it accessible to newcomers while still providing a challenging experience for seasoned players. The weather system is dynamic and adds an extra layer of realism, affecting your flight in real-time.

The vastness of the virtual world in Microsoft Flight Simulator is awe-inspiring. Whether you want to fly over familiar hometowns or explore exotic locations, the game delivers an unmatched sense of freedom. The multiplayer feature allows for shared experiences with friends or other players, enhancing the overall enjoyment.

While the game's system requirements are demanding, the payoff in terms of graphics and realism is well worth it for those with capable hardware. Some users may encounter occasional bugs or performance issues, but updates and patches have been released to address these concerns.

In summary, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 sets a new standard for flight simulation games. Its breathtaking visuals, realistic flight physics, and vast world make it a must-play for aviation enthusiasts and gamers alike.

I am torn whether to recommend it or not, but I can tell you this: I find aviation as a real-life hobby to be 80% frustrating, time-consuming, and expensive, and 20% sublime joy (my ratio of "hours played" to actual time flying probably tracks that ratio too).  Good news: Flight Simulator 2020 simulates that all too well!  If you know that, and if you have a lot of time, money, and patience and you know what you're getting into already -- go for it.  But if you're just casually deciding whether to get into this -- probably you can have more fun elsewhere; this won't respect your time.

I've spent a ton on controllers (yoke, stick, throttle, pedals...), hardware upgrades to run it in VR (not to mention the VR headset)...  Over the years, from Flight Simulator '98 to this: it is a dream come true to be able to really sit in the cockpit, look around, and fly all over the world!  (I wish Force Feedback were still a thing).  The content updates have been a treat: the F/A 18 Top Gun expansion, the 40th anniversary additions (Meigs Field!), helicopters, sailplanes..!  (For the sailplanes, hopefully you like metric..)

But Flight Simulator will not make it easy for you to enjoy it.  Gigantic slow downloads that don't happen in the background.  An incredibly clumsy interface that makes it more difficult than necessary to actually do anything other than the limited discovery flights (which don't even include the scenarios it's showing you in those beautiful screenshots).  As of right now, the application crashes all the time (apparently some issue with downloading scenery or traffic).  Good news, though, saving and loading is hit-or-miss too!  (Hope you can get your flight done in one shot and that it doesn't crash on you...)

Beyond that, it's like Kerbal Space Program: some basic tutorials, but expect to spend a lot of time outside trying to learn how to do things, particularly autopilot.  If you poke around the site there are "aircraft manuals" -- the 787, 747, and Cessna Citation CJ4 have pretty good tutorial-type manuals.  The latter two are in the standard version -- by the way, another kick in the ... teeth ... is that the upgrade cost to premium is punishing compared to buying the premium version from the get go. I think it's like an extra $90 USD.  Sales on that are rare but do happen, but that's a big leap for a few airports and (let's face it...) the 787.  (You should also know that starting in 2023, first-party add-ons in the marketplace are 33% discounted if you have the deluxe or premium editions!)

It's very frustrating how close it is to being something incredible.

DO NOT RECOMMED!!! Have owned MS Flight Simulators since Windows 3.1. I am an absolute enthusiast until this game. How the mighty have fallen!!! Bought it shortly after release and at first I thought the issues were growing pains and it would get better over time as they did updates. NOPE! Here I sit, years later and still just as frustrated as day one. Graphics are great, game play is great, plane selection is great. When the game runs well, it's nice! However, I have well over 500+ hours clocked by Steam in hte game, and yes some of that is updates, however I only have just over 100 hours of actual flight time as of today. You will setup up a flight and at very random times, take offs, landings, mid flight, and/or in game menus, the game will do one of several glitches but all end with a frozen game with the last flight noises still being played or being booted out of the game completely. I have had a couple sessions to where I played seamlessly for several hours but most flights end in the game freezing or shutting down. I have upgraded my PC, adjusted setting high and low, have even tried on other gaming PC's and end up having the same experience. Call Microsoft and they are helpful right up until they find out I bought it through Steam and then they go to blaming Steam. Not a believer in that as I have the same issues with my free version through my XBox game pass...IT'S THE GAME!!! FYI the console version is a nightmare and still locks up. Anyways, if you like your heart broken on a regular basis, then this is the game for you. I'm used to it at this point and I'm always hopeful that I'll get a good session, but I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME!!!!

Fun but has problems. 
PROs
-Looks pretty
-Customization and modding support
-Very cool live data / traffic / weather options 
CONs
-Extremely demanding / power hungry. 
-Planes that should have been added into the base game are sold off as DLC from get-go. 
-A second installer has to launch and download an additional 127GB of data for the Sim to run; so half of my in-game time is actually just downloading the game. 
-A lot of larger international airports are unfinished, airport details are just painted on to the terrain. 
-Default control mappings are not great for HOTAS / common joystick configurations. 
-Game breaking bug that causes CTD during landing at random airports
-Jumping to a different point in your Flight Plan usually just results in the plane crashing, and the timescale / simspeed feature does not show an indication of how fast you are moving.

I had a realization that I love aviation and planes when I flew for the first time recently. While Microsoft Flight Simulator may not physically put me 34,000 feet in the air, its gets me as close to flying as I can get from the comfort of my own home. MSFS 2020 offers an experience like no other. The technology employed here to make this game come to life is insane. The airplanes are very detailed and offer a fun yet challenging flight experience, the graphics are stunning and the photogrammetry tech offers highly accurate rendering of ground objects. There is something really special about flying over your house or neighborhood in-game and seeing it exactly as it is in real life. While MSFS 2020 does a lot of things right, it is not without its issues. Occasionally ATC will bug out, at very unfortunate times too. Some achievements do not unlock even after the requirements were completed, and the list of other bugs goes on. Despite its minor issues, this is a huge upgrade to the growing family of flight sims especially its older sibling FSX. MSFS 2020 really does make real life look incredibly realistic.

Been playing various versions of MS Flight Sim since 2000, and I have to say this isn't just a great flight sim, it's a truly amazing bit of software, IF you have a powerful enough PC to run it. Happy to say that I do. It's also tremendously accessible even if you've never played a flight simulator before. I've generally played a lot of DCS World in recent years, and while there's a lot of fun to be had with that with its strong focus on military jets and combat, the learning curve to it is a huge barrier to a lot of casual players. Not so with MSFS 2020. Just pick it up and start flying. 
I find it nice and relaxing, discovering parts of the world I've never been before (and likely never will), or just flying around closer to home and picking out recogniseable locations. Looking forward to spending many hundreds of more hours on this, at least until the next iteration is released.

lam a 300 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. am a single father to my Mayonnaise, who is 216 now. ______Rant incoming______

Currently my Steam account reports about 32 hours played by the time i am writing this, infact I am in game right now on another system.
Huh why that.... you might ask?
Because the installer is sh*t, it is the most anachronistic thing ....... in the WOOOORLD as someone very famous would put it.
The trouble shooting guide for this game basicly reads something like this.
Kill all security applications on your system.
Do not intstall it where it self wants to install it...... Windows might not grant it all neccesary rights even if you are an Administrator on your own System.
Deactivate ipV6 on your system while downloading the Game.
Disable some network autonegotiation because the Gamesever might think a ddos attack is going on and will kick you out.

I thought this was all Microsoft .... why can't it just work.  

Now we come back to the 32 hours..... no 2..... yes two hours not more. Of theese two hours i was able to fly 1,5....
because a Logitech force feedback Stick is unknown to the likes of Microsoft.
After I got my head around the convoluted assigning of axes and buttons i failed to find the Force Feedback (FFB from now on) settings.
There are NO words to describe my feelings of disbelief  as i learned that there is no natvie FFB support.
WTF ?!?!?!? ...... is this a game like Warthunder or a Simulator.... i claims to be one.
You can find and buy 3rd party Plugins for FFB btw.
Ok but what happend in the first 30 hours you might ask ?!?...... the DOWNLOAD!!!!
A small summary of my Steam + MSFS experience 

1. buy the game

2. press button to install.

3. wait

4. !!!!Get forced to set up a Microsoft account!!!! see you next tuesday .... what is that for?
That actually brought me close to rage quit...... but hey Jeff, Mark, and Steam already have everything from me.... so Bill here you go as well.

5.Realize that you have essentially downloaded nothing.

6. Wait 8 hours 

7. Have the download interrupted by backgound noise from space.

8. Restart and find it now noly decompresses the files, so all must be well then...... RIGHT?????  no!

9. Download the update, come back the next morning.

10.Find out your game would start but the Pl ne s mis ng halv t e p rts ..... yes thats right neither steam nor Microsoft can determine if the download has gone according to plan.
To me i seems like it looks for the file structure and dosen't even check the file sizes, let alone a hash value.

11.open Steam hit deinstall.

12.Reinstall

13.Wonder why it only wants to Download ~70Gig instead of the initial 120Gig maybe it is replacing the broken Fliles since the first update only had ~60 gig.......

14.Learn that the Decompessing of files only uses ONE core of a AMD ryzen 9750X3D it has 16 btw. come back tomorrow.

15.Learn that your system crashed over night.(might due to broken files)

16.Start the game anyway and learn that the models are still broken.

17.Hit Deinstall again and find you basically only deleted the launcher. delete everything you can find related to this bloody piece of crap. comb through the registry.

18.Reeboot

19.Hit Install

20.While waiting another Day Let of some Steam and write this Review 

21. GET YOUR S  T togehter who ever progammed the installer! CHECKING HASH VALUES ON DOWNLOADED FILES CAN'T BE THAT HARD!!!!
Decompressing files with only single core support in 2024 is beyond me!
You get money for this for f sake.
In some cases the download is faster than decompressing, just for fun, as deconpressing was under way, I walked to my 1987 Amiga and zipped it's 1Gig system partition..... yes 4Gig hard drive support since 1986 eat this Microsoft.
And while it was doing that i played the very first Microsoft flight simulator on the pc emulator in that very Amiga, a thing called multitasking, you really should try it one day Microsoft.

This has got to be the worst game ever. 
I love flight sims and I've had nearly all of them since MSFS98 but this has got to be the worst pile of poo that exists. 
When it works its great but when it does not... 
It's the most infuriating polished turd you have ever seen. I don't have 60 days to trouble shoot why this piece of poo wont install I don't agree that My bandwidth for the month goes up to 1TB because I've had to try re install it over and over again.  
When I find I have a few hours to play I don't want to find some update destroys the install and then you spend an entire week that you had off trying to figure out what the hell went wrong only to find your entire time off you spent looking for a needle in a haystack only to get nowhere. not only that but the fact you have to run the game to do the install is completely idiotic your system runs at full tilt to download the content that is coming down at a trickle from the MS servers (25Mbs / 140Mbs Linespeed) So Downloading is a multi day event that your PC sits there running clocking up steam play time to MS advantage only I got about 20 minutes of play this week before the updates killed everything I hope to God that someone with some level of brain mentality at Microsoft figures this out and gets MSFS2024 sorted but that is a moot point these days because even if they get it right from day one there is no reason some underpaid intern does not screw it up 6 months down the line in another forced update.

Out of the 24 hours logged, 22 of those were spent updating, and I don't have a slow connection. Updates aren't pushed via Steam, they're pushed file-by-file at a fraction of your download speeds with the app open.

Microsoft is incompetent and if and when this thing works it's great, but you probably won't get to fly very much, because you'll have grown old and died before updating finishes. Shame on Microsoft for wasting everyone's money. I did not get my money's worth for this. The experience of constantly waiting on updates that fail and restart while time is logged can really be only described with really nasty expletives. Whoever thought all this was a good idea should never work on any software ever again. It's like waiting on playstation updates but worse, far far worse.

VR Review:

Although most of this simulator/game is stunning, unfortunately the VR interactions and implementation is a bit lacking. I am use a Steam Index running Windows 11 with some USB connected Logitech Rudders. Rudders work great, flight mechanics are spot on, and the 3D scenery is super immersive, but the interactions of the controls with my hand controllers are awkward, glitchy, and sometimes requires such intentional focus just to grip something, that normal operations become complete inhibited by the struggle to do something that should be simple (like when trying to go between flaps and throttle while landing.) Unfortunately, no amount of immersive ground texturing is going to make up for poor VR implentation. part of the problem is that you have to point at everything to be able to grip it. That works for most switches I guess, but not the throttle or the yoke.  I only purchased this to use in VR in hopes it would be better than x-plane. Now I;ve logged 15.4 hours on the game and I can't return the game to Steam, even tho 14 of those logged-hours was just the game doing it's initial in-game updates after the first fresh install.

Beautiful game/simulator. An expansive list of planes to choose from and the world itself is simulated beautifully. Mods are plentiful and you can do outrageous things like trying to land a B-737 on Lukla Airport (ifykyk). 

The only downsides I can think of are that the game can and will take the better part of a day to download if the servers are angry that day. Once you're finally in, you'll also find that none of the default planes are fully detailed/simulated, which is a bummer for something being touted as a "simulator". This is on top of a sometimes very silly AI-controlled Air Traffic Control that will sometimes have you doing really weird and unnecessary altitude changes as well as holding patterns that are a whole city away from the airport you're trying to land on; which of course ruins the immersion. 

Despite this it's a great game if you're a casual flight simmer.

This game had a chance for greatness because the scenery technology is astonishing and unrivaled. Very high fidelity terrain.

However, everything else about this game is bad.

- For a PC user, UI is a mess, dumbed down for XBox. Looking for or change control bindings, filtering airplanes and choosing one to fly - everything is a nightmare. They even have a basic controls screen which is completely blank and has 0 functionality. The interface even has a very annoying lag.
- Graphics are cartoonish, oversaturated and takes a LOT of effort to fine tune (nVidia filters, turning off irritating instrument popups etc). Even then, with a configuration well above recommended, it's just blurry, unpleasant. Vsync is turned on and yet not even working. 
- Few classic planes are available, glass cockpit are way too much. Physics are worse than XPlane, taxiing a taildragger is not different etc.
- Extendability and addons, the great strengths of both FSX and XPlane, are limited to an in-game marketplace.
- Not to speak of the initial 10 hour game client download which it takes to setup.

Verdict: strictly a  VFR alternative for XPlane, not your main sim
