Up front I just want to say for the last couple years this program has been one heck of an experience both good and bad!  I used this to see the world and it was one heck of a geography/history lesson if you combine it with some mods and the Internet.  So why am I not recommending it you may ask?  Because after 3+ years it is still a work in progress and still under performs in VR and only getting worse with each and every update! Also it still has immersion breaking terrain morphing and and other strange visual anomalies that almost NONE have been addressed or fixed since the game's release!  Even the very best consumer level PC money can buy WILL NOT give you a totally smooth real-to-life flying experience in VR and that is after a $7K investment!  If you spend your pilot life at 30K feet, then there are other products out there too for less to get your pilot skill up with more real-world instruction.  Get down low and this software can get you a general idea what the world looks like but it's still a long way from realism.  Case in-point; go search out your favorite waterfall, prepare to be disappointed, if you can see it at all!  There are tons of helpful Youtuber's out there with many suggestions to improve performance, visuals, etc.  Follow them all of them to the letter, some helpful, some with mixed results. In the end, you will experience so many high hopes to finally achieve a minimal acceptable performance level only to be disappointed again, and again and again. Deleting caches on almost every load up and tons of other regular maintenance is your burden and duty for now on; shame on a software developer to make us go through so many hoops just to tolerate their product!  What's next to do; delete the entire piece of software and reload fresh on every update????? No way, I'll delete it first for good, lol!  In lieu of these efforts, it's undeniable that this awful piece of software continues to degrade performance with each and every update this year!  If your system is just a couple years old in both processor and GPU, then your weathering the storm at a barely tolerable rate.  The rest of us however, are not!  My I7-9700K "seems to" be overburdened more and more with every passing update, however the data I have recorded does not exactly support this conclusion as I have contradicting data. (However I am not a software engineer and may not be looking at the most important data elements? Also my RTX-3080Ti seems to never be breaking a sweat, (steady at 45-55% GPU load) then a transient during the CPU spike every few minutes.  I have been recording data over the last 2 years since the purchase. Ironically though the data also shows the CPU not being overworked either, steady at 55-65% workload except every 3 minutes or so when there is a consistent CPU spike that off-loads the GPU and the frame dips for a fraction of a second to less than 10 then heads back up to a mere 23FPS in high density cities!  The only indication the CPU is over-burdened is the consistent latency spikes on some of the CPU monitors available to us on-line, indicating it's missing it's duties to send frames to the GPU,  Memory at 64GB of 3600 DDR4 is not the issue either!  My extensive testing is over a fixed area, (Downtown San Francisco), circle after circle at 500ft over the same area and over the past year I have had to steadily reduce settings to maintain the minimum Reprojected frame rate at only 23 fps!  (I used to get 30!) I see the exact problem at other high-density metro areas all around the world but my control area has always been S.F. USA.  Now I have settings so low that any lower and the visual quality is so bad it's, intolerable on my meager VR setup: a mid-low range HP Reverb G2.  Even in the rural areas, I used to get re-projected frames at 45 FPS, now it's steady at only 30 and I rarely ever see 45 FPS anymore!  There are continues and occasional stutters in cities because of only 23 FPS, but even in rural areas too all the time.  No re-projection mode= It's a stuttering mess everywhere down low, in-town or in the country: trees/buildings just blurrrrrrrrrrr on past, LOL!  What does this all mean with low CPU and GPU work load combined with abysmal FPS:  It's appears to be a poorly optomised/bloated piece of software only getting worse with every update!  At this juncture, I want to just delete the program and play other fun games that don't take a $5K system just to tolerate and still at minimum performance! And I have seen this program run on a 13900K with a 4090 on a Varjo Aero VR setup too! All that money spent and one "STILL" has to limit graphics settings and "STILL" does not achieve a totally smooth trouble free experience!  That advanced system still delivers an occasional stutter and immersion breaking morphing everywhere on the land; cliffs morphing continually as you fly past.  Buildings; sometimes there too. Even if you have an area pre-downloaded on your PC in high resolution.  Roads that look painted on and not carved into hill sides, roads under the overpasses in same direction like the program forgot to cut that part off when reaching the overpass. It's is still funny to see all these anomalies everywhere all around the world, LOL. Finally; weird holes in the earth, deep cracks in the earth that are not there for real, I even saw a river recently raised "UP" from the rest of the land around it but still in a larger valley for about 2-3 miles, ouch!  Looked more like a raised railroad track but with tons of sharp curves, LOL!  Still all this after 3+ years. I'm done!

For the price I paid for this simulator, I have experienced nothing but headaches.

You are required to create a Microsoft account, this is a real pain in the nut when you want to setup children accounts, the control profile system is confusing, I can only use windowed mode - can't run it in full screen because the mouse pointer is offset to the cursor - you will learn all kinds of cuss words you didn't know you knew. Wind effects seem incomplete/basic - it just wobbles the plane around in the same repetitive motion, and the game just crashes randomly. The best part about it is the complex cockpit controls and scenery but that comes with a whopping 160Gb disk cost.

Microsoft really needs to stop forcing things down users throats, like continuously suggesting Edge being the best browser in the world (which it is far from) as if I said "no thanks" the last 100x on accident. I bring this up because setting up a Microsoft account using Chrome simply doesn't work, and took me way too long to figure out just to play this darn game with my kids. Y'all insecure about your products or something... Just focus on user experience and people will follow.

You really need to improve the user experience of this game, as in cross platform users, yes.... Windows is not the only operating system in the world - And yes... you should pay just as much attention to other platforms as you do your own for paying consumers... Otherwise, match the product price per platform against your effort for quality and I'll shut up.

This is a spectacular simulator and experience in general. It is big though. This game would happily run off of it's own 500gb ssd, and if you plan on getting the deluxe edition, establishing a sizable cache file, and maybe adding anything to that, it really wouldn't be the worst idea. You're looking at about 200+gb for the premium deluxe. I've read it's closer to 156 for the base game. I've got around 500mb/s downstream, but the only part of this games internal download process that actually showed it's download rate showed around 350-400. The initial 2gb game files you'll get from steam will come in at your bandwidth limit, but the rest will not. This did take a few hours. Also, the installer might just hang on you. You'll need to reboot at this point, but for me it was actually done downloading, so no real idea exactly how long it was done but frozen. The installation manager will also attempt to default this 156gb+ into your user app data on the c drive. You don't have to install any of this onto the c drive, but the option was not immediately available for me. I had to select another drive and go into it before the rest of my drives showed back up on the right. Once it's all downloaded and installed, you'll still have an 8gb cache file automatically created in your user app data on c anyway (yes, despite the fact that you just told the thing to put all your files wherever you specified) You'll find in the options the ability to move this cache file to a location of your choosing, as well as to amend it's size. (bigger wouldn't hurt).
Get all that out of the way and it's absolutely breathtaking. This simulator in vr is transcendent. If you've got the hardware to crank it the visuals are absolutely astonishing. You can go anywhere in the world!
That being said, I am still experiencing an occasional catastrophic system failure on this one. System crashes, and I've got to power cycle again to restore gpu functionality, And each time this happens, it takes out AMD's "smart access memory" requiring me to turn off and back on resizable bar in my bios, rebooting repeatedly in the process.
Running a 5900x, 64gb ddr4 3600 cl18, 6900xt, on an x570 board. Temps stay fine, the hardware isn't being overtaxed. It looks like a memory fault issue. It's quite sporadic. It's happened after flying for hours, also just a few minutes into a session.
All of that being said it's completely worth the sale I picked it up on. It's expensive and problematic, albeit gorgeous and fulfilling.

No, I don't recommend Microsoft Flight Simulator. As other have mentioned, the download process is ridiculous. My downloads through Steam (and elsewhere) are very fast but through the MFS built-in downloader, it will take an eternity. It is as if Microsoft intentional throttles your download beyond belief. As a bonus, you can't get a refund as all the download time is accounted for in your Steam play time. The graphics are very nice but the mechanics and UI leave a lot to be desired. I can't even figure out how to move my camera around freely. I am stuck moving the camera through predetermined points. I am also disturb since many of the buttons on the cockpit are "INOP". Where is the 'realism' in that? I am staying with X-plane 11. While X-plane could use some better graphics, its mechanics are far more realistic than those in MFS.

This is a really great sim that I have to down vote for some simple reasons. 

1. MS Doesn't give a flying fk about you, your time, your bandwidth. If you move the install location via Steam it literally deletes 130+ GB in files you must re download. This may even be criminal, it absolutely should be. 

2. The installer negates any refund policy by steam as it takes hours upon hours to install via it's own installer, not Steam! Also because of this you can't limit the DL speed via Steam so that you can play other games online while this downloads in the background. 

Seriously VALVE? how do you allow this!? 

3. Installed files aren't in a single location but multiple locations. It's so convoluted that only MS could think it's okay.  Some of them you can't apparently ever move from the C drive.

4. Prepare to spend $$$ in the game to fix up cities that are auto generated and look... well not so good up close. 

5. Prepare to spend money on planes as well. For the type of person who wants to only fly say an F22 Raptor only, you can figure another 25-35 dollars for that plane. For the person who wants to fly a lot of planes you can spend over $60 each. 

There aren't a ton of planes in the base game, for a game that still costs $60 they should include another 20 planes and cities should be patched at no cost to look nice.

Between the plane costs and city costs and every thing else you could probably literally spend TENS of thousands of dollars on this "game" 

It's not a true Sim, it's not a true Game. It's something in between both of them. I really do enjoy playing it, I enjoy flying around in my F22, the graphics are amazing, traveling around the world is a super cool experience. 

But I will NEVER buy a MS game or product again after they criminally removed my download. A big FU to MS and frankly Steam should never have allowed that to happen as well.

Another note: Review says that I received this product for free. WTF. No. No I did not.

Well folks, it's 2024 and MSFS2020 still doesn't have good multi-monitor support.  It's there - but it's labeled 'experimental' because it's hard to use and doesn't work well.  There are dozens of videos out there with suggestions to make this work - which is proof-evident it just doesn't work very well.

As of this review  my 'play' time is over 100 hours - but my flight time is only around 20 hours because I've spent around 80 hours fiddling around unsuccessfully to configure 3 monitors without geometric distortion, stretching, etc..  i just can't recommend this to anyone wanting to use multiple monitors arranged panoramically.

This is the first new version of Microsoft Flight Simulator in 15 years, a game I have loved throughout the years.  Every version has its good and bad points - and this is no different.  A tradition with the flight sim is pushing the technology to the limit - you will need a high-end computer with multiple processors and dedicated graphics to run this game.  Fortunately I do have a gaming laptop PC, so I can run it fluidly.  It is also highly recommended to have a flight stick.

One of the worst failures of the new sim is the installation.  Even with a high-end computer and fast 250 mb/second internet connection, it took about 6 hours to install.

One of the best items of the new sim is the graphics - which can only be described as jaw-dropping stunning! The world and aircraft are nearly beyond true-to-life. The aircraft look like shiny metal with a hint of rust/icing if you so choose. The world has dirt blowing across runways, and individual blades of grass swaying in the wind. There are cars driving in the streets, animals in the field, and finally people that actually move instead of standing there like statues. Your ground crew gives you hand signals directing you how to park your aircraft after you land. There are lots of landmarks for you to explore to find using a "smart cam".

This new version also finally incorporates into flight simulator the use of real-world chart procedures for arrivals, instead  of only direct/vor-to-vor navigation.  ATC will tell you to proceed direct waypoints, clearing you for a published approach.  And, built in to the aircraft is the ability to select and edit those approaches.

Multiplayer is built in quite nicely, although there is no voice capability built in to the sim. But another aspect is taking real-time real-world aircraft, and putting them in the sim as AI traffic.  For instance, as I fly around Hawaii, I will routinely encounter Aloha and Hawaiian Airlines flights. AI traffic also uses procedures, freeing up much of the traffic congestion of previous versions.

There are numerous activities that are ready for you to try.  One of my favorite is the landing challenges, which grades you on your approach and landing to difficult airfields during adverse conditions.

A slightly disappointing feature of the new flight sim seems to be the flight model.  It seems to be overly simplified and too shaky at slow speeds. I'm tending to like multi-engine aircraft in this sim better because of the shakiness.  Trimming the aircraft is harder in this version as well. Use to the autopilot seems to negate this effect.

There are definitely still bugs in the program. The game has never errored out on me during a flight, but it has stopped responding after I land and I hit the escape button to exit to the main menu.  If I had not properly shut down the aircraft, sometimes the sim will not register the flight in the log.

The new Microsoft Flight Simulator has grown much on me, and I have flown it much more than the Steam version of FSX. The graphics really take the cake, even with a poor flight model I surprise myself (and my wife) by saying "wow!" under my breath for no apparent reason. I was able to locate and land a helicopter in the parking lot of my apartment complete.  The real-world graphics, incorporated from Bing maps, is detailed enough to find your own house.

The weather is system is nice - I have flown in thunderstorms to snow.  Icing does accumulate on your windshield and wings if the conditions are right. The anti-icing controls are active in the sim and seem to do a good job.

I hope this is helpful.  I waited for Flight Simulator to go on sale by 40% at Christmas to purchase it.  A new version is apparently coming out this year with an aviation career focus, so that should be interesting.  Happy flying!

This is a fantastic installment of the Flight Simulator series that brings a lot of new things to the table. The graphics in this simulator are fantastic, even when playing with sub-optimal hardware, which brings immersion to the next level. The simulation aspect, while it depends more on the available aircraft, is also good - most aircraft feel really good to control, though it is possible to encounter minor bugs here and there. While 3D photogrammetry isn't amazing, tiny details are unnoticeable most of the time, and most obvious errors can be fixed with add-on scenery. Unlike older editions of the series, this one offers something even for more involved gamers, such as full controller support and more game-like missions, like the Top Gun addon. Overall an amazing program worth every penny.

A hard "do not buy" for now. MS and Asobo have overrun both players and 3rd party developers with their announcement of the upcoming MSFS 2024, and while most people do not expect it to be a big issue, there is no hard information on the safety of any aftermarket purchases at this point. Wait until that situation changes or until the next game.

Adding to that, there are many blatant issues like a half-arsed broken DX12 implementation with easily reproduced graphics glitches that has not been touched in probably years, and Asobo keeps breaking vital parts of the simulation like avionics (or just the entire SDK) with moderate to severe impact especially on addon planes. Weird performance issues abound, the user interface is one of the worst in the industry, the flight model is officially worse than FSX. 

And if you encounter any issues and need to contact support, you are stuck with what I sincerely hope is some form of AI bot responding to support requests, because if that was actual humans, they are absolutely incompetent beyond advising you to just reinstall everything and hope for the best. In that light, I would not recommend spending money on Asobo.

The graphics are great, however thats only if you can make it past 1hr of even using the sim. If you buy this game just know you pose the risk of spending countless hours doing tweaks and changes to your computer just for it to crash anyway. I am a avid MSFS fan, but this game is a total disappointment and VERY unstable. If I could honestly get my refund I would. The game is virtually unplayable after a certain period of time. Imagine spending 30-45mins preparing for flights that crash on taxi to the runway..or better yet in the middle of a 2.5hr flight and you don't get to land. People will blame Mods/Add-ons as potiental reasons to blame, but FYI it also crashes 100% base game. Its developed poorly and only good for the graphics. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY. You have better luck waiting on MS2024. This game has been unsubale since the release in 2020. It is now 2024 when I am posting this. Its sad ASOBO ruined such a beautiful program.

I'm a student pilot with about 25 hours in my log so far, and I believe that the flight model in MSFS is superior to X Plane 12, as well as the visuals and weather effects. I used to be an X Plane 11 fan, however I do believe MSFS has out shined the X Plane franchise at this point for the following reasons: 
- Ground effect on landings is far more pronounced and accurate in MSFS

- The basic version of MSFS has a far more exhaustive selection of stock aircraft that X Plane, and the premium deluxe version, dare I say, has an absurd amount of craft to choose from right from the get go.

- P-Factor and related turning tendencies are more thoroughly modeled, wind gusts and turbulence feel much more accurate, and my favorite thing about MSFS is how at least GA planes (i.e. Cessna 172) feel during turning maneuvers when in gusty conditions.

- Communications, although really nerdy sounding (No one uses the phonetic alphabet to refer to airport identifiers and runway 29 is not "runway two-niner"), are more robust than in X Plane, and AI traffic is more robust as well in MSFS.

Now for the negatives:
- I have experienced a couple crashes in the ~16 hours of time I've played MSFS for, which is odd to me because I'm running Windows 11 on a mid-high end PC.

- I may be missing a setting, but I find it very goofy (and annoying) that the airport I train out of (Quakertown airport (KUKT) in Pennsylvania) has airport personnel with push back machines and a fuel truck sitting on the apron, and I often also spawn nose pointing against hangar doors. Non-commercial fields should not have airport personnel at all at non-commercial airports.

- The modelling of the local airports that I fly to IRL are not very accurately modeled in MSFS - X Plane has MSFS beat in the regard IMO, albeit apples to apples the textures are more appealing in MSFS.

To be fair to X Plane, both of these sims have great communities and a slew of mods to tune just about every aspect of each game, so one can conceivably mod X Plane 12 to look as good and model flight as well as MSFS, and anything that one finds lacking in MSFS can likewise be modified. I expect, however, that MSFS will require much less effort to fine tune to my personal efforts than X Plane 12.

In closing, it seems to me that MSFS is the sim to get for both non-pilots who like the allure of aviation for pleasure and pilots-in-training as well as experienced, possibly career pilots for training.

I welcome critique and alternate points of view from the statements I make above, especially since I've historically been an X Plane player.

If you are even remotely into aviation, even as a pedestrian enthusiast, you will thoroughly love this flight simulation. It is a totally immersive experience that really fascinates your imagination and gives you some sense of what it must be like for real pilots. Word of caution, the game is a complete platform with plenty of add-ons and mods available so it can be very system demanding. Not for the faint of Hardware...make sure you have BETTER THAN minimum requirements before even attempting to get this game. If you have a relatively robust system with good graphics, you'll fall in love - my hardware list is shared below for you, and that was an upgrade to enjoy the sim more. 
The other thing you need is time and patience to learn and enjoy the journey. I have over 5000 hours into the sim now (mostly commercial jet time) and feel like I am only beginning the journey. MSFS and the good folks at ASOBO work hard to give us a great simulation, so please be patient with them too as they continue to expand, tweak, update, comment, and blow our minds away with their amazing passion for aviation brought right to our homes!  

As a bonus, all of the Community Discussion Boards and Youtube guides available on various channels (even from real pilots) makes this a potentially serious hobby. Seriously, for you brand new folks you can literally type into the Google, Discord, or Youtube search bar, "How do I start my [Boeing 737] in MSFS2020?" or "What is an "ILS landing?" or "How do I calculate Take Off Performance in my Airbus A32X by Fly By Wire?" It doesn't matter what you are looking for, someone will help you out there, YOU ARE NOT ALONE in this journey, and some of these content creators are so talented, and just salt of the earth people, I feel truly thankful for them. Remember to support them!  Happy Flying to you!

Something I wish I knew beforehand, the game installer downloads from steam at normal speeds like you would expect. But the actual game files from microsoft download at an INCREDIBLY slow speed. Guys with 1gig ethernet are seeing sub 5 megabit/s speeds.  Frequest dropouts and restarts. It could LITERALLY take several days before you can play the game for the first time.  From the research I've done, this is not only a common problem with the initial game download, but people also experience this with updates and game add ons.

This game downloads incredibly, and I do mean incredibly, slowly. I left it running all night last night downloading just the ~120 GB that was the main game (not all the other updates that have to be installed after that if you want them).

Came back this morning, nearly 12 hours later, to find it sitting at 19% completed and crawling along at a speed of like 0.1 MB/s. Apparently this is an exceptionally common issue that has been present since launch, and they've just done nothing to fix it in all the years since. It has only become worse as the game as dramatically increased in size with all the updates they've done.

Worse still, the download cannot be paused or interrupted without having to start over entirely. You can hit the pause button, but close that window and you have to restart. I lost all 19% progress by pausing the download, closing the window, then trying to change some settings recommended online before restarting the computer to start the download again.

TLDR: This "game" is a scam - don't trust it - You *cannot* access it after a number of "updates". Customer support does *not* exist to fix the update-looping problem.

If this was classed as an alpha or beta version - then fair enough for the (endless) update failures to download.

Final update: Steam has refused to give me a refund to this farce of a product on the basis that "there's no evidence of a failure"... OF COURSE there's no evidence of any failure since MSFS2020 update systems are specifically *external* to Steams ENTIRE update process & ability to monitor!

REVIEW STUDIES: After going through many of the "negative" reviews on STEAM - SO *many* have expressed *exactly* the same problems. It's so reassuring that STEAM says there's NO EVIDENCE of any problems...

But who am "I" to say!? I can only speak for myself... Here are just a tiny few personal log examples that don't account for the hundreds of hours of attempts I've spent to beat the UPDATE looping (NOT GAMEPLAY!)... (all of which has *since* refused my ability to engage in this "game" in any sense what-so-ever, just saying):

Update: 4/4/22 at 99% of the latest 9gig update - it *LOOPED* back to zero percent.
Update: 18/5/22 Latest update - looping!!! Can't access *anything*. Over 10gigs gets to 90'sh% then Loops back to 30%.
Update: 7/6/2022; All efforts to communicate with MSFS2020 support (who-ever-they-claim-to-be) have actually failed in any resolution process of a simple software update downloads issue. Instead, their excuses of such a basic internet function have ranged from the most ridiculous of "local" failures ("my fault") to an apparent phantom "Local Content Provider" issue, presuming some sort of global conspiracy that their contracted service providers ("proxy" servers!?) are at fault without any accountability of any sort, and all the while completely disowning any kind of responsibility themselves.

Hope is always that the devs (whoever they claim to be) will one day actually fix things to a usable state... Until then - Stick with something that actually works like FSX.

Update (late june'sh 2022): I eventually uninstalled this product and will likely *never* attempt to reinstall it... the horror of this entire products experience *and* their "customer service" experience has left such a bad taste that's beyond reason for a product of this expectant calibre & price.

Summary: DISGUSTING EXPERIENCE.

Update: 31 dec 23: Obviously based on their very own posts & continued complaints from users, the update problem has not been fixed! I think it's obviously a design protocol to cash-grab and refuse server access to customers!
I'm furious and speechless at this scam - yet WHY with such an awesome proposition of an incredible flight simulator!? I just don't get it - but then profit ain't got no reasoning for customers...!!!

With 584 hours of flight time, here's what I can tell you about this platform (shut up people who call it a game, it's anything but)

I own the Fenix A320 and the PMDG 737. I have flown multiple GA aircraft in real life and was gladly able to hop into this sim and fly after doing one of the flight tutorials and a few of the discovery flights (I started in SU5 or 2021).

As I started to learn more, I finally understood the mechanics of aircraft and could finally fly without any struggles. I had recently purchased the Fenix and was able to start it up and taxi with no problems as I have completed standard startup procedures for the FBW A32NX before. If you own some of the add-ons, a VR headset that can run ultra graphics, and a PC that won't run at 15 FPS while your CPU and GPU slowly cry for help, I can definitely recommend this game. With the level of detail that it is, and all the improvements that the devs have made to it since I started in SU5, I will say this is one of my favorite games of all time, and I hope you enjoy it too.

READ THIS ENTIRE REVIEW FOR GOOD HELP,  This Is a very Good Game, I did not have A long loading screen as I am pretty sure it depends on your wifi or your computer but you definitely need a very good wifi network probably 5g because I could not use satellite scenery when I was on my 2.4g extender. If you want the beautiful scenery like the images look like you are going to need a good computer or an xbox or a playstation as my PC specs are: 24gb of ddr4 ram, GTX 1650 with Max-Q Design, intel core i5 11400h. I run microsoft flight simulator very well with minimum lagging when I am in very populated cities, and good frames when flying high in the sky. if you have a bad PC you can run this game, but with bad graphics. The cockpits and scenery are beautiful but one downside is that you are going to need about 120 gb of free space for the minimum game, but if you want all the scenery and airports than around 187gb.

this game does not support the nintendo switch pro controller or a mouse yoke because I have tried to use the pro controller and there is no way to use it. the mouse yoke does not work unless you use this special software that is janky because you can only you the mouse as a yoke and nothing else. 
the only control options this flight sim supports is a joystick or a xbox controller I think playstation can work too with some software you can also use a keyboard but it is terrible. if you are looking for a cheap joystick though you could look for a logitech extreme 3d pro as it is cheap for around 40 bucks plus tax and works very well you can pick one up at best buy. the xbox controller works for this flight sim obviously because microsoft made xbox so they only have support for their controllers which makes me frustrated but it is what it is. if you are looking for professional grade flight simulation than you should get x plane 12 as it is more realistic regarding the physics because microsoft flight simulator focuses mainly on scenery, you can get addons but the default cockpits do not have every switch mapped out. overall this game is an incredible work of art though from the scenery to the mostly detailed cockpits this game truly simulates what it is like to be a pilot.

Finally getting to fly this thing and maybe ten twenty hours of flying in I'm finally getting what's wrong with this game. It's not really flight simulator. Yeah the planes mostly look good and the ground scenery is nicely modeled for the most part. But I'm use to doing trans continental flights in my payware and feeling just slightly like a airline mogul, dropping cargo and passengers everywhere I fly. I just don't get that with this. MSFS 20 is like some over blown arcade game. The planes fly fine but without the realistic flight modeling of X-plane, and the plane systems seem to be lacking. It seems as if the designers never heard of autopilot. Which is in almost every GD modern plane. I can fly from a to b but it just feels like I'm always waiting for something to happen that never does. The educational components don't feel like real flight training missions but some quickly patched together shit for you to do with the simulator so they're not realistic and don't really train you in anything other than the annoyance of never being able to look around and do the things in the cockpit we've all come to expect in Microsoft Flight Simulator. I mean that literally. In FSX you can use the top hat to look around and zoom in and out. Not in MSFS 20, they messed with all the basic function keys and views meaning you need to use the mouse just to change views from inside to out and replaced the view everything with stupid zoom shots that don't allow me to use half the instruments when I need to.  You know most of the flight sim fans only wanted better graphics that run on a moderate computer, nice looking and handling planes that work and are fun to handle and the ability to fly where we want when we want. Adding more gaming things wouldn't have hurt as well, dof fighting with AI, using weapons, having a inbuilt career mode like AIrhauler2. These are what we wanted not some trimmed down arcade game that make flying feel so fake.

I've changed my review to recommend.

Original review
===========

They absolutely MUST fix the download problem before I can recommend this to anyone. It's next to impossible to actually use the simulator. I have 120 mbps connection and the best I can get updating their regular 40-100gig updates is 1-2mbps. It's insane.
===========

Ok much time has passed since the original release. Download speeds for content and updates are now not perfect but improved enough that it's liveable. The quality of the simulation itself is worth the inconveniences. Lots of good free content add ons since release. 

I like to play in VR. I've been using it with a quest3 via the new steamlink and it's worked pretty well for the most part. VR still needs some work. It's no exactly user friendly and control setups are a little touch and go, but it's quite playable if you have good enough system specs once you get through the initial setup. Once you're flying and your controls are working well the final effect is spectacular and visually unmatched by competing simulators on steam.

I really enjoy the simulator, it may not satisfy everyone for some it may to mainstream for others to hardcore but for me its great to relax, visit some places I already visited in real life, explore places around it where hardly anyone knows and just enjoy the view.

I would love to recommend this for others, but based on my experience I just can't if I want to be honest. 

Don't get me wrong, the actual simulator is great especially with third party addons when and if you actually get to the point where you can fly. So far my in-game time is 180 hours, of which something close to half has been actually flying. Rest has been spent in endless load/troubleshoot/update/reinstall-cycle. 

So far I've had to reinstall the whole simulator no less than three times which takes somewhere around 6 hours minimum each time with 100mb/s internet. I've also uninstalled and reset parts of the sim and updates way more than I should have. After Christmas I haven't been able to start the sim even once. Nothing should've happened in that time since my computer was off for the whole time, but now it doesn't get past the initial load.

Still after all of the issues I'll most likely keep playing in the future, but I could honestly only recommend this if you have incredible patience and don't mind watching terribly slow downloads accompanied by some elevator music for what seems to be countless hours.

Minus the really shaky launch, MSFS is definitely worth the 14 year wait from FSX from 2006 and a fantastic entry point to anyone who really just wants to sit back, relax and fly or even get into navigating through routes from point A to point B. 

Graphics - As incredible as it is, you do have building inaccuracies, terrain inconsistency and some jaggies here and there but overall, it looks insane. 

Sound - Yeah it sounds REAL good. 

Immersion - Yeah you're definitely going to feel like you're actually exploring the world and seeing all sorts of locations while piloting your craft. It is just insane. VR will be added later on but the game just looks fantastic on ultrawide for maximum iMmErSiOn

Realism - Yeah I'm no pilot, but the planes feel awesome. There's realism difficulties for everyone. You can make it as arcadey as possible or as real as possible. Keep in mind, the default airplanes are NOT study level quality (Study meaning, you can actually fully train yourself with licensed aircraft). Yes you will definitely learn so much from them but keep in mind, they're default planes. Temper the expectations but go in wanting to have fun.

Weather - Wow. just wow. You can adjust weather on the fly and at least at medium settings, the atmosphere is just unbelievable. Kick it up to ultra and you'll be puking rainbows like those trailers you've seen of MSFS.

At the end of the day, many sites are giving it a 10/10 or a 9/10. Do I agree? Not necessarily. You are buying into an ecosystem for several years. This cannot be a 2 year cyclical game. It has a road of improvement to go through for the graphical consistencies and some flight modeling bugs. It has definitely come a LONNNNG way since the alpha but as soon as some autopilot and flight management bugs get squashed, it still has some improvement to be done.

For a newcomer I give flight sim a 9/10. It's definitely a must-fly so you can see if you want in on this amazing experience.
I give it an 8/10. I know Asobo will improve this product and Microsoft will support it through the years so my review will change but in the state that it's in, it could definitely need some polishing.

Do I recommend it? Yes for any flight sim vet/intermediate player. WTF are you doing just buy it and try it.
Newcomers? Get Gamepass and try it out.

UPDATE - 12/26/2023

Asobo has constantly pushed out new updates, even improving graphics and optimization for weather and ATC. It's still not perfect but holy moly its far better than launch.

2023 update: What should you expect from Microsoft? Actually developing software that works like it's supposed to? Definitely not with MSFS.

The game wants me to download a 120GB update, which in theory should only be a matter of wating 2 minutes with my connection or 30 minutes with a proper cable/5G connection, it takes forever to download the update rendering the game practically useless for anyone with a job. To be fair, I don't get close to what my ISP claims to be able to provide, but the game downloads the 120GB update with like 10 MBit/s (not MB/s) instead of 300 MBit/s. Similarly to Microsoft Windows, I except them to deliver at least 500 MBit/s of download speeds for a software that costs 70CHF or more. I don't want to go into the whole Apple debate, but what Apple at least allows you to do is to fully utilize a fiber or 5G internet connection.

For the game itself, I can't obviously speak for the current version, but the older ones were just riddled with errors, glitched and generally unrealistic behaviour. So go for something proper like X-Plane, it's simply not worth it for the graphics to spend 15 hours of your time every few months to get some update.

Edit (December 2023):
Microsoft still hasn't bothered fixing many of the persisting problems in MSFS like the problem with slow downloads, also at least for me controller configurations get reset EVERY update. And also, the game was playable to some extend during 2021, but now it doesn't respond to anything when attempting to land (reverse thrust doesn't engage, AI tries to unalive itself, etc.).

Simply put, it has gotten to a point where like with many Microsoft products, it's unfinished, expensive and there are generally better options out there.

Best version of MS Flightsim so far.

The sim includes numerous enhanced airports and has a few aircraft as default, that would have previously been considered payware quality, thanks to Microsoft's partnerships with leading developers, such as iniBuilds.

Includes the SDK, which can be used to create various addons.

User created addons can now (in most cases) be added by simply putting them into the user's Community folder.

There are many excellent addons in the in-game Marketplace also, often at very reasonable prices in frequent sales.

What a unique experience. I tried it on mouse and keyboard.. what a disaster! Purchased the Thrustmaster T.16000M and it's made this one enjoyable ride. I went for the Premium edition on a heft sale (40%) so got it for ¬£65 and it's easily worth that for the experience of what this brings. I've so far found every house I lived in, although the buildings are a bit generic rather than the actual shape and look they are. My son took a fighter jet through the Grand Canyon and enjoy it too (he's 20), so there really is something for everyone with this experience if you have an interest in flight simulations. Overall I highly recommend this.

It was a bit of a headache to get Microsoft Flight Simulator installed. After an initial install on Steam there's a Microsoft launcher that installs the actual game, unfortunately when I first tried I didn't have my Microsoft authenticator app installed on my phone & by the time I downloaded it the Microsoft launcher crashed. Every time I tried to start MFS the login to my Microsoft account would fail & the game would close without any error message, After a couple of days of searching online & finally found a fix.

Despite all that, once I had the game running it's one of the best VR games I've played. The ability to fly anywhere on the planet while being immersed sitting in the cockpit of a plane really is incredible, It's surprisingly rewarding to create a route around a location I know & half continue to learn to fly & half sightsee, even replaying the same route multiple times.

it is absolutely horrible, I dont normally set reviews but this game was so dogwater that I wanted to refund it, also it took 9 hours to download and the 0.7 hours were me playing, the controls are so sensitive I have to buy a 2,000 dollar mini cockpit just so it can be a little better.

Cons: The game is expensive and non-Premium Deluxe versions won't have everything you want. The download times are excruciating and slow and may loop. Mandatory updates will unexpectedly take up the evening you planned for flying. It requires a beefy hardware system along with 200-500GB dedicated and faster than 10mb/s internet. And a joystick. And throttle. And foot pedals. There are plenty of small stupid bugs which have never been fixed and probably never will be.  If something is wrong it will CTD and you won't know what it was. Microsoft servers will go wonky at times.  Manual/offline cache never worked right. The documentation and public relations are nonexistent from Asobo/Microsoft.  The trees are random massive and even cover up highways. Auto-gen buildings look the same and are boring. I haven't noticed snow or any seasonal changes because of some setting.  Auto-trim will probably not work along with many switches and functions on some aircraft.  The flight model is stupidly simple and a failure will bounce you back to the Main Menu without warning.  Something will annoy you to no end, eventually.   
(Stop reading now if you just want to press 'Play' and fly immediately)

Pros: The PhotoGrammetry can be absolutely gorgeous and highly detailed, down to the rivet, in the limited areas available.  Visually you might even feel 100% immersion like you're inside a real cockpit traveling above the earth.  I caught myself wanting to land my heli and walk around that pleasant neighborhood. The aircraft models are highly detailed and without any obvious flaws to my experience.  Many addons are available as well as multiplayer servers with professional pilots. Most shorelines have been polished but the broken bridges and missing boats are a distraction to be ignored.  Large cities have most of the important buildings modeled with precision. I've only found a few places where the mesh did not look exactly right such as Monaco and Hong Kong.  The entire sim will run very well (30-60fps) on a upper mid-level system without PG.  Despite the many bumps in the road it will be an amazing experience at the end.

This game might be fun, that is if you can actually get the stupid thing installed.
I have fast internet and a decent computer yet every single time I try to install it takes hours only to constantly fail at the last moment every single time.
It either endlessly downloads the same 20gbs over and over until you are forced to reinstall the entire game, or it finally actually downloads the entire update file only to then tell you that you are "missing packages" with no option to download them and the only option to quit the game and literally reinstall the game from scratch.

Tried going online to look up possible solutions and although this appears to be extremely common, there is no fix beyond constantly having to reinstall the game over and over again until it maybe decides to work.

Also take note of my play time. Over 90+ hours and 90% of that has been spent trying to download the in app updates.

There are issues that preclude MSFS from being anything more than an arcade sim.

You cannot edit an existing flight plan you can only start from scratch.
Half the key bindings don't work. 
The devs seem unable to, or unwilling to fix these basic problems with this 'sim', concentrating rather, on how it looks.
Updates break more things than they fix.
Seriously, someone at Asobo needs to go out and buy a copy of FSX and learn how a flight simulator is supposed to work.

Microsoft flight simulator is a detailed game, with great graphics, and major complexity. Teaching the player how to fly a plane in real life, from learning the basic controls with a yoke, to cold starting an Airbus A320, Flight sim can be as simple or complex as you like. Additionally, you do not require a fancy graphic driver, but a good CPU. 
However there can be some issue's with startup, connection to the internet, and crashing issues. if you really need a good flight sim in your life and you have 150GB of free space, than MFS2020 is for you. 

Nevertheless, Microsoft flight simulator has been well thought, and it's very obvious how much work has been put into it, although there are still some issues, the game itself is everything it promises. However, given the price and how close we are to the 2024 version, it may be reasonable to wait until then.

I am playing with a gamepad and the controls are just atrocious. I am spending 99% of the time making corrections because the plane refuses to just fly in a straight damn line. It always goes up and down and every plane so far has a drift to the right.

The trim wheel is the worst offender. It always seems to either make no adjustments at all or proceeds to put my plane into a nosedive. The stupid instructor of the tutorial missions drives me mad with her endless babbling over and over again. Hearing about what her flight instructor told her for the 50th time is just annoying.

There are tons of flying games (including other sims like ED) I have played and they don't have these problems. Hell, I even played around 500 hours of ED with KB/M, making great kill streaks in conflict zones with a decked out vulture. The controls were buttery smooth for what they offered and I could dance around enemies with no problem. With this game, I can't even manage to fly straight because the plane seems to do things on its own without any interaction. I put my gamepad on the table and can literally see the VS of the plane going up and down and drifting off to the right every time.

I also tested playing FSX with the controller. The controls there are MUCH smoother and flying is actually fun. How Asobo managed to make the controls worse than on a 17 year old game is beyond me.

EDIT: VR is even worse. In the training flights with the Cessna, the throttle just outright refuses to work. I put it to 100% but the plane stay where it is, brakes are also set to off. When I put the headset and controllers down and start typing, it suddenly springs to action.

Now playing the game also bugs out my controller. It is still displayed as connected in Windows, but the light on the controller is flashing. I can't use the controller and the inputs are not being registered by the game anymore. This only happens AFTER I start FS. I have to completely turn off bluetooth and remove the controller/repair it for it to work again.

I just give up with this game. I know that sims require a bit of tinkering, but this is far from tinkering.

I'm a hobbyist private pilot and I don't get up in a real plane as much as I should. I've been enjoying MS Flight Sim using VR - it is immersive and helps keep me sharp on sight pictures for landings, etc.

The challenges have been fun, such as the landing challenges for difficult and high wind airports, and the Bush Trips, etc. 

Wish List:
I'm looking forward to hand tracking tech getting better so that I can manipulate things like radios and gps in the cockpit more easily. 

I wish I could get access to real sectional charts in-game to help with pilotage / dead reckoning while in VR.

I'd love access to more "low performance" airplanes, such as a Cessna 120 / 140, or a Luscombe.

This is the first time I have felt compelled to write a review.
I pre-purchased the premium deluxe edition 4 years ago, yet I only have 72 hours play on it (at time of writing).  The majority of that is through installing and updating the software, before the Xbox version came out. 
To be able to use this software properly you need to purchase a flight yoke and rudder pedals. Because Honeycomb and Logitech (the only affordable and viable options for these controllers) gave all their products to You Tubers during Covid, it took nearly 2 years before I was able to purchase these at a very inflated price, however I was able to make a few short flights, all was good (except the load time), and I was staring to enjoy the game.  
Microsoft then brought out the Xbox version and since then I haven't even been able to login to use this software. I don't have a Xbox, I have a PC, yet it still wants me to sign in to a Xbox account before I can even play this.  I have tried to come back to the game on several occasions to see if by some miracle the Xbox login had been removed, but no change there.
It seems this franchise is going the way of many others ("The Golf Club" been the worse case of this) and abandoning PC players, for console players, yet still scamming the PC players for their hard earned cash, in my case, ¬£120.00 for the software, ¬£600.00 for the hardware, and well over ¬£250.00 for add-ons which were purchased before the Xbox version came out (purchasing from the in game store is another horror story, being charged twice, and then not getting the add-ons), so nearly ¬£1000.00 wasted on a game I'm not even able to play.  
I feel Microsoft and Asobo have totally conned me with this game, and I advise anybody who intends to play this on PC, to seriously think again before purchasing.

I got a refund , but maybe just save yourself the trouble until the developers at least add support for Hosas and Hotas systems.  Even Star Citizen supports most flight sticks and its just an Alpha.

Buggy as hell. Offline version only works on ONE device. I have two computers, one at home, one at the office. Usually have a great internet connection...until I decide to play, or at a critical point in a flight. Downloading game files takes forever. I tried to verify my game files, and it totally erased the 125GB of files and restarted the download. Saved games completely wipe out the flight plan when reloaded. AND can we please get those trees away from the end of the runways? Airplane checklists are often incomplete. There's no indicator of simulation speed (this should be an easy fix).

Pros: Graphics are nice, when you finally get this POS running.

Cons: 
1. Buggy and feels like incomplete software
2. Updates only within the app itself, and won't update in background or overnight like normal software, likely to artificially increase the apparent "hours played" on services like Steam.  Probably not a problem if you're unemployed but if you sit down to play, expect to load the game then wait 1-2 hours for a MANDATORY update
3. In-game store full of garbage and hard to identify items of actual value amongst the plethora of re-skinned planes with default flight models
4. In game "addon packs" are priced at approximately double the pre-purchase packs; just predatory pricing for those that would otherwise support the franchise.  i.e. $48-60 for standard, premium deluxe is $96-120.  However in-game "upgrade" isn't $48-60 extra, it's $85-100.  For a 787 with a crap flight model?  Cool.  
5. Flight models are generally poor on all but the most popular planes (although the 787 is crap too), probably because of publisher pressure for commercial priorities over "true to sim" / gaming priorities

Pros:
1.  Absolutely BEAUTIFUL, can't fault the incredible recreation of the feeling and atmosphere - well done.  To be fair, the other sims on the market have all caught up substantially, but it's clear packaging and appearance are the priority for MSFS over all else
2.  The massive marketing machine of MS = driving interest in aviation and I can't be sad about that
3.  A 1.5 hour flight IRL costs $300-ish anyway

Overall if you're a teenager and your parents are rich, I guess have them buy you this, but I only load it up to show other people how pretty flying can be.  Otherwise I'd personally rather play DCS when I want to sim combat planes, I play X-Plane 12 for all other plane sims (their "beta" was more stable than this "final"), and I load up star wars squadrons to fly around and blow stuff up.

UPDATES: "You've played an additional 26 hours"
Sorry, but I have not.  I've got a solid 24 hours of updates in with 2 hrs of play.  In the same timeframe I've played >200 hrs of DCS, 50 hrs of X-Plane 12.  I'm reinstalling this now to show off the graphics of my new sim setup.  It can be fun, and it's a beautiful flight experience, but if I want to actually "sim fly", I'm going to one of those other options.  MSFS is useful to scope out scenic locations, and would be fun intro-level sim if the publisher tried to monetize *valuable* additions to product (I'm thinking things like more than 2 planes with flight models, working avionics, or training that even described basic procedures, stalls or steep turn or anything (although you'd need a flight model...)).  

But hey instead there are loads of skins, which DOES simulate how I feel about the color of the plane I'm flying -- which is that I do not care at all.  They know when you're flying a plane you can't really see the outside of it, right?

I bought it to fly with Quest 2 headset and I wouldn't advice this game to anyone who dislikes disappointments. It didn't run on my Windows 10 installation (I get a vague error message) so I installed Windows 11.
You cannot refund the game after having played with it because the first download takes more than 2 hours time off of your try playing time. When the game runs, it is very hard to browse through the menus 'cause it scrolls down an left in not time so it is difficult to select a menu item that scrolls away. I ran the simulator and, although the software knows there is a VR headset connected, it won't start in VR so you have to use ctrl+tab to switch to VR mode. It does not recognize a vr headset when I use Steam Link on my Quest 2 headset which is also a disappointment. Then, I end up in VR BEHIND the plane as default. Now, the game stucks in a loop when I try to fly in VR, so I miss stability and I am reluctant to continue trying to make it work 'cause I'm afraid I cannot deal with the disappointment anymore. Maybe I should stick with X-Plane. This is a typical MS product as far as I can see right now: Expensive and impractical and unstable. As a real life pilot, MSFS can be used as a great tool to practice, real world procedures, navigation, and communications. While the base game may not come with the best models for airliners, and will require you to purchase 3rd party addons to enjoy a realistic airline world, the popular Cessna 172 comes very close to what I fly in the real world. Combining the realistic Cessna with the beautiful scenery MSFS provides, and a 3rd party addon for ATC communications, like PilotEdge or VATSIM, I can create a very realistic feeling with the simulator. If I every fly an unfamiliar route in the real world, I can practice it in the sim first to get familiar with the sights I will see when I really fly, I can practice real world approaches, as well as other instrument procedures. Because the actual feeling of flying is hard to replicate, I strictly do not use the simulator to practice technique as it could create bad habbits for the real world, however while this may be true, I can still practice working procedures, and task management which sets a great foundation for myself when I return to the real cockpit!

No Internet?  No Flight Simulator.

I'm using Starlink.  It's the only thing available in my area.  I bought MSFS 2020 this morning, and it's been downloading at 20 Mbit/sec for the past 12+ hours, and it looks to be only half done.

Since I've had plenty of time to read up on this version of MSFS, it seems if your Internet goes down, the Sim stops.  This is a deal breaker.  You have to log in to XBox, deal breaker.  If you're on Starlink, when the Internet goes down, the Sim stops, deal breaker.  But, now that it's been "running" for the past twelve hours, apparently I can't get a refund.  

I haven't been past the "Installation Manager" yet.  Don't buy if you don't want to be held for ransom by Microsoft.

I have five hours logged in this game, but I haven't even been able to launch it yet.  There is a HORRIBLE bug with download speed, related to microsoft's launcher they force you to use.  I have gigabit internet, but the launcher is only capable of downloading at LESS THAN 1 Mbit/s! I've tried every workaround solution posted online and this is a known issue affecing many people since launch, there is still no solution.  Who knows if I'll ever be able to play it.

Update: 10 hours in, still no play time

I am now at 60 hours.  Still have not played the game once

The install procedure is FUBAR, but here's how to install in the shortest possible amount of time: 

 1. Clear your Steam download cache
 2. Run MSFS, and watch the update process. At some point, it will probably show 0.0MB/s for a while. When it does, exit the program and restart.

 The files already downloaded will still be there. I was able to download the update in a couple of hours, with maybe 12-15 restarts.

 After this tedious nonsense, there are still issues. Pausing the game will give you fill up elevator trim, and there are other peculiarities. The graphics are great though, and I'm enjoying the game very much, when it works correctly.

Edit: fired the game up for the first time in a few months and still a broken mess. Once I pressed play I was greeted by an update! Once again why do I need to download updates IN GAME when I've already updated it in steam! After an hour of waiting I was greeted to none of my throttle bindings being set and the bindings menu being utterly broken and refusing to load. After half an hour of waiting then troubleshooting I gave up and admitted to myself that I had wasted almost two hours on this game without ever making it past the menu.

MSFS can certainly be fun, but, this game is in a consistently broken state. 

First off requiring updates to be downloaded from within the game would downright frustrating even if the game managed to update quickly and consistently. Secondly the aircraft in this game have a shockingly large number of issues, missing functionality, and once again, are inconstant between aircraft. Weather is always buggy even at cruse (the wind will instantly swap directions at least once in flight so get used to it) and the flight planing in game is best ignored. I've ran this game through both the xbox app and here on steam and neither time did the game remember any of my previous flights and it would frequently change my settings too. 

Basically this game is alot like windows itself in that the original was good, yet it and all the other games since serve as the shaky foundation that the rest of this game is built on.

Thank god for world updates.
Hundreds of gigs of world updates.

320 hours = 100 hour achievement for flying. That means 2/3 of my time in this was spent downloading. 

For all the good it does, It fails at being usable software. The camera system is 100% broken in both settings and saves. Keybinds are bad - there is 'turn off avionics' next to the outside view key, and the button underneath escape catapults you up 10,000 feet. The UI is fullscreen and badly organised in a list view - there are general settings and control settings, but graphics are under general for no apparent reason. There is no tower view, the replay feature is there but you need to jump through hoops to use it - and mine is still greyed out unusable. The download manager will often fail at a random percentage and restart, leading to hours and hours of frustration just to download a gigabyte of data. If you lose your internet connection a giant error message pops up and you lose all your control inputs - woe betide you if you were lined up on final. Most of the aircraft are the most generic uninspired GA you could imagine - taildragger with G1000, Baron with G1000, Cessna with G1000... AND it doesn't quit when you exit so steam keeps clocking up hours. Approx 75% of my game time is actually downloading their updates. "Content manager" is what where you'll find your addons - and what's the logical place to find it? Marketplace obviously! 

And don't buy the Carenado PC12, the gauges have a memory hole that reduces the game to a slideshow. I've wasted probably 8 hours finding that.  

--

-Flight plans cannot be opened through the avionics (GPS)
-Crash sound is 'tinnitus' 
-Search doesn't work unless you know the ICAO
-Airport traffic drives around airports getting in the way
-No restart button on flights
-Warning messages steal focus from your controller (and you crash)
-Warning messages appear in the middle of the screen 
-Crosswinds are too strong making it impossible to take off 

But it's the most beautiful game I've ever played. 

X-plane 12 has helicopters, but it is the same miserable world as 11. If you enjoy VFR or sightseeing in your simulators, you should probably get this.

This game is great when it works BUT...

Hadn't played since April, thought I'd give it a few spins before my new VR headset arrives, and it crashes to desktop from the black screen before there's even a logo displayed or anything. I now have at least as many hours trying to get it to work as I do actually in the game itself. I've spent hours now tweaking drivers, doing uninstalls and reinstalls, every trick in the massive catalog that other frustrated users have accumulated since they released the game. Troubleshooting this thing is like trying to summon a being from another dimension. The error message it kicks is next to useless for diagnosing the issue. What a pain in the ass. They've broken the game in the 8 months I've had it and they're already off to work on the next version of the sim. Love to pay money for things that don't work.

12 hours of hunting and pecking through forums, Windows reinstalls, memory tests, and more finally led me to the culprit -- I just had to shut down the internal Windows audio server to launch the game, then I could re-enable it through Task Manager after the game launches. You know, normal stuff! Not a thing had changed on my system since I last played it so I have to assume this is something MS broke on their end. The frustration with this software is REAL. Of the 31 hours of playtime it says I have, only 4 were actually in the air.

If you like flight simulators, I think this is definitely worth a try.  This version of Microsoft Flight Simulator (since 2020) has some of the best looking, detailed scenery (which is updated in real-time via Bing Maps), and the graphics and weather simulation are very good as well.  Sometimes it can be difficult to distinguish screenshots of this game from an actual photo.  The visuals are that good.

I have always enjoyed playing casually, running the game and flying an aircraft around for a bit.  For that, I think this game does very well.  I actually find this version relaxing too.

Great game but it does come with its downsides.
Good things:
-really good  graphics
-mostly realistic flight model and airplane design
-immense selection of aircraft to choose from
-ability to chose airport spawn point from a map and just freedom to control the flight
-missions and different things to do than just fly around randomly
-the replayability, i have spent whole days doing nothing but flying around 
-no real bugs
-scenery looks way better than X-plane 11 if you're comparing sims
-adding on to scenery, it uses bing maps satellite view so you can set waypoints at your house and see your house in the sim which is pretty cool (if you have maxed out graphics)

not so nice things:
-impossible to refund the game because the installer takes over 2 hours even if you have nasa pc and wifi and also testing out the game and configuring and all that takes over an hour
-premium deluxe version takes up around 350GB of disk space
-pretty poor optimisation, the minimum requirements say 8GB of ram but you will need atleast 16 to enjoy the game properly
-base airliners have all panels and switches modeled but some don't actually do anything
-no good boeing aircraft included
-no good turboprops included
-don't buy this game if its not on sale or unless you're rich
-it is possible to play on controller but not ideal at all so don't buy it if you don't have a flight stick

conclusion:
good game if you want scenery, aircraft variety, graphics and realism. however if you don't have much space on your disk, have a slow internet connection and a bad pc in general you might want to reconsider.

TL;DR: The game downloads inside of MS Flight simulator itself and has taken me more than 14 hours to just simply download. I haven't played the game yet and I don't think you should try either. This seems to be only 1/5 downloads/updates

This entire time has just been the game downloading, I have experienced no gameplay and the download speed slows down the further I get into the download, it has probably been way more than 14 hours because steam doesn't update the playtime frequently while the game is launched. Basically the entirety of the game is downloaded inside the game with their shitty servers and way slower speed than any other download and this only seems to be 1/5 downloads. Normally the download would've been done within an hour on my computer, but this is way longer and then some more.

It's not even worth it for what the trailers show, which is usually way more quality than the game itself.

And before you say it's something wrong on my side, I have terrifically good internet and have the game's priority on high in the task manager. This is a known issue and if I can experience it, so can literally anyone else. The download speed is now under 4Mbits/s and decreasing. I only just got to 90% and I've heard of people who spend 80+ hours downloading the game while I researched this issue.

This game is absolute dogshit and should instead be a simulator for horrible internet connections, if there is no fix for this problem and Valve doesn't give me a refund, then I'm fucking done with everything Microsoft related. Microsoft is absolute dog urine filled dog water that is out of touch with the rest of the world.

Naturally, this is a very realistic flight simulator, and if you like aviation you'll probably enjoy this. Best played with a group of friends or even strangers found through online chat groups.

However, there are some downsides to keep in mind:

- KB&M support is tacked on, barely works, and it's basically impossible to fly without some kind of joystick. However, gamepad for basic flight and keyboard for advanced instruments works fine, as does VR with motion controls.

- The marketplace is borderline a scam, most of the planes on it are poorly made, with limited or no support for VR motion controls, and some lacking support for cockpit controls (clicking on switches) entirely. If you plan to use it, don't buy anything with a low rating, and even then be aware that it probably won't work with most control systems.

- The ATC system is terrible, and user made ATC systems like Vatsim are even worse. I recommend flying with ATC entirely turned off, or with a private group that has someone roleplaying ATC from the ground. You can't collide with other planes so ATC is more for roleplaying purposes anyways.

- The officially made planes, which are the only ones really worth flying, are very limited in numbers. Most of them are civilian aircraft, which is not a bad thing, but worth keeping in mind if you're more into military aircraft. There's also very few helicopters, and no non-helicopter rotorcraft at all. This is a plane game, don't get it expecting to fly anything else.

- There is no ingame chat of any sort, if you want human interaction you best find people out of game to fly with.

Abysmal installation process, requires hundreds of GB of update after initial installation from steam. Does not provide sufficient bandwidth for downloading, game needs to be restarted multiple times since decompressing of file stalling installation AND downloading process. Fiber optic capable of at least 500MB up and download speed is used for the installation.

My 9 hours played time is actually 9 hours long of installation time.

Google how many issues this game has before you buy. I have 20 hours on record now, about 16 of them have been diagnosing issues and trying to fix bugs. Im giving up at this point after I mapped my controller buttons but only one of them works. I can only use the rudder to turn my planes left, but the right one doesnt work. I unmapped both to start over, and even with the controller settings showing that I have no buttons currently mapped to my aircraft rudder control, the left one still works. But the right one doesnt. I tried to google/reddit the solution but theres so many issues with the game that it's time consuming trying to sift through them all to find someone with the same issue you're having. The game was fun for about 30 minutes out of 20 hours. I would not recommend you waste your money unless you like researching how to fix bugs more than flying and having fun. Several years on steam, 50 games in my library, and this is the first time I'll have to figure out how to get a refund.

I'll start by saying that Microsoft has built the highest fidelity flight simulator to date with MSFS 2020. It had its fair share of bugs and quirks over the years, but Asobo has put in a lot of hard work stabilizing and optimizing the sim. Having come from FSX, I highly enjoy this sim and strongly feel that it is a worthy successor.

Flight models are slightly less realistic than you'd find in other flight sims, but the inclusion of Bing Maps streaming and AI photogrammetry introduces a simply stunning real-world experience you can't find anywhere else.

I'm not recommending it to new simmers at this time due to Microsoft's active development of Flight Simulator 2024, and would recommend that new pilots save their investment until the release of the new MSFS.

If you decide to own MSFS 2020, steel yourself for some epic download estimation times with the base game *and* all free DLC regional packs coming in well over a whopping 250GB.

Rename it: CTD Simulator 2020 

Update: November 2023 - CTDs inbetween flights is also still a thing. Do too many things in a row and you crash when going back to the main menu. The heading bug of death is also still not fixed. Use the keybind for the heading bug a little to much, it gets stuck in a spin and the game will not react to any other imput anymore. ALT-F4 is the only way out. Unplugging USB devices may help but also often results in CTDs. Unplugging USB devices generally is likely to cause a CTD. 

Update: October 2023 - Random CTD during the flights are also still a thing. Rather than fixing some of the major issues of this sim, they opted to announce the release of a new one, so one can expect none of the listed below will ever get fixed.

Update: Jan 2023 - Long haul flights still cause immense FPS drops down to 25-10fps. This issue has been widely discussed on the official forums years. Asobo seems unable to fix this. Really makes serious airliner flying a huge let down. Apart from that many issues have been sorted out. Many I have listed below I haven't tried to reproduce now.

January 2021: Performance has been improved, but so many of the issues I complained about are STILL not fixed. Now they even managed to break the "set optimal mixture" key. It will stall your engine and won't let you set your mixture for seconds. They also managed to totally litter the world map with sightseeing POIs, even though you are not zoomed in. 
Adding new aicraft like the Hornet is nice, but it really feels like a toy. I don't expect it to be 100% but it could at least be as good as the FSX version. FAR from it.

October 2021: Still a broken mess. Losing controls mid fligiht, because the game will stop reacting to mouse and keyboard, because I dared to use the keybind to turn the header. That bug was there on release and they still haven't managed to fix it. 

If you are not a die hard flight simulator fan, stay away! At this point it is a buggy mess. Likes to crash and many features just do not work properly.

They messed up so many basic stuff up, it's unforgivable for such a hugely anticipated release. These are all I collected in roughly 5 hours of gameplay, plus the initial download time.

- forced music on initial start all the way through the roughly 4 hour download on a 150mbit line
- Disabling FS sound via the audiomixer worked until it did not, and played the annoying 1 minute looped music again
- It did not recognize my quite common (yet stone age, IK) MICROSOFT percision joystick 2, FSX would automatically assign controls to
- It did automatictally recognize my XBOX360 controller, would even show a graphic of the design, but not show the actualy bindings (FIX THAT!)
- It simply applies numbers to the buttons 1-X instead of calling them X, Y, B, A. RB, RT and so on. Have fun finding out wich is which. It's YOUR hardware. That is not properly included???? 
- When assiging keys and you assign a key which has already been assigned it may alert you, but it will not give you the option to auto unassign the old binding, but have both assingend at the same time, so you have to find that old binding through the 2000 options and unassign it for yourself (what the actual heck????)
- I had to unplug all my other controllers I have, which it said to not have recognized, because they would still mess with my inputs. Only happened in EA games so far. Good job MS, not asking me to simply ignore their inputs, unless I assign them!
- The whole design of the menu is questionable. Multiplayer is not really distinctive it seems, but thanks to the lack of an actual in game tutorial how to go about free flight and online mode, etc, it's all the same anyway. 
- Great to have spent 120‚Ç¨ to have many airports and planes, select them and look for liveries and I have not yet found one where I could actually change a livery. Wow.
- The great FFM (Frankfurt) airport EDDF has unassiged taxi ways simply showing the letter "X". I paid for that! FIX!!!
- Custom realism presets can not be saved!
- You can NOT save and reload your current flight simulation (if so, why hide it?)
- It was absolutely not obvious how to comminicate with other players fling around, even with all assits on
- You can't quickly tell players from AI traffic

Aside from these aspects, it's a solid thing. I find the menu utterly horrible. MS may reach out to me, if they wanna know what I think how to improve that.

Live weather worked like a charm. The overall flight simulation and cockpits are top notch. The many inop buttons are a shame, especially on the PRICY models like the dreamliner. For whatever reason I always start with 50% fuel. The ATC is extremely clunky and is even less fun to operate than in FSX. I made the dreamliner crash the entire game, no error message, could only ALT F4 out of it. Changing weather seetings gives me some solide freezes sometimes, for up no a few seconds. Using the steam overlay even in paused simulation will have the game recognize my inputs, which can turn out pretty nasty.

Edit: After an additional 13 hours I have had a few crashes to desktop without any error message. Happened when starting a flight. Happened when touching the wrong systems on certain planes. Happened after changing the weather. 

Edit No2: Another 22 hours later
The 747 is basically broken. The AP is ocmpletely crazy. It does all sorts of things and cant even manage to keep altitude when set correctly. UNACCEPTABLE.

Oh, and bugs are common. Sometimes autopilot will just turn the plane in circles, sometimes your ATC controls will vanish and you will be powerless as your plane gets backed into a building by ground control, forcing a restart of the flight.

But the best part is that the developers continue to push content on the marketplace as well as plan for MSFS 2024 while people complain about the issues that have been present since launch.

IMO, this is one of the worst entries in the MSFS franchise. I would rather they have sacrificed some graphical quality in favor of features and testing.

A highly-awaited descendant of FSX, right out of the gate it has a few minor issues (nothing game-breaking), but this is definitely the next Flight Simulator X that everyone has been waiting for since 2008, that everyone assumed would never make an appearance after the original ACES studio disbanded.

P3D is based on the FSX engine, and while it has been upgraded a few times, it still has some archaic elements in its engine that never allowed it to really flourish. This simulator breaks free of the shackles of backwards-compatibility, and opens up new possibilities with an entirely new engine. As of now, the IFR capability isn't as fleshed out as it is in FSX, but with a platform like FS2020 I'm almost certain it will be complete in no time!
