I know for a fact I like this game, as I played it on my fathers computer before purchasing it myself. but, the fact you have to spend a day or even the better part of two days downloading the game AFTER launching it for the first time means you will have at least a few hours in the game before you even see the opening menu. This is a problem for the customer experience, returns through steam are just not possible, and while I'm sure there are good server reasons that the files must be downloaded through the game itself, it is agonizingly slow. 

As far as the game itself goes,
It is flight simulator, if you like it you like it. don't play it if you aren't at least familiar with the basics of flight sims. A lot of negative reviews seem to fail to grasp that flying in real life (a simulator is supposed to get as close as possible to real life while maintaining fun, by definition of the genre) is not easy, and must be LEARNED. If you want arcade-y easy-to-grasp flying, maybe don't play simulators. That being said, I wish there were better tutorials for the sim genre in general. The graphics are pretty damn good considering what the game is, once again somehow people are expecting literally the ENTIRE EARTH to be modeled and rendered in high-quality at close distances. I actually have a hard time believing that those people aren't just being purposely obtuse with that criticism. I feel a better terrain and flora generation system would be doable however, and I wish some parts of the game weren't so unrepresentative of their real life counterparts, specifically a distinct lack of trees in very heavily wooded areas, but once again, this game can't do literally everything.

If you are new to flight sims, be aware that you MUST watch videos and might need to even start in a more beginner-friendly game before being able to fully grasp some of the confusing amounts of controls and advanced flying concepts.
If you are experienced, well, you definitely already have this game. 

Overall I definitely can recommend.

Short version: 
Nice graphics, decent flight modelling and fun to sight-see, but a terrible launcher with horrid download speeds that completely turns me away from wanting to get back into MSFS.

Long version:
The sim itself is fine, it's fun flying around and seeing things with the graphical fidelity that MSFS has managed to achieve. The plane selection (after 3 years mind you) is fun, with a mix of old and new, my personal favourite of the free planes being the DC-3 (as of November 2023.)

HOWEVER.

When it comes to downloading the actual content, MSFS falls flat, hard. I was constantly limited to about 5 Mbits per second, yes BITS, not BYTES. That's less than 1 MB/s (1 MB = 8 Mbits) for downloading 55 GB worth of content. Not only does the download itself take a long time, but it also decompresses and optimises the files during the download and then your download speed tanks again for each new file. You're looking at an entire day or more just to download content to make the sim's locations look decent. Why is this the case? Why is a game developer with a publisher as big as Microsoft still unable to fix this issue 3 YEARS AFTER LAUNCH? I really hope that FS2024 fixes the launcher, because if not, it will not be worth giving Asobo any more money for a sim that takes 100x longer than it should to download. I can download Red Dead Redemption 2, a 112 GB game, in about 45 minutes. This should not be taking as long as it is, Asobo.

As long as the launcher continues to be this bad, I cannot recommend this flight sim as you will go well over the refund time just downloading the game. Out of my 141 hours, I think a solid 20 - 25 are from downloading mandatory-update content for this game. That's insane. Do better, Asobo.

It has lot of bugs.
Many of these bugs were also in FSX.
You need lot of additional softwares to be able to play without bugs.

The general ATC system, the autopilot system of the planes, the side systems of the planes, the navigation systems and ILS, even the simplest tools like the lights inside the plane have many problems.For example you need an additional mod to add lights in night to the airport gateways unless you can't see anything.

Similarly, for long flights, for example, from London to New York, there is an option called "Fast Travel" or "Travel To..." which does not work properly and is not useful at all and is full of bugs, so you have to say goodbye to IFR flights , because at least in FSX you could activate sim rate up to 16x in autopilot mode, but in this version you can use up to 4x, and if you put more than 4x, everything will fall apart.

The new FS is only worth flying with a small plane on a short route.

With so many bugs the pleasure of a long IFR flight with a 787 jet is taken away from the user.


It is regrettable that this simulator is not well supported with all this potential, and even though it has been almost three years since its release and many updates of high data volume, it is still not usable.

The conclusion is that compared to FSX, the graphics are 100% better, more realistic, and more enjoyable, especially in the details of the aircraft, but in the development and simulation of a jet systems, it appears very basic and disappointing and has no resemblance to reality. It is not much different from FSX.
If I had the resources spent on this simulator, instead of working 100% on graphics, I would have spent some of my resources on research and development on simulating the principle of flight and the operation of a jet systems.

If you've ever wondered what it feels like to soar through the skies, not just as a pilot but as Maverick from "Top Gun," then buckle up, because Microsoft Flight Simulator is your first-class ticket to the skies ‚Äì with a side of humor!

From the moment you take off, it's clear this isn't your average flight simulator. It's like "Airplane!" meets "Top Gun," with a dash of "Hot Shots! Part Deux." Imagine trying to navigate a storm while Leslie Nielsen's voice echoes in your cockpit with unsolicited advice. You're trying to focus, but you can't help but laugh as your co-pilot, who bears a striking resemblance to Lloyd Bridges, decides it's a bad day to quit sniffing glue.

The graphics are so realistic you'll feel like you're in the cockpit with Tom Cruise, sporting aviator sunglasses, of course. And the attention to detail? Simply stunning. You might even find yourself humming "Danger Zone" as you execute a perfect barrel roll, only to be interrupted by a voiceover asking if anyone on board can fly a plane ‚Äì a nod to the classic scene from "Airplane!"

The controls are intuitive enough for beginners yet challenging for seasoned pilots. Whether you're dodging birds in a nod to "Sully" or attempting a landing on an aircraft carrier a la "Top Gun," every flight is an adventure.

But it's not all about the thrills. The game has its share of comedic Easter eggs, like a mission where you have to deliver inflatable autopilots or a cameo appearance from a rubber chicken as your flight mascot.

In summary, Microsoft Flight Simulator is the perfect blend of high-flying adventure and side-splitting comedy. It's more than a game; it's an experience that leaves you feeling like a true pilot, albeit with a few more laughs. So, if you're ready to fly, laugh, and maybe quote a few classic movie lines, this is the simulator for you. Just remember, "I am serious... and don't call me Shirley."

Great game with even greater MOD aircraft. 
Does it have issues? Yes. 
Does it take well over 2 hours to initially install and subsequently download any new update even with 200mbs DLspeed? Yes. 
Does it require its own 1Tb hard drive because of its size? Not far off. 
Does it almost kill my potato of a PC every time I load it up? Yes
Is it worth the above to take to the skies in the beautifully rendered ASOBO aircraft, free or paid for MOD aircraft (shout out to FlyByWire) and live out your pilot fantasies? Yes

Not even close to 2004 system... 1. calibration of equip. 2. aircraft selection 3. Flight training 4. Interaction with Display of airports 5. Interaction with ATC selecting VFR / IFR . 6. Taxing & Airport taxing & runways directions 7. Post flight analysis  8. Interaction with ATC conditions / com. with Ground / Tower / Center 9. Switching from VFR to IFR in flight . Many more but mostly the detail of the Display and tracking of aircraft including approaches airfields on the display.

On the surface, this is an incredible achievement and a glorious experience. Graphically, an immense step up from previous simulators, using Bing Maps and Azure technology to stream in near-photo realistic surrounds in the simulator, with live weather, live aircraft, etc. Although the simulator takes quite a beefy rig to play when you do find yourself in the thick of things you will be consistently taken aback by how beautiful the simulator can be. Your first flight and first few experiences will be breathtaking, whimsical, and exhilarating.

About a year I was stated that this is not the best simulator, in my case however it's getting closer and closer by the day, in fact, it's starting to be like a simulator more than just a game. It is great in so many ways at least but not it's not worth paying ¬£120 for the full package. I cannot stress how UK eccentric this is though, as the majority of photorealistic cities are in the UK. Even FSX had high def bump mapping and scenery in the UK and USA, and the rest of the world was lower quality, much lower lol. Still, with more products and addons being released, I'm changing my mind regards to that. Yet FSX is 20 years old. As for flight controls, I upgraded (2022) to a great device "Thrustmaster TCA Captain Pack Airbus Edition" before I was using a cheap Logitech joystick and the setup is so easy but a pain in the butt at times, and when you are able to get it to work, it works very well, plus once set up right, you no longer have to play around with those settings as it's saved to the cloud. On that note, third-party developers also make flight controls easy with their products and own built-in setup whiten in their EFB. The simulator has sensitivity controls, and over five pages of A4 are needed to print out the keyboard assignments. One downside is that two of those pages are for camera controls, and there is no replay built into the simulator, however, you can pick up a freeware addon!

Then, the honeymoon phase will wear off. The more you learn about the aircraft provided, the more you learn the avionics systems and how to actually pilot these planes, and the more frustrated you will become. There are still glitches and more rampant. It can be from something annoying, like having to press a button a couple of times in a row to get it to act right, to something game-breaking, like engine failures, autopilot crashing you to the ground, or autopilot not letting you follow your course. I haven't even scratched the surface, but the two main planes I personally enjoy flying are getting there. Third-party devs, like the FlyByWire team for the A320, are amazing, they have come down a long road to get to the point where they are now. I cannot help but feel sorry for those who had issues in the first weeks, but the truth is that many issues have been fixed, and fairly quickly. FSX is around 16 years old, and I have been using it for the last six to seven years and had fun with it, it worked out to ¬£3 a year (PAid under ¬£10). If this one keeps going for 10 years maybe 20 years, it's going to be worth it. 

Now in 2022, it's incredible the amount of modern-day DLC and payware addons for the simulator that you can get your hands on, from 100s to 1000s of freeware to payware, Yes expect bad and good addons. I always ask you to review before buying third-party addons, and also these that support regular updates. When first announced regards the simulator we had nothing, now we have the Boeing 737 series from PMDG and Aaerosoft has confirmed that they are aiming to release A321, A330 and also A350 as mentioned they already have Twin Otter (DHC-6 ) and CRJ 550/700 available to buy from the marketplace. Those that are legitimate about flying may also hear about the Fenix a320 coming in late summer. I expect my flight sim to be more complete by the end of 2022 with payware to good freeware aircraft, at least two good freeware helicopters, and all the functions of FSX in this one, so to find that the A321 in FSX has more functionality than the default A320 was disappointing, yet I fly the FlyBywire mostly. That coupled with the fact that Asobo is knowingly and admittedly rushing out patches from the start and continuing to break things as normal, however, they are improving and had many fixes and happens that when you fix things something breaks the simulator with each patch as normal but that's Microsoft for you, that being said we had amazing third-party developers like FlyBywire and salty for the 747 mod make a stranded default aircraft in something more realism. The phrase, "one step forward, two steps back" certainly was a big problem from the start and now, It's improved by a long dog. We learn from mistakes and also find a workaround for in-game bugs and errors, I'm not a game developer, and while like most people realize that modern-day publishers do not force developers to rush development as they want the finished workable product, it's just not acceptable in the realm of reality to push broken patches and break the game in such a manner, especially when a said company doesn't really do hotfixes.

The community meanwhile is growing, growing fast. There are so many addons/mods available, and the A32NX project is restoring the functions of the A320 MFD for free. We already have so many airports being released for free and utilities as well, so many that I can't keep up with it all myself. It's not all pay to play. For those who are into 747, we have a developer of daily making their own standalone 747 Aircraft, plus freeware workable simbrief integration A330 that uses the FlyBywire system. If you have forked out a small fortune for the Premium package, it's a real shame that there aren't many aircraft and from the start, you really think we should get two helicopters for free, instead, we get them through the world update packages. Or they release as extra money-making, Similarly, there is float/seaplane to get rather for free or payware, and that also is a bit off. As years go on we are finally getting more. So this is a technically impressive simulator, the scenery, graphics and AI are pretty high quality though, and flying at night and across scenery in the daytime is pretty damn amazing. It's great, beautiful, and serene at times when it works, but it will hopefully be addressed in time. it's going to be a long road still since the release back in 2020. Yet, as I'm typing now, it's amazing how far it has come alone. I have read reports that tell you the flight characteristics improving, aren't like when it was first released, once again thanks for the great support from the community, from others flying the Cessna 152 in real life, I know they will eventually improve it as time goes on, but given the way things are going, I have read people saying "you shouldn't be able to fly upside down!!" You know what? I don't care, most are in for the enjoyment, Myself for the realism. I used to use FSX and P3D and have flown too many aircraft, and this one is 10 times more realistic than FSX. I have also watched and listened to several real-world airline pilots flying the A320neo in the sim, and they are saying it's pretty realistic, so I think we have to say that it is more than 55% realistic or using third-party aircraft is 80% with the A320N, and at the end of the day, that's good enough for most people.Not everybody will share this "zero-criticism" but when you try to model 110,000 airports around the whole world, even 0.5% is going to be a large NUMBER of mistakes. The WHOLE world's terrain and is impressively accurate, but with the help of mainly freeware mod. MSFS has still a way to go but is almost endlessly expansible too; the default install package includes 

To conclude, I absolutely love this Flight Simulator game but it has a few flaws to it that I can recommend for new players unless you're a pilot or trainee or a beginner like me that very fully invest in Simulator games I highly recommend it!

MSFS is a fantastic game, takes 8-20 hours to download, that's how you know its a good game. But if you play on PC, keep in mind it will fry your CPU, a joystick is recomemded, The game also comes with many activitys such as flight school, bush trips and landing challenges, msfs also comes with a variety of aircraft such as the a320neo and the 747 I personally like flying in the B787-10 Dreamliner (only comes with the msfs deluxe premium adition) every plane is filled to the brim with a realistic cockpit, almost all of the buttons work, realistic thrust to weight ratio ect. And you can fly to over 1,000 airports such as KDEN (Denver International) and airforce bases to fly your favorite jets, and if your craving to get more planes, check out the community market planee, it has planes from the A330neo to the f35. The game will lag crazy if you don't have the right PC or XBOX but you can a just your setting to how you want to play the game, I hope people who are considering buying the game found this short, simple review helpful.

Major updates have further enhanced this simulator, its just glorius now, did a flight from Paris to London, full flight, exactly how I remember it from a few weeks ago.

Edit:

so its been roughly 4 months since release, and I must say the patch fixes and the updates have been continuous and regular, this in fact has completely changed the game, honestly as a casual gamer, im no expert on simulators, ive never flown aircraft before, the experience is breath taking and spectacular.

As mentioned I play on a controller on easy settings, that means anyone can enjoy this game, you don't need the latest hardware or flight sticks

The easy mode is like arcade mode playing GTA or Ace combat, that easy, I dont experience and game issues now, so its so relaxing playing this sim, choose your departure and arrival destination and take off, so far the furthest ive flown was like 1500 miles, though if you have the time and patience you could do longer flights.

If you want a chillaxing game where you lean back to enjoy the flight but also like a bit of adventure with the controls during rough weather or night time flying, if you enjoy a sense of achievement, then get this, also if you have friends and play multiplayer then it takes it to another level, you wont have kids playing this

So far its getting better and better, so im pretty sure there lots to come.

Updates has further improved this sim, VR is also possible, Ive also collected many aircraft for free, just as good as paid ones, from jetliners to turbo props to smaller aircraft, helos too, stay away from the boats though.

Nothing new here. Graphics is amazing! More game than realistic flight simulation. If you want something that is more realistic I would recommend X-Plane 12. 
As a pilot I can say that the controls for the Cessna-172 is pretty accurate on X-Plane 12 than it is for MSFS. One thing I wish that could be more controllable is if we could sit higher and see the cowling of the aircraft (172) maybe I haven't figured it out. My instructors always reminds us when doing VFR flying that nose on the horizon or something like maintain a fist of trees from the horizon to the dash but you cannot really do the same, but you can in X-Plane 12 (haven't tried X-Plane 11 but heard good things about that).
Regardless, this is a great game! If you want something more realistic give X-Plane 12 a try.

A wonderful flight simulator. The world and aircraft are stunningly beautiful. Just make sure you are on the higher end of the recommended hardware, especially in the RAM and GPU departments. Also, there are a few points during flight where I wished some things had carried over from FSX. For example, the AI ATC in MSFS is a step down from what FSX offered. I also think the simulated aerodynamics are off. The plane is prone to lurching more than seems accurate, for example. Nevertheless, the game is very fun and worth getting (if your hardware is reasonable and you're willing to wait a day or two for the install to finish)!

Keep in mind, the base game is big and does not include the world updates. Those downloads have to be installed manually from the in-game store, though, so you don't have to install map region updates you don't care about.

Great game for those who loves aviation. If your objective is simulate the procedures to flight an aircraft as in real life, I highly recommend start from the basic principles of the aviation, and pick up the Cessna 152 model in the beginning for your training flights. There's a lot of free tutorials on internet that can help you on this journey, starting from the bottom of the sim aviation. For example, I highly recommend a channel on YouTube called "Alpha Hotel Flight Simulator Training". Doing this, in couple months, according to your learning time, probably, you'll be able to fly more complex aircraft models, like turbojets, commercial air planes and etc. But if your objective is not to simulate as close to real life as possible, the game still give all the resources for those who want play the game in arcade mode, and it's very intuitive.

It's a Flight Simulator platform designed to replace the aged MS FSX.

Compared to competitors, this simulator places less focus on simulating the entirety of the aircraft system functions and more focus on visual fidelity. Still, the modular design allows for 3rd party aircraft which do simulate more of the aircraft compared to the built-ins.
Additionally, there has been a global avionics overhaul going on, which does affect (improve) the avionics quality of built-in aircraft.

An ever-wider array of bush trips and similar exploratory content is available with each update, capitalizing on the visual part of the simulator.

I do believe it is a great option for starting out with flight simulation in general.

Pro:
- incredible graphics
- very high realism in most details (YouTube videos from actual pilots confirm the degree)
- Weather system / Clouds quality is absolutely next generation level
- You can also choose live weather / wind / conditions .. which is fantastic !
- You see other pilots and their planes (collision with planes/cars/trucks is disabled, so, not stressful when people just ignore the rules)
- Great payware and study level aircraft available through the marketplace and 3rd party stores.
- Authentic simulation of ATC radio communication Airport/Tower... you even have ground services where you request refuelling or a push back for your plane..

Pro-verdict: 100% the most advanced, beautiful and immersive Flight Simulator today for PC
- we've got a modding community already working on new planes / buildings / airports / landscapes and even
bug fixes.

Con:
- It's not finished (Many elements in the cockpit of bigger jets don't work yet)
- The map still needs a lot of fixes/improvements, but since we're talking about the entire earth -> it is already amazing and awesome.. just, not finished. So, not a bad "con".
- Biggest complaint -> Autopilot. The autopilot for the jets has horrible bugs, and can crash your plane easily.
It's far from reliable ! More details in below in the dev-section.
- you'll need a high-end PC for getting awesome graphics with good FPS, but that's logically to be expected ;-)

Neutral:
- Many big buildings all over the world are missing, since that's enormous work to be done, and much of it will be added later and / or can be bought from community modders.

Verdict:
In my opinion, if you can live with not trusting the autopilot yet and wanna learn and enjoy, I recommend you buy. The game is already awesome.

An online buddy convinced me to finally take the plunge and shell out for this being a fan of DCS World and spending vast amounts of time and money on that already. I picked the Premium Deluxe Edition up in the lunar sale at 20% off which at ¬£90 was still a gamble for me. 
 
I haven't played an MSFS title since 2002/2003 but knew roughly what to expect in terms of realism, detail and live weather but I was a bit hesitant that it wouldnt be as exciting for me as DCS World. But that's the point. It's like comparing Gran Turismo to Euro Truck Simulator. Two totally different sims with different feels, objectives and experiences. But I'll get to that later.  
 
The install is HEAVY! Take ZERO notice of the recommended specs on the store page! By the time you've installed the game and any updates and free DLC, you're looking at 294GB! Roughly the same as my DCS World install. As I didn't have that kind of space free on my C: drive (SSD), I had to uninstall few other games on my D: HDD drive and install it there. I may have to purchase a portable SSD to keep both simulators on in the near future. Another thing about the install process is that it took me about 4 hours to download and install completely. I think this ate into my Steam "trial period" time so if I wanted a refund, I would have had problems. Luckily, I didn't need one.  
 
The first thing that struck me was the menu and options screen layout along with the music. The hangar option is a nice touch too. It reminds me of the Gran Turismo showrooms as do the challenges. I also liked the world map where you create your flight routes. If you turn on real clouds you can see the real-world cloud cover. And by zooming right in, you can actually see them move! This also enables you to set up a flight right where you may see a real-world weather event taking place such as a hurricane. Personally I thought that was a nice touch.  
 
The level of detail is quite nice if not 100% perfect when it comes to generating buildings in cities. Again, the live weather is pretty cool but that technology has been around since MSFS2002 so I wasn't as impressed as a newbie to the series might be. The game itself I find quite relaxing. I like to setup up long haul flights, leave the autopilot on and the dull droning of the engines can be very relaxing in the back ground when I'm sleeping, reading or streaming on another device until I get the call to begin decent.  
 
Nearly two years after release, this game STILL has a lot of bugs. Issues with systems on individual aircraft, atc issues, achievements not unlocking, AI (or lack thereof) I'd be here all day if I listed them all. The game has been out for nearly 2 years and has been in development for years before that. So why is there still so many problems? Each new patch/update seems to open up more problems too. Asobo and Microsoft really need to get on top of this. Reporting bugs via the site just gets marked "bug solved" which I've found out since just means it's been noted. No I'm not joking. Asobo could learn a thing or two from Eagle Dynamics on how to engage with their fan base on the forums especially when it comes bugs, fixes and upcoming updates. There's non of that here from what I've seen. No communication whatsoever.  
 
So is it worth getting? If you're into sims then yes, go for it. Although I personally don't believe the benefits of the Premium Deluxe Edition justify the ¬£100+ price tag. If I had the choice again, I'd just get the standard edition. DCS World is a lot more technical mainly due to dealing with the various weapon systems and tactics etc. MSFS is basically keeping up with ATC and perfecting your landings. The autopilot does pretty much everything else. Unlike DCS you don't need a HOTAS to enjoy it or get the most out of it. A simple XBOX controller is suitable and will work just fine. Again unlike DCS World, you also don't need TrackIR to look around with. You're in a small cockpit and going at a slow pace therefore it's not a necessity.  
 
All in all, 7 out of 10 but don't shell out for the Premium Deluxe Edition whether it's in a sale or not. This game STILL has a lot of work to be done...

I've never played any flight simulator until this one, and I am loving every second of it. There's everything an enthusiast for these kinds of games could be looking for in terms of simulation, but everything about the game remains fully open to casual gamers and novices. There are plenty of choices for how many assists you want and the amount of depth and consideration for accessibility makes me confident in saying that everyone can pick this game up and enjoy what it has to offer. You can play it comfortably with an Xbox controller with no issues.

Making your own fun is the best part of the game. My first flight had me flying in two remote locations across the arctic ocean just to see what would happen to the GPS when I crossed the top of the planet. I made my own fun ducking and weaving through clouds as I flew towards the sunrise on the other side of the planet, then trying to land on a remote landing strip despite a thick arctic cloud layer obstructing my vision.

The depth of the simulation is unlike anything I've ever played in a game before. It is a "simulator" title, but don't let that make you nervous. Anybody can pick it up and start flying. Can't recommend this game enough!

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a fantastic flight simulation & game with surprisingly good optimization despite its incredible visuals, even on systems that barely meet recommended requirements - noted as my grandfather, who used to be a pilot, plays this off a 12 year old dell business desktop on a spinning platter hard disk drive, where the only upgraded component is its used GTX 970 GPU (bought explicitly as that is the 'recommended specs' GPU for this game). The support is phenomenal, and despite the game's large size requirements, the decision to allow updates to be individually cherry-picked so you can improve the areas you fly most often - saving disk space wherever possible - is fantastic. I would love to see features like this in other large games. 
Flight models have been regularly improved for aircraft based on community feedback over the years when Asobo & Microsoft realized how much of a hardcore fanbase MSFS brought in compared to the casual audience, and the amount of free content provided to the game is outstanding even if you don't purchase the deluxe / premium deluxe versions. Asobo has worked with multiple major third-party addon creators to bring high-quality updates to the aircraft as well as entirely new planes, such as the free study-level A310, upcoming update to the A320, updates to the Garmin navigation systems to make them true-to-life, flight models and system quirks of aircraft including the Cessna Citation series aircraft, etc. Speaking both for myself and my grandfather, as both of us have been regular MSFS users since Flight Simulator 95, this is by far the best the series has ever been.

HOWEVER. The biggest drawback, and perhaps only truly major drawback to this game, is the launcher. The MSFS launcher is incredibly resource-heavy, eating up your CPU and GPU while open - and the launcher is the only method to download and update the game. You are only downloading the launcher when you purchase and install this product. 
The launcher is not fast at downloading either, capping out well below whatever your maximum download speed is. For those of you with download speeds in the gigabyte+ range, this is probably not an issue you'll notice or care about - but for anyone with slower, cheaper urban internet plans or rural internet connections, you will be stuck on that launcher for a very long time when installing or updating the game. All of this counts towards your game time as well, meaning you will lose the ability to refund the game just by installing it as you'll far surpass the 2 hour mark. The download is also prone to freezing and erroring out during peak download times, such as directly following a major content update - and fixing this often requires manual intervention and more headaches.

Essentially, you need to know this is a product you will enjoy BEFORE purchasing it if you know your internet will push you past the refund window. If you're a casual fan looking to get into flying, then you can't start in a better place than here - but just make sure you've done some research and know you won't want to refund it before jumping in.
Very fun, lots of challenges and you are completely free!

1st major concern is that this game is violating Steam terms and is simply non-refundable, because the 1st 2 hours you have for testing it (even more) you need to spend on mandatory update downloading when you first launch the game. Steam thinks you're playing it while you're watching a progress bar. I have an ultra fast non-shared optical fibre connection and it took many hours to finish (not to mention the hdd space it takes, it's just ridiculous).

2nd thing is that it is just NOT for everyone. Basically if you know nothing about planes, you'll only get some few basic introduction tutorials that will get you into air and back in just 2 planes (+some basic flying techniques on the most basic plane). For the jet, there are literally just simplistic starting and landing tutorials, without much explanation why you are doing those things, and there are hundreds of controls in those planes, not to mention all the procedures. This is something that if you are hoping for (I was), you will be very disappointed.

3rd thing is the "whole world available" thing. If you are hoping that you will fly over your town or house, you will be very disappointed too. It is literally like flying over a flat google map image, with just reflections added to water + some houses converted into random 3D models (not matching reality in any way).

The game is also hard to master with an ordinary xbox controller, the joystick is just too sensitive. For me it was just not very fun because of this and in general I really regret buying this game, despite buying it on one of the biggest discounts that you can get in more than year of waiting. I could get (one and a half of) another, much more entertaining game that I'm hunting for (for a good price, I'm a patient guy and I already have more games than I can play) without any discount at all, since it offers a demo and I know that it's very good.

Having said that, I can recommend this game for pilots and hobbyists that know their stuff and are playing other plane simulators, because it probably is one of the best ones (if you don't mind financing Bill Gates and his "philanthrophy" of course üòâ). I'm saying "probably" because I have seen only a few and they were overwhelming for a beginner and had zero tutorials. You will most likely not care about the ground looking bad from close distance, you are used to worse than that, while from above everything looks perfect and the plane simulation is probably perfect (I can't judge) and most or all plane controls are functional (again, didn't test that much as I don't know what is for what). You may be slightly annoyed with the game and mission loading times though so be prepared mentally.

PS:
Also I had a bug that I couldn't select any starting location or aircraft, apart from the one I selected the very fist time - it was just loading that setup every single time later. I don't know if they fixed it yet (it's loading too long for me to check that now), but in case you get it, I found online that it's because of non-English character in Windows user name, so you need to create a whole new Windows account and switch to it every time you want to play this game, if you want to pick starting locations rather than playing tutorials or any fixed missions.

Title: Soaring to New Heights: A Comprehensive Review of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020

Introduction:

In the realm of flight simulation, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 stands as a groundbreaking testament to the technological advancements in the gaming industry. Developed by Asobo Studio and published by Xbox Game Studios, this latest installment in the long-running series has raised the bar for realism, graphics, and overall immersive gameplay. Released in August 2020, Microsoft Flight Simulator (MSFS) has since become a benchmark for flight simulation enthusiasts and casual gamers alike.

Graphics and Visual Realism:

One of the standout features of Microsoft Flight Simulator is its jaw-dropping visuals. Powered by Microsoft's Azure cloud technology, the game utilizes real-time data to recreate the Earth in exquisite detail. From the sprawling cities to the remote mountain ranges, the level of realism is unparalleled. The use of high-resolution satellite imagery and 3D photogrammetry creates a visually stunning world that mirrors our own.

The dynamic weather system adds another layer of realism to the experience. Pilots will encounter realistic weather conditions, including rain, snow, thunderstorms, and even the Northern Lights. The attention to detail in the depiction of weather patterns contributes significantly to the overall immersion, making each flight a unique and challenging experience.

Aircraft Selection and Realism:

Microsoft Flight Simulator boasts an extensive fleet of aircraft, ranging from small propeller planes to large commercial jets. Each aircraft is meticulously recreated, with realistic flight dynamics and cockpit details. Whether you're a seasoned pilot or a newcomer to aviation, the simulator offers a range of difficulty settings to cater to all skill levels.

The game's attention to realism extends to the physics of flight. Aerodynamics, engine behavior, and even the impact of different weights on the aircraft are accurately modeled. This level of detail provides a learning curve for beginners while offering a rewarding experience for experienced virtual aviators. The simulator's commitment to authenticity is evident in the fact that real-world pilots have praised its accuracy in replicating the feeling of flying.

World Exploration and Navigation:

Microsoft Flight Simulator is not just about flying; it's about exploring the world from a unique perspective. The game features a comprehensive map that allows players to choose their departure and arrival points from virtually any location on Earth. The ability to fly over famous landmarks, explore remote areas, and witness breathtaking landscapes makes each flight a captivating journey.

For those who prefer a more structured experience, the simulator includes a variety of pre-planned flights and landing challenges. These range from short scenic routes to more complex cross-country flights. The inclusion of live air traffic, based on real-world data, further enhances the sense of immersion and realism, making each flight feel like a small part of a much larger aviation ecosystem.

User Interface and Accessibility:

While the level of detail in Microsoft Flight Simulator is awe-inspiring, the user interface remains intuitive and accessible. The game offers a range of control options, from simplified setups for beginners to advanced configurations for those using flight simulation hardware. The menus are well-organized, and the on-screen tooltips provide helpful information for players of all experience levels.

The simulator also benefits from an active and supportive community. Online forums, tutorials, and user-created content contribute to a wealth of resources for those seeking to enhance their experience or troubleshoot any issues. Microsoft's commitment to ongoing updates and improvements has resulted in a responsive development team that addresses user feedback and continually refines the simulator.

Multiplayer Experience:

Microsoft Flight Simulator introduces a robust multiplayer component, allowing pilots to share the skies with friends or other players from around the world. This adds a social dimension to the simulation, as users can coordinate flights, explore together, or engage in more competitive activities such as aerobatic challenges. The seamless integration of multiplayer enhances the overall experience, fostering a sense of community among virtual aviators.

Performance and System Requirements:

Given the breathtaking visuals and the scale of the simulated world, Microsoft Flight Simulator demands a powerful gaming rig. While the game is optimized for a wide range of hardware, users with mid-tier or higher systems will fully appreciate the visual fidelity and smooth performance. The simulator's ability to scale across various configurations ensures accessibility for a broad audience, but those with top-tier setups will enjoy the most immersive experience.

Conclusion:

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 sets a new standard for realism and immersion in the world of flight simulation. Its stunning visuals, extensive aircraft selection, realistic physics, and the ability to explore the entire globe make it a must-play for aviation enthusiasts and gamers alike. The simulator's accessibility and commitment to ongoing updates ensure that it will continue to be a benchmark for the genre in the years to come. Whether you're a seasoned pilot or someone with a curiosity for the skies, Microsoft Flight Simulator opens up a world of aviation like never before, inviting players to soar to new heights in the most realistic virtual skies ever created.

Don't purchase on steam at this point, its available on xbox game pass and that's how much you should pay for this. The simple ability to set a specific cloud layer for a hard IFR ceiling does not exist, very inaccurate ground marking and signage coupled with horrid traffic flow even at the "premium airports".

At this point it might be worth waiting for the newer MSFS2024 thats been announced - sounds like it will fix many of the faults of this product and is an evolution of it in the right direction. This Sim offers three things.  It does three things amazingly well.  And Ill list those things: 1. Update 2. Crash 3. Offer an amazing experience visually flying.  And objectively it does all three equally well.  So when I setup my yoke, throttle, fire up the sim, Im expecting the game to either update or crash the MAJORITY of the time.  If its updates, they should or could even add it as a dlc called "Update Simulator", because the amount of time spent updating vs doing anything else is amazing.  Id honestly say its 1/5 of the time spent has been doing updates.  Now if I manage to get into a flight, I fly fingers crossed the entire time as its a 50/50 if the sim will crash.  Theres no reason, no pattern, nothing that I could point to and say thats whats causing it to crash as it does it all the time.  My drivers are updated, the sim makes sure its updated, I have no clue.  I would love to say that the time that it does work makes up for the rest, but the time that it works, without having an update, and not crashing is so little I find it hard to want to get frustrated with updates and crashing all of the time on a sim ive spent over $100 on the sim itself, and nearly $1000 on hotas and yokes.  Ive spent thousands of hours on fsx and waited patiently for a long time for this to come out, this is such a disappointment because it does give a taste of how good it could be if it would just be stable, Id be ok with updates if it was stable.

Still does 3 things amazingly, update, crash, and be an amazing sim.  I still spent the last 200 hours split between the three.

Until Microsoft can actually fix their simulator from crashing all the time, especially for folks with up-to-date PC parts, I'm giving this a thumbs down. And here I was hoping for lots of hours to enjoy this with my new RTX 4080, but I guess I clearly set my expectations too high for this simulator.

When the simulator isn't a crash simulator, it's enjoyable but it's gotten to the point where I can't even do anything for 5 or more minutes without the sim just dying. Just scrolling on the world map? CTD. Loading in and in the middle of takeoff? CTD. Reaching cruising altitude? CTD. Keep in mind, I tried everything I could whether it was booting in safe mode, updating all my drivers, going through all my community files, rolling back the graphics driver etc. etc.

Microsoft Flight Simulator? More like Microsoft Crash Simulator. I sure hope this isn't an indication of what Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 will be like.

I love it but I hate it.  I've spent thousands of hours in every iteration of the sim since FS2002.  They have all had their bugs, but this one may be the most annoying.    I don't have performance issues, or any complaints about visuals, textures or anything like that.  All of that is fantastic.  It's some basic functions that completely ruin the experience.  

-ATC will fly you into terrain.  If flying IFR into an airport around mountains, follow your planned altitudes, not ATC. 
-ATC voice goes silent
-ATC sometimes goes off the rails and keeps assigning new altitudes, over and over and over. This usually happens at the worst possible time.   Everything is smooth, you‚Äôre stabilized and picking up the localizer, waiting for your handoff, and you get ATC yelling at you to go to 4700, no 4400, no 3000, now back to 5600, no go to 3000, 3400.... no go to 8000.   ABSOLUTELY MADDENING.  
-ATC gets stuck on ATIS, then when you swap to COM2, it also gets stuck. 
-Missed approach?  Yeh, ATC says climb back up to your cruising altitude. 
-ATC vectors? useless.  Like they just give you a random vector.  
-Flight planner... sucks, for lack of a better word.  1 out of 3 flights, after setting everything up to start cold and dark... it starts me hot, on the runway.  
-Set altitude for a waypoint?  Nope, Pilots don't do that, according to MSFS. 
-You landed, and want to take off again?  Radio voices go silent... have to quit to desktop and restart the sim.  
-Airport personnel are a nice touch, but they are suicidal.  They will walk right through your prop.  I feel like there should be a stat in the game for how many poor airport workers have casually strolled right into your propeller.  If they are not gonna fix this, then they should at least model the gore and make it realistic.  
-Airport vehicles are cool, but always doing silly things.  I've never sat in traffic behind 12 cars on a real taxyway before.  Not really a big deal because you can turn these off if you want to.   Has real potential, but needs work and could be annoying.  

I want to recommend it, but how can a company with so much money behind them still after ALL THESE YEARS not get this right?  They nailed almost everything else.  The visuals are fantastic, virtual models beautiful, weather is awesome, good flight dynamics (at least for turboprops and piston aircraft).  If they at least fix this maddening ATC and radio problem, then I will gladly change my mind.  Till then, I cant recommend it unless you just want to fly around and look at pretty stuff. 

But did I spend enough time in it?  168 hours, multiple updates (including a major one) and... it's like they are doing this to annoy people.  

Oh, but it's the adons?  Did you disable the.... No, shut up, I have NO adons, just the stock game.  I'm in IT, I tried everything, it's not my system.  


EDIT:  Just as I was gonna change my review and recommend the sim, I get a disconnect while on final after an 1 hour flight.   Naturally, an un-clickable prompt pops up, hides the cursor, and I watch my airplane spiral towards the ground.  Of course, it un-locks 2 seconds before impact.   

I see there have been a ton of scenery and aircraft systems updates lately.  All of that is great, but USELESS when things like this happen.  Fix the ATC and random nonsense like this.  No reason this should happen.  

...and no, I still do not have any aftermarket ad-ons, so cant blame that.

I think this flight simulator definitely deserves a bit of praise, not only for reinventing how the entire world appears with mere coding and graphical design in a videogame, but for being one of the most widely successful re-entries done by a company in videogame history. I really enjoy flying over major cities and being able to actually see what they generally look like with the help of ground imagery. I salute Microsoft for really putting in the effort and re-innovation, in such a beloved series for aviation enthusiasts like myself. 

However, I will say this. The physics introduced by this engine is rather self-limiting, as well as the extreme lack of cross-compatibility with its predecessors. The fact that Microsoft has just released plans for a 2024 edition (around the time of this update) also irks me. The lack of freeware addons doesn't help either, and I don't like the long re-installation process and painful lag on even newer systems.

Those are just a few quips about this program. I still recommend that you play it, especially for the newer enthusiasts.

IMO this needs to be either PC or Xbox, not both. Quality control for PC seems to have suffered. (Maybe for Xbox as well, but I run this on my PC.)

I tried all I could come up with, adjusting bright, contrast, gamma. Removing Eye adjust in the config. Even put in a support ticket for a refund for the KODIAK 100 and a day later still no support response. 
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1250410/discussions/0/3279192092216029483/
I bought the KODIAK 100 to fly bush plane type flights in Papua New Guinea, sadly this is not very possible as the displays are mostly seen best at night, and PNG grass strips in mountains don't have runway lights!

This MSFS GOTY (2020) has possibilities, but it also has many glitches, issues, and problems. Trim at times is devil possessed. Several times now after a graphics adjustment, the elevator trim is FULL up.
Lastly, I wish another company would make a flight sim like this, because I dislike supporting anything to do with insane B.G.

The pro's:
I do like the world map setup.
I do like accuracy of the roads and building (real world) placement which seems 90% accurate. Although the actual buildings are not real world replica's
The terrain elevation seems very accurate.
The Cessna 152 "felt" very similar to the real world 152's I've flown.

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is very realistic and beautiful, especially because of the 3rd party developers that make the game stand out from other simulators like X-Plane 11/ 12, P3D as well and Flight Sim X by adding realism and immersive features. MSFS 2020 is a good game and I would recommend it to anybody who i curious about flight simulation :D

Update* 
Should I Recommend Purchasing Microsoft Flight Simulator in 2023?

As I've mentioned before, Microsoft Flight Simulator (MSFS) has seen significant development, with numerous third-party companies contributing scenery, tools, and aircraft. When you factor in the immersive VATSIM experience, it truly becomes an exceptional flight simulator. It's worth noting that MSFS 2024 has been announced, so if your primary goal is casual gaming for fun, I wouldn't necessarily recommend buying MSFS at this point. However, if you're interested in creating an ultra-realistic flight environment, the good news is that many of the add-ons available for MSFS can likely be adapted for MSFS 2024, so no reason to wait!

The simulator looks amazing, truly unique and beautiful. However one of the few positive points to it. Do not buy the premium deluxe version, as most of the time the perks won't even show up. The simulator already takes up 450gb of space, and nearly every time I open it I have a mandatory 5-10gb update for some region that I will likely never even visit. Loading times are painfully long, and any add-on aircraft are nothing short of a nightmare to install. The simulator crashes easily, and frequently resets your controls, which will get very annoying very quickly. Multiplayer can be fun at first, but it will quickly become a chore to use as you notice a large number of very annoying players who have no regard to realism or rules.

The simulator is mainly focused to GA and light aircraft. The missions section is quite fun, however after spending hours trying to get an A in all of them, it can be quite dissapointing to come back the next day to see that all the progress has been undone. 

The UI is somewhat decent.

A strong point of the simulator is its flexibility in flight. For example, you can change the weather in any way you want mid-flight, without any loading times, at the risk of the simulator crashing of course.

Overall, it is not a simulator worth spending 120 Euros on for the premium deluxe version. Standard might be a little more worth the money, if you have the patience for the simulator. If one is buying a simulator to help learn flight physics, you'd be better off buying XPlane, however if you just want beautiful graphics, this Microsoft Flight Simulator is well... the best one out there, graphically speaking.

I know it's probably a good soft, but it was the worst experiment for me, as i wanted to try some VR flight.
Well, the VR controls are not usable, and the default settings are awful.
I just wanted to try to chill out in a nice VR demo flight before deciding whether or not i wanted to invest some time into properly learning how to flight. It was hell: couldn't even take off before 20 minutes, there were some horrible green wind vector lines all around making the view awful, the controls needed a mix of keyboard, regular controller, and VR controllers, because you actually can't do much from the VR controllers alone (like switching from outside to cockpit view requires to take of the headset and reach to your regular controller).
I could finally fly over New York for a few minutes, well what's left of NY: it looked like a post apocalyptic world, with low poly and messy textures everywhere. They don't show you that in the ads.
Long story short, it took me about 30 minutes to decide it wasn't for me. No problem, refund is made for that, right ?
Well, that was when the game hit me with a last punch: the bandwidth management is so poor that it took me about 2 hours and a half to download the 125 Gb of mandatory content (and i have a very high bandwidth), so when i decided to get a refund after 30 min of actual "playing", i already had 3+ hours of playtime. So no refund for me, $70 for a game i suffered with during 30 minutes and probably won't ever launch again.
Buy it if you know what you're getting into, don't buy it for a cool VR beginner experience, it's definitely not made for that.

Overall a great game: tons of simulation fun, stunning graphics including aircraft, weather and the planet, and many fun activities. As expected with a flight sim, a solid rig is needed, but settings are in-depth which helps to fine tune for your rig. Unfortunately, this is one of the reasons why MS Flight Sim can also be a bit buggy at times, it's a sim with so many modes, settings and possibilities, that it's rare to not run into some issues. Less bugs and more stability would be my biggest wish for improvements. One of my new highlights is the VR mode, it's just such a great use of VR to make you feel like you're actually in the cockpit, and I even notice it helps me do better in some of the landing challenges because I can look around better. Amazing for VR if you have a great setup! (I'm using a Quest 2 with Virtual Desktop + Steam VR to connect via WiFi to my PC which is in mobile hotspot mode, my specs are 4070Ti with a 7950X3D. That's probably close to minimum specs for VR, MS Flight Sim is already very demanding and then VR makes it a lot more demanding) Please keep the great updates coming!

2023 updated review:
Microsoft flight simulator is still one of the best flight simulators even with the new release of x plane 12, since the last review I made on this sim the physics have definitely been revised and do feel much better than before, since i've recently started flying in real life this is a great tool to practice my real circuits I do in real life. I have to say the gyroscopic precession is simulated quite well in propellor aircraft and you can definitely feel the weight when flying the aircraft. Overall this sim has aged beautifully in recent years and has been maintained extremely well by asobo with bug fixes and new dlcs, and also the mods have taken a big step up from the last review like the pmdg 737 or fenix a320. and if your heavily interested in having an immersive experience on msfs (or any other flight sim) I highly recommend VATSIM. Hopefully asobo can deliver on microsoft flight sim 2024 and bring more features!

The greatest compliment that I could give Microsoft Flight Simulator is that it developed a profound interest in aviation for me. I believe games and play can be the best way to learn about topic, well at least for me.

I originally tried MSFS20 on gampass on release back in 2020, and now after 3 years, it is about to take the spot of the most played game in my library.

Some people are against calling MSFS a game as it is literally a simulation of Earth and it's atmosphere in which you can fly nearly any type of aircraft. Looking at previous entries of the series and other flight sims, I would agree with this sentiment. However Asobo have provided a wide array of activities and challenges including bush trips, landing challenges and even Top Gun themed missions including carrier landings. MSFS does not have to be seen as a pure simulator and can be thoroughly enjoyed as an absolute novice who has never touched a sim and wants to treat it as an arcade-like flying game. MSFS can absolutely be enjoyed as a game through and through, or it can help you learn how to pilot real aircraft and simulate accurate procedures undertaken by real-world airlines.

Over 3 years, MSFS has developed a large abundance of downloadable content, both free and paid, and both official and third-party. All of the official content and a large portion of the third-party content can be accessed through the ingame store. Flight sim addons appear to have been a vital aspect of flight simulation for the better part of 3 decades, and the variety of types of addons and their varying quality is extremely vast. Read and watch reviews before purchasing addons, especially the more expensive ones like "study-level" aircraft.

I would not consider addons as necessarily essential to MSFS however, but like most moddable games, they can dramatically enhance your experience. When starting out with MSFS, especially as an absolute novice like I was, the standard aircraft and scenery is fantastic to get started with, I do highly recommend downloading all the free world updates by Asobo but they will take up a good chunk of drive space.

MSFS is difficult to review as game due to the nature of the beast, but as I've said MSFS is a thoroughly enjoyable game, but it is so much more than a game. For me, it was a step into a new hobby and a great introduction to the wonder of flight, and believe me when I say it is a truly wonderful experience.

What both amplifies and assembles this experience is the unparalleled visuals and presentation of the aircraft and planet. MSFS is without a doubt the most impressive digital interactive experience I have ever seen. The out of the box beauty and realism MSFS provides is absolutely unheard of in the long history of flight sims. Other flight sims have required hundreds of dollars of addons to even come close to recreating MSFS's visual glory. Other sims like XPlane are said to have better physics, but if you are new to flight simming, I would definitely recommend this over any of the others. If you are an experienced simmer, im surprised you're still reading this review.

If you have even the slightest interest or even just want to see what it would be like to fly a Pelican from Halo through Manhattan (yes, you read that right), do yourself a favour and get a taste of the virtual skies. Flying became an addictive and rewarding experience very quickly. There is something so gratifying about getting clean landings, from 747s to Cessna 152s and the landing challenges allow you to go after that buzz over and over again with ease. For me, replicating airliner procedures from start to finish has become my favourite thing to do in MSFS, while the game may not teach you how to necessarily do those procedures by itself, it provides the perfect platform to learn how to do so. Bush trips and general aviation may totally be your buzz on the other hand. No matter which way you decide to play, MSFS can be an extremely satisfying, rewarding, challenging or relaxing experience. Its what ever you make of it, in MSFS the sky truly is the limit, so to speak.

Definitely Microsoft's best version of the Flight Simulator yet, and (arguably) the best of the civilian flight sims. Apparently this program had some teething issues when first released including extremely frequent updates, but now is running smooth... At least I haven't had any problems with it thus far. Graphics and attention to detail are truly incredible, especially if you have a computer with plenty of horsepower to run it at maximum capabilities.

Don't let the game hours fool you, most of this was from downloading it, and downloading updates that break it further.  Enjoy the menu music, which will permeate your soul in the meantime.  When it has finished downloading and you finally get the chance to turn the menu music off, you'll notice that every time the game starts, the menu music starts to play before it gets to the point where it reads the instruction that the user did not want menu music, then it stops playing the music.  A quintessential example of the development team's investment in quality control.

Beside the fact that it has 150GB mandatory download after installation, the UI is really bad. After spending time and money into installing the game (buying peripherals for the flying experience to be more immersive - HOTAS and VR set), it crashes on launch. I've spent the last two days trying to debug the whole thing and found out there are virtually limitless reasons for why this game crashes in all it's stages. Fixes for this do not come out and the user is expected to just navigate around eventual incompatibilities with other programs and stuff of the sort. I honestly can't see why this game received "Mostly positive" reviews...
it is expensive but good: good graphics,planes etc.

It's a decent enough sim. Runs much better than XP12, has an excellent community of creators who make some excellent freeware mods that completely change the experience. I'd recommend getting the free Live Map Replacement and the FlyByWire A32NX before anything else. If you want the 787, you'll need the Premium Deluxe edition, or you can purchase an upgrade in the msfs in-game store.

Only thing people should keep in mind is that it has no seasons, and microsoft still hasn't released their weather API, so you're stuck with the default live weather system. 

Microsoft's xbox CDN network can be hit or miss depending on your location and ISP, meaning you'll get very slow speeds irrespective of your data limit. There is a list of "solutions" on the msfs support page, but that is hit or miss.

Most airports, if bought from the MSFS marketplace, have encrypted files, so external add-ons like LittleNavMap or MakeRwys won't be able to read them.

I hate to do this because I love this sim but after all the years this thing has been out it still suffers from random BS crash to desktop issues for no good reason.

The last word on consumer aircraft simulators. Not the most accurate, doesn't have the largest add on pool (Yet, but its getting bigger FAST), but god is it pretty and is it approachable. While more in depth simulation will require third party tools like simbrief, the game strikes a great balance between being a simulator and being a game you can just fuck around with for an hour. The stock aircraft are fine for beginners, but those looking for better sim will need to download add ons unless you like the A310. Luckily, a lot are free and are full or high fidelity (aka most of the buttons work).

A great game for anyone who likes planes, and the performance requirements are surprisingly low for a simulator.  YOu will need a dedicated GPU/gaming PC but thats not a huge hurdle as the game will run fine with entry level GPUs like Nvidia 1650s on lowered settings.

GAME BREAKING BUG - BE AWARE OF IT OR DON'T BUY IT UNTIL IT IS FIXED

Ok so it tooks me a while to figure out what was happening because I though I was the one doing something wrong or not understanding.

The bug is simple but game breaking. I recently found out that it's there since 3 years. So you make a flight plan for your flight. Then you fly but at some point you will save to resume later. Once you load your flight back, you COMPLETELY lose your flight plan you made for your flight and you can't have it back.

So if you don't want to lose your fight plan, you can't leave your flight...

Otherwise it's a very fun and immersive game but right now I can't recommend it until it is fixed if they ever fix it :(

Update on October 27 2023.  I haven't played this game in a while but decided to try again with my quest 3.  I tried to launch the game, and it kept crashing on launch. I went to verify integrity of files, and it passed. But I now have to download a 125 GB update just to play this game?  I swear this is the most frustrating game I ever purchased on steam. Let me defer upgrades, if you don't at least provide a high bandwidth for the download.  I have almost '300 hours' playing this game; most of those hours are downloading updates.  Most people have jobs and want to play on Friday night or the weekend, but everytime I do, I have to wait several hours to download an update that likely provides nothing substantial to the game. FSX was by far a much better developed game; I hope they go back to those developers for the next version of MSFS.

Update one July 28 2021.  They released a mandatory update.  After this update, the game no longer works in VR, it will crash within 10 minutes.  This is been documented on Reddit and Steam forums.  The update was mandatory, and broke the game.  This has to be the worst game I have every purchased on Steam, and given the fairly high price, I feel ripped off.  The game worked before the update, and now it doesn't work.

The installer is forever frustrating. I first tied with XBOX app on windows 10, it failed to recognize my harddrive. There was a fix posted on microsoft website, but it 404s. I then installed through steam, but the download is not through stream, but through the app itself. You are forced to sign into a Microsoft account. I have 2 computers, my desktop and laptop, you can only download the game files on one computer at a time. So, if the download takes, say 8 hours, and you have 2 computers, you can't play the game during the 8 hour span that your second computer downloads the game. I swear Microsoft is making it so people will pirate this game.  I'm on an actual 400 Mbps connection, as per speedtest data on the advertised 1Gbps connection, 3 hours in I'm only 72% downloaded.  MS should have let steam handle the downloads.  For the price premium, this is unacceptable, if you work a normal job, you will spend all your free time just installing this game.  I don't see why I can't download this game on 2 computers at once, from the same IP address nonetheless.  It would at least allow someone to let the installers run overnight.
cannot play anymore because of update.

In Steam, you have 2 hours to decide if this game suits you or not. They release an outdated client and force you to download 121 GB of updates. Is this incompetence or a scam? And someone from Microsoft who thought it was a brilliant idea probably won't even be punished; instead, they might even get a promotion.

Update-sept 2023- now Boeing planes are unplayable the plane goes crazy and shoots up so you cant fly with nose down, and landing gear never goes down, was never an issue b4 the update. Asobo incompetence knows no bounds. this game will be broken forever. 

Update Jan 2022. Now the mouse and keyboard  via blutoothdo not work after update. Asobo are clowns. Why so upset? imagine paying over $100 for a game that works 40% of the time then no refund after 5 hours of playing so you are stuck with a flawed product that you pay for. Only the software companies can get away with this, imagine buying a car that only starts 40% of the time but cannot return because already drove 100 miles, we as consumers would be outraged  but for some reason we tolerate it from companies like MS and Asobo that flat out take our money knowing they selling flawed product and then have endless updates that may or may not work. 

Original review - I bought the premium version. complete rip off for a broken game. Bugs galore. Auto pilot is crazy buggy, sometimes takes over and tries to kill you, for example, when you land and taxi to gate the plane takes over and crashes you even if AI  and auto pilot off this happens 40% of the time also Auto thrust turns itself on during flight so if you turn off then decent it will turn on again without you knowing, wow this is not a sim it is a broken mess. Game crashes 40% of time, nothing like almost finishing a 30 minute flight for it to crash and lose all your progress. The save function is useless, it does not save point in time you save it, it just puts you close to beginning of the flight so you lose most progress.  Turning off planes to log your flight is a buggy mess, sometimes the plane will be completely shut down but does not log progress so then after 20 min finding the right button to shut down only to discover had to press twice because of bug. Sometimes plane will shut down but fails to log progress  so you lose  flight time because would not log it so imagine flying an hr and losing all progress because of the bugs. 

The tutorials are useless and frustrating, for example the trim tutorial is the worst tutorial in gaming history, no matter what you do it will not trim. Trim is broken in this game, just read forums from real pilots.  Trim is one of the important aspects of flight and is garbage in this game.   I have a I9, 3080 GPU, 32GB ram, 900mbs internet and it still crashes and performance dips in large cities. Avg 40FPS. So  after 2 years they still cannot take advantage of all cpu cores. Wow, complete incompetence, let's develop a cpu intensive game but not utilize all cores, who hires these morons? Nd most cities missing key buildings. e.g. LA missing some iconic skyscrapers.

Take away the pretty visuals and great maps and you have just garbage game-play with game breaking bugs (restarts computer now when crashes) that are still not fixed after massive updates.  People so impressed with the visuals and maps that they overlook the actual gameplay and tolerate the bugs, crashes and  omissions . Asobo is same studio that made terrible frustrating games in the past and this no better. I guess MS hired them on the cheap and it shows
Its crap, it doesn't load. Nothing but a lot of hassle and expense.  Flight sim blames NVIDIA and NVIDIA blames Microsoft.  I wish I'd never bought it.

Put simply, this is the best flight sim to date.  I play it on a single screen, 3 screen setup, and in VR and it works well in each.  I have more invested into this game than any other I am currently playing, when you factor in DLCs and Honeycomb flight controls.  I bought the Premium Deluxe for the extra aircraft...   It is worth every penny.

VR - my first experience in VR was in an F-18 over the San Juan Isalnds of Washington State, USA.  The bubble canopy gives you alot of visibility, and the experience was in the top 3 gaming experiences of my life.  That was with Oculus 2, and it may be enough for me to consider an Oculus 3 at some point.

The only gripe I have is feeling a little betrayed by MS/Asobo in not necessarily sticking to their long term plans with FS2020 in favor of FS2024, but if they deliver improvements to the level that 2020 is over FS X, then I will throw my monty at them for that too.  

9.7 / 10  only because some places the AI went a little off the rails, but then the modding community is HUGE.  Free and paid, so you can really tailor your overall world, or flight to flight depending on how much load time you want to wait for (it definitely takes a bit).  Way cheaper than owning a plane from my experience with a humble 172G, and the landings are way less stressful at my home airport in the mountains in the game too -_-

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a masterpiece of technical achievement and immersive gameplay. The world is recreated in stunning detail, with photorealistic scenery that stretches as far as the eye can see. The weather system is dynamic and unpredictable, adding an extra layer of challenge and excitement to every flight. And the aircraft are meticulously modeled, with realistic handling and cockpit instrumentation.

Whether you're a seasoned pilot or a complete novice, Microsoft Flight Simulator is an unforgettable experience. The sense of scale is truly awe-inspiring, and the feeling of soaring through the skies is exhilarating. The game is also incredibly educational, teaching you about the basics of flight and navigation.

If you're looking for a truly immersive and challenging simulation, then Microsoft Flight Simulator is the game for you. It's a must-have for any fan of aviation, and it's sure to leave you amazed.

Here are some of the key highlights of Microsoft Flight Simulator:

Stunning photorealistic scenery
Dynamic and unpredictable weather system
Meticulously modeled aircraft
Realistic handling and cockpit instrumentation
Comprehensive flight training system
Vast and explorable world
Ongoing support and updates
If you're looking for a truly immersive and challenging simulation, then Microsoft Flight Simulator is the game for you. It's a must-have for any fan of aviation, and it's sure to leave you amazed.

Microsoft Flight Simulator: Soaring Beyond Imagination

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a virtual masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of what we thought was possible in the world of gaming. Let's embark on a brief flight through its many facets:

üñ•Ô∏è Graphics: An Unbelievable Reality

The visuals in Microsoft Flight Simulator don't just push the envelope; they redefine it. The game's graphics are so breathtaking that they make you forget what reality truly is. Each frame is a masterpiece of its own, and the meticulous attention to detail is awe-inspiring.

‚ú® Gameplay: The Art of Flight

Playing this game is not just good; it's a revelation. It's not merely gameplay; it's an art form, allowing you to take to the skies and experience the joy of flying like never before. The thrill of liftoff, the serenity of cruising, and the precision of landing are all beautifully crafted.

üéµ Audio: A Symphony for Aviators

The audio in Microsoft Flight Simulator is nothing short of an eargasm. It captures the essence of flight, from the roar of engines to the wind's gentle whisper. It's an auditory masterpiece that elevates the overall experience.

üë™ Audience: From Kids to Grandma

This game caters to a wide audience, from curious kids and enthusiastic teens to seasoned adults and even adventurous grandmas. It's an all-inclusive journey through the skies.

üñ•Ô∏è PC Requirements: A Need for Speed

You'll require a fast PC to unlock the full potential of Microsoft Flight Simulator. It's not just decent; it demands a powerhouse to truly appreciate the beauty and realism on display.

üß† Difficulty: Learning to Soar, Mastering to Soar High

Microsoft Flight Simulator is easy to learn but hard to master. It's a delicate dance between understanding the basics and achieving true mastery of the skies. It's not just a game; it's a skill to be honed.

üÜô Grind: The Sky's the Limit

There's no grinding involved; the game is all about enjoying the journey rather than chasing arbitrary goals. It's not necessary for progress; the open skies await your exploration.

üìñ Story: The Sky's Your Canvas

Microsoft Flight Simulator doesn't follow a traditional narrative; it offers a blank canvas for you to paint your stories. It provides endless opportunities for exploration and adventure, limited only by your imagination.

‚åõ Game Time: To Infinity and Beyond

The game's longevity is virtually limitless. You can hop into your cockpit and explore the vast world for hours on end. The sense of freedom is truly boundless.

üí∞ Price: A Jewel in Your Collection

While it's not free, Microsoft Flight Simulator is worth every penny. It's an investment in an unparalleled experience that's both educational and immensely enjoyable.

üêû Bugs: A Smooth Flight

The game is impressively stable, with minimal reports of bugs or issues. It's a testament to the quality and polish of the overall experience.

üèÜ Verdict: A Perfect 10 for Aviators

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a masterclass in gaming, combining breathtaking visuals, realistic gameplay, and an open world that beckons exploration. It's an absolute 10 in the world of virtual flight.

I love flight simulators and MSFS 2020 was alright when it first came out. However every time a new patch comes out, a bunch of issues pop up that weren't there before.
