The game hasn't been out for long, so this review represents the state of the game at the time of writing. It's both very impressive, but it still lacks some core features to be considered a product worth buying.

The good stuff - If you have played any other flight simulators, you'll know that none have ever had scenery of such quality. People paid hefty fees for 3rd party addons on other flight sims to get scenery packs that look worse than what you get out of the box with Flight Simulator's blackshark AI procedurally generated stuff. Sure, your house is just a flat texture and your garage was turned into a house, so what? It's a flight simulator, you shouldn't fly low enough to notice and it is still above and beyond anything else you can get.
The planes are wonderfully well done. The design details are fantastic and they do look and feel like their real counterparts and you even get fully simulated Garmin glass cockpits that are almost perfectly realistic. Some planes do need their engine performance/behaviour modified at this point and some are full of non functional switches, but even this is at a much lesser extent compared to default planes you would get with the old FSX.
Graphics need no introduction, you must have at least seen a youtube video that shows it's glory. From incredible lighting to visible fingerprints and scratches on glass surfaces, this is a real eye candy game like no other.
Sounds might have gotten under the radar but they are equally as impressive. Pushing or pulling on the yoke makes an eerily convincing sound you'd expect to hear in the real thing. Same goes for all knobs, levers and even buttons. Planes squeak and crackle when you put them into high G maneuvers, but my favorite sound showcase remains sitting in a cold and dark cessna caravan and playing with the prop and condition levers.

Now onto the bad stuff: If you're not willing to spend a lot of time just randomly flying flight plans you set for yourself or doing bush trips for the sake of it, there's very little content in terms of scenarios. Apart from a mediocre flight lesson section that only teaches you VFR basics, the only scenarios you can play at the moment are two bush trips and a bunch of landing challenges. If you want something more from your simulator, you might need to wait for a while.
The other glaring issue is that the game is currently not worth getting unless you have a proper flight yoke or stick controller. Big issue for me since I use my xbox 360 controller for flying. Not only is a Microsoft controller not being properly supported in a Microsoft's own game, but the development team seems to be struggling to add it in with the community waiting for more than a month now and no solution in sight. Until then one must learn to rely on flying without rudder pedals if you don't have a pair of combined axis ones.

All in all, FS is currently offering the best possible technological platform for civilian flight simulation, but with the little there is to offer on top of that platform and with urgent issues that need to be addressed, I think Flight Simulator feels like it was pushed out early and definitely still needs a lot of work. This is not uncommon and it is something I expected going in, but my concerns are currently directed at whether the team behind it will be able polish FS into what it could and should be, and the latest monthly update that not only failed to fix some crucial issues, but broke a couple of things as well has me worried. All things considered, I can't give it a thumbs up just yet.

EDIT: Many issues have been fixed including controller support I noted in my original review. The game is continually updated, there are still small glitches and some glaring unrealistic issues on the planes, but comparing this game to FSX that's to be expected with default planes. All in all now this has become a solid product.

EDIT: After many more hours "played" (many of these were spent waiting for the game to download and not actually playing) I can no longer support buying a product that works around half of the time. I have constantly had various issues and I can never start the game and expect to be able to play it. For a simulator that requires vast amount of content, around 100 GB, it's unacceptable that all the download happens through the game itself. It only takes a slowdown in the network connection to cause issues. I've had crashes upon the end of loading, infinite loading screens, crashes mid flight, etc. Now, knowing that they'll abandon this product, there is absolutely no point in buying it.

I hate to say this, having been a Microsoft Flightsimulator fanboy sinds 1994, In fact MS flight simulator has helped me to become an airline pilot; this version however, is simply not worthy of that legacy.

FS2020 was released in an incomplete state. the Dev's know how to make a fantastic looking game, but lack any expertise to make it a true simulator. Even though the community provides them with the expertise via the forums, this is totally ignored in favour of adding more payware eye candy add-ons.

Their lack of aviation expertise is obvious to the experienced pilot, but an insult to anyone who is learning to fly. Where I could use MS'95 '95, 2000 and FSX to aid in my flight training, this game, especially with a keen eye on technical details, such as pressure altitude instruments, gyroscopic behaviour and engine management, is simply wrong. a student pilot might learn wrong things which would slow down their training progress instead of helping.

Then there is the total ignorance to legal customer rights. When a plane does not work (the fokker F.VIIa does not fly at all and the TF-104 starfighter can't fly supersonic) a refund from anything purchased on the the marketplace is not possible. For support you can go to the forum but there is no support from the dev-teams at all.

Breaking news:
Microsoft has recently announced their next simulator: MSFS2024

In fact this means that MS2020 was just an early access tech demo, sold at premium retail price. MS2024 would be the finished product, but you'll have to pay the full price again.

Do your self a favour and AVOID this broken game. Buy X-plane 12 instead.

Dont consider this review a recommendation, At best assume this to be a 3 out of 5 stars.
If you want to just get home after a long day and boot up a sim to go fly someplace. Seriously look elsewhere. The amount of coding/problem-solving I've had to put into this sim to just get it to boot up to the main menu has been horrifying. (in a way it does accurately simulate the hundreds of hours trying to fix and maintain an aircraft vs the actual couple of hours you ACTUALLY fly)
I go through a loop. Sim won't boot. The entire weekend lost in troubleshooting, bug fixing, giving up, reinstalling, reinstalling ALL the addon content, Sim works fine (I let my guard down and think "its not too bad") close sim, sleep, try again a day or so later, Loop repeats.
MSFS 2020 is an abusive relationship. It sucks you in with the nice visuals and the promise of just being able to jump in and fly anywhere. 
To begin with the massive downloads took a literally 4 month to complete. At first it would consistently crash just downloading updates or game data. 
My initial impressions were not positive however as time has passed and it finally now runs I have to admit. It's grown on me. Mechanically speaking its much more stable now. Still has the occasional hiccup but overall fine. Bing maps gives the world a good sense of accuracy. If you know your local area well you can do flights purely navigating off landmarks. It ain't perfect but its only getting better. I am pretty sure there are ways of increasing the accuracy/visual fidelity of the maps but its dependent on the kind of flying you'll be doing. It is very easy to set up a flight from the thousands of airfields around the world and go anywhere your heart desires.
It does have decent tutorials to get you up and flying as well as challenges to attempt. However I've not tried those. Instead I've done my own thing. 
For example: My current self made challenge is somewhat inspired by the TV series Long way round by Ewan McGregor and Charley Booorman. Fly around the world, but not in a straight line or even directly. Instead, follow the major coastlines of the continents.

There are also a tonne more external mods you can add to it. (Realistic mapping/flight planning tools. Player driven ATC, upgraded visual mods, more planes.)  A good one to look at is Skypark. It is paid software however the add on makes the sim close in general idea to Euro truck sim. Getting paid game money to fly cargo on specific routes. 

The point I am getting at is that MSFS2020 is still an abusive and addictive relationship that keeps me coming back and spiralling deeper into the world of aviation.

Lovely simulator - very little to comment on or complain about in that respect, other than to bemoan the lack of a combat mode as in some of the (typically) much older games. I remember flying around in a Sopwith Camel on a green screen, so FWIW... 

My only MAJOR complaint is the download size. Every install is about 127GB at this point, with no ability to trim the fat (e.g. leave out airplanes you don't want to see or fly until later, etc.). At absolute minimum, letting someone copy the files from one PC to another before activating the game would be a... game changer ::winces::. Sorry. Still, it's true. Finally, if they can't do any of that, maintaining a transfer speed of better than 2mbps would be great - it takes 2-3 days straight to download the game, whereas downloading a game from Steam direct only takes a few minutes or an hour at most (looking at you, MK11).

So the game itself is great (real-time weather sync!) - I can't evaluate HOW realistic the planes or flight models are - but the way you GET the game on your machine isn't. It's pretty terrible.

This game is an exercise in dealing with bugs. Every time I launch the game, I am required to select whether I want to start in safe mode or normal mode, despite having shut the game down properly when I last quit. When I try to setup a new flight, I cannot use the Delete key to change the cruising altitude. Hitting Delete closes the window, preventing me from making a change. When I select a parking spot at my departure airport and then select the destination airport, this game changes my departure to a runway rather than the parking spot I selected. If I select a parking spot again, the game ignores my input and selects  the runway again. Often when I am landing at an airport, this game puts giant hills in the middle of the runway, causing me to run straight into the side of the hill and crash even though I'm dead center on the runway. I could keep going, but I'd like to do something else with my time other than moan about how poorly this game was coded. Microsoft cannot build an operating system so I don't know why I thought they could do any better with a computer game. Microsoft Flight Simulator is a wonderful game when it works. The problem is that it never works correctly. Every time I open the game I run into at last one bug. Trying to get help from Microsoft consists of posting well documented reports of the issue on a forum only to never receive any kind of assistance from Microsoft.

Review below, first an important tip:

Many people have the problem that downloads are extremely slow for MSFS, see the negative Steam reviews here and posts all over the internet. This seems to be because MS uses the Windows Update system for MSFS downloads, which is special and designed for slow, unobtrusive background downloads. My download speed was 1.5Mbit/s, that's really slow and not even 5% of my typical Steam download speed. Paired with the large game and the fact that you have to download the real content in-game, these speeds mean that people cannot even play before the end of the 2 h Steam refund window! For me the installation took 9 hours, I only discovered this fix afterwards when downloading the extra packs with more detailed maps. So if your download is slow, look at this thread: 

  https://forums.flightsimulator.com/t/slow-download-speed-megathread/427731

and follow the first solution, by XTCQuinn. It worked perfectly and instantly for me. I did it with the game running and downloading, without restarting it. As soon as I had typed the [i]netsh[/i] shell command (last part of the instructions in the post), the download speeds went to 100% of what my connection is capable of.

---

Review:

Apart from the Windows Store and Windows OS integration, this is a good game with two sides: an impressive world to fly in and great airplanes on the one side, various technical issues and bugs in the missions / activities as well as a lot of rough edges with ATC, ground services and menus on the other. 

There are 2 competitors (Xplane and Aerofly) which may be slightly better in a single, limited aspect each (VR performance, comms/ATC), but they are worse in most other aspects. The impressive graphics and detail of the world make FSFS the winner in my opinion, despite its flaws in some areas. It seems they have [i]every German airport in existence[/i] in this game. Even the tiny grass strip at the back of beyond of Lower Saxony where I once learned to fly is in there! The control you have over the weather at any point and the flight model are really good. Soaring in the Alps feels amazing, and so did my custom flight plan in a Cessna from Cuenca, Ecuador over the amazon to Macapa, Brazil. It was a dream come true. Virtually, but still.

Sadly, the game has quite some issues in other areas: I encountered various technical issues (cf. downloads above) and bugs quite early during my experience, e.g., in the glider training mission the tow plane sometimes does not climb and keeps on flying just meters above the tree tips and the village until it crashes you into the forest after 5 minutes. Also for me the 2nd Cessna tutorial in AZ just would not end after I did everything they asked, I had to quit and do it again later to get the grade, and [i]damn[/i], that tutorial is boring! Also the "Active Pause" is buggy, e.g., if you pause while flying at the limit of the aircraft, the aircraft continues to get stressed during pause -- I just got destroyed because I paused during a fast descent: While the game was paused, I started feeling increasing force feedback vibrations on my joystick, then I was dead.  

Apart from bugs, the training missions in general leave large gaps and can be quite unclear at times, their order is also pretty absurd in some sections but that's minor. The time acceleration (sim rate) also is quite buggy (e.g., it seems to disable(interfere with the autopilot in the Cessna 172s w/ G1000) and generally should be used with care: when you turn it up too high for your hardware, there is always a chance that the game will start to stutter badly and finally freeze. I encountered some issues with the landing challenges and other activities so far, and I have finished about 30% of them. E.g., in the bush trip challenges, the refueling by calling the fuel truck does not work, and there are many posts on the internet on it. You have to cheat and bind a key to 'Repair and Refuel' (which should not work via a key press in realistic mode, but it's another bug that can save you from the first one). Another thing is that the majority of the achievements are bugged, i.e., some will not pop up even though you did what is being asked (bush trips for me), but some will also pop  even though I definitely did not meet the requirements (e.g., land at every star airport on the world). Cannot comment on activities much more, as I mainly fly my own flight plans.

Apart from these things, the game is quite good though, and you can find much help on Youtube, although switching between youtube and MSFS is a bit annoying if you do not have a 2nd monitor or a laptop next to your computer. Still overall a good game with a great world but quite some issues. 

It is perfectly possible to fly with a controller, and the default mapping for the Xbox Controller is very well through out. I fly with a Virpil joystick and there was no profile for it, so I had to map everything manually, which is to be expected.

Altogether I would say this is a rather neutral review, but that's not an option on Steam. So while I do not regret my purchase, I have to say I would not recommend friends to get this without knowing about the issues, so I give it a negative for now, because this increases the chance of people reading this. 

My total rating is 7/10: definitely get it if you are happy with flying around on your own in a beautiful world with great planes. Skip it if you need ready-made, working and great missions and are not willing to invest quite a bit of time for getting started, which you will have to do because of the bad/missing training missions and documentation.

Note: If you get it, make sure you get the free world updates by MS at least for your favorite region in the in-game asset manager. It's typically another 10 GB download per region (there are about 10), but they add more detail to that region of the world and are a must-have in my opinion. I bought the ultimate edition, but I guess for most people that is not needed: there are a lot of planes to learn in the standard edition.

Also keep in mind that MS has already, to the great surprise of the community, announced a new version, MSFS 2024. What this means for this game, and the large amounts of money many people have invested in extra content for it, is yet to be seen.

The Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is a flight simulation game with a rich history spanning over 40 years. I must admit, that fact alone makes me feel a bit more seasoned than a seasoned pilot.

Now, when it comes to the variety of planes available, this game doesn't skimp. Right out of the box, you've got an impressive assortment of flying machines to choose from. So, unless you're on a quest for a specific aircraft, there's no need to break the virtual bank for extras. But for the collectors out there, rejoice! There's a store where you can purchase additional aircraft, and it's not just planes; they've got all sorts of flying contraptions. Hoverboard, anyone?

The game's world is generated from actual server-based map creation. Want to find your house? You can try, but don't be surprised if it doesn't look much like your real-life abode. It's all procedurally generated from data, so your dream mansion might turn into a cozy log cabin.

Now, let's dive into those meticulously detailed cockpits. They're like the Swiss watches of the aviation world, packed with buttons and knobs. But here's the catch: many of them are labeled "INOP," which is just a fancy way of saying "for display purposes only." In other words, they're there to make your virtual cockpit look fancy, not to actually press or turn.

As for the terrains, they're breathtakingly realistic. However, not all airports are fully simulated, which is where the DLCs come into play. And speaking of downloadable content, if you're not careful, you might find yourself in "DLC-hell" quicker than you can say "altitude check." Sure, it's cheaper than buying a real airplane, but those virtual dollars add up!

In the end, the Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is a beautiful flight simulator that'll have aviation enthusiasts like myself logging countless virtual hours in the cockpit. So, buckle up, folks, and get ready for a sky-high adventure that's been 40 years in the making. It's like fine wine; it only gets better with age, even if it makes us all feel a tad older in the process!

The game-play and flight characteristics/simulations are good and well done. However, the downloader for it is terrible, it'll randomly freeze up when downloading or decompressing a file, requiring a restart of the whole download process at the minimum, or having to dig through the files to delete the failed airport/plane/scenery. Sometimes, it will just crash to desktop in the middle of the download and I have to restart everything.

But that's not even the biggest issue. The game just wont load. I have been having consistent crash to desktop for the past  6-12 months, which is why I have low hours. The most it will get is 75% through the loading bar then back to desktop. I have tried every thread on the forums and none of them work. I have completely removed the game and reinstalled it multiple times but still no progress. I cannot play the game as I cannot even access the main menu, and the only time I've actually made it to the menu, it crashed to desktop when I selected the "World Map" to start a flight.

It is a good flight simulator. BUT I don't recommend it due to all the issues which as it appears on the forums has been going on since December 2021.

What an absolute f***ing turd.  Just a terrible experience.

My son started trying to fly in the "all assist" assistance mode.  The plane kept climbing so hard it would stall and crash.  Only maximum forward stick pressure would fly it level, and any attempt to correct with trim was soon overriden with auto-yoke.

We switched to the middle assistance setting.  That turned off some of those auto settings, but now during lesson two, when she is supposed to be demonstrating straight and level flight in a cruise attitude, the instructor never feeds any throttle.

Predictably, the aircraft slowly sinks and crashes, before she finishes running her mouth and gives you control to potentially save it.

I'm shocked at what a terrible experience this has been.  We've been f***ing around with this simulator all day trying to get the most basic things to work reliably, and they just don't.

The thing is gorgeous.  I hope they will fix these problems.  As things stand, I have a 10yo boy here who wants to be a pilot and is trying to understand the basics.  He is one disappointed little kid.

I would love to use it, but Microsoft apparently can't figure out how to give users a good install/update experience.

Good sim, stability has improved a lot and the graphics are amazing. Needs some better long-haulers though, but the default 787 and 747-8i are much more flyable now in terms of systems since the AAU2 update, but still need a lot of work in the physics department, at least for the 787 especially, it's too touchy right now. We need some more Boeing narrow bodies too, because get ready for this.... We are about to get an ini A20N, on top of the FBW A20N, on top of the Fenix A320 rework, on top of the Fenix 319/321 coming end of this year, lol. No Airbus long haulers at all though, but I guess that will change soon with Aerosoft releasing their (probably mid, and one engine type only **ahem RR**) A330 soon... whenever that is. Hoping for ini or FBW or FENIX (preferably FENIX) to release an A321NEO so I can do a bunch of United A321neo ops. Probably won't get MSFS2024 for a fat while unless its really a huge upgrade and addons stop supporting MSFS2020. Doesn't look that much different and I don't want to re-setup everything. Just finished a 787-10 long haul from Newark (EWR) to Tel Aviv (TLV). Good flight, had some problems with the LNAV and vectors on that EWR4 departure with the plane not following LNAV... Note to self... LNAV after a vector does NOT work in the current update of the 787. Other than that, everything else was fine. One thing I really wish this 787-10/-8 (Kuro -8 for context) had was Pause at T/D. Anyways, end of review. Good sim overall, it has a very bright future and look forward to flying in it for many many years to come.

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 has exceeded my expectations! The graphics are stunning and the attention to detail is amazing. With thousands of real-world airports and aircraft to choose from, the possibilities for exploration are endless. I have thoroughly enjoyed learning to fly and experiencing different weather conditions, all from the comfort of my own home. The community features are also a great addition, allowing me to connect with other aviation enthusiasts. Overall, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is a fantastic simulator that is both entertaining and educational.

I have 168 hours in MSFS, but haven't played the sim part of it yet.  All of that time has been spent downloading updates and watching them fail to install.  The absurdly huge updates are unlike anything I've seen in 40 years of gaming.  This application struggles to download complete files, or has trouble unpacking them, because it gets stuck in loops while doing so.  I'm forced to restart and delete .fspatch files and hope that the next time will work, which it sometimes does, but it usually doesn't.  168 hours of watching this thing download updates, while consuming 100% GPU so you can't play another game while it's running, with music you can't turn off, downloading from potato infrastructure.  I'm on a Starlink connection and I get near 100 mbps with Steam, but from this Asobo I get roughly 5-10 mbit average - and then the constant download restarts and failures to unpack files means this thing has cost me nearly as much in electricity as I paid for the game itself.
I find the game relaxing. the graphics and the general feel of the game is great

Fixed my previous gripe with download breaks on fast connections?  Yeah.  Thank you, Microsoft.  

It hurts any CPU/GPU you throw at it when you try to squeeze out every last frame with as much detail as possible, while keeping it smooth.  My fans run full speed and I have to wear headphones, but you should be wearing a set in the cockpit, anyway.

The fun begins when you run MSFS on enough computer to deliver 30 FPS smoothly on medium level detail in a VR headset.  Magic starts happening when you have more computer and can add more detail and/or better performance.

I bought premium at launch because I had the cash to throw at it.  Don't, unless you absolutely have to (you really don't).  Just add what you want from base and exercise some patience in the Marketplace.  Very little is worth full price.  Some planes just suck, some add ons just toss garbage into your experience, and all of it will eventually go on sale at some point for you to impulse spend and find out for yourself.  I'm looking at you Reno Air Races.  You are worth $25, not $100.  Personally, I found the birds, balloons, and improved runway textures, and upgrading my local airport are nice aesthetic touches, just not at full price.  

Detractors can have their say, but I will leave it like this.  I am satisfied.  Flying along the Colorado River in downtown Austin, TX, or along any of its highways and tolls, is a flashback to 2020-2021, right down to the construction in progress.  The Tesla gigafactory is construction just starting.  East of KAUS, inside the racetrack, my house isn't up, but the foundation looks pretty accurate at ground level and the single tree on the greenbelt immediately behind the house is shockingly there, all by itself as in the real world.  I don't know how that happened, but it absolutely created a sense of deja vu.

Onto the next 350 hours.

The game title is slightly misleading, It is called "Flight Simulator", however, more accurate term is "Download Simulator".
The players are challenged with downloading gigabytes of mandatory updates, pushed out at random times throughout the year, while looking at the pictures of various planes and helicopters. (I guess that is the "Flight" portion). 

The game also offers a unique feature: a download progress bar that can actually move backwards and well as forward, so the player has to guess when the download will actually finish, if at all. 

While the download may succeed, the update can still fail (that is the "simulation" part of the game),. In this case the process will repeat again, which offers an excellent replayability value. 

The game comes from a small indie developer called "Microsoft", therefore, some growing pains and occasional bugs are expected. With refreshing honesty, the developer also freely admits its inexperience with this genre right in the title of this release: "40th Anniversary".

The devs have also promised to release a new version in 2024, in which the download simulation process will happen not before but during the game, offering even more excitement.

As a private pilot with over 250 hours of real-life flying experience, I can't express enough how much I've enjoyed Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. This simulation game is a game-changer for aviation enthusiasts and aspiring pilots alike. It offers an incredibly immersive experience that is remarkably true to life.

One of the standout features of Flight Simulator 2020 is the stunning graphics and attention to detail. The landscapes, cities, and airports are so realistic that it feels like you're actually flying over the places you've only dreamt of visiting. The realism extends to the aircraft themselves, from the cockpit instruments to the flight dynamics. It's as close to real flying as you can get without leaving the ground.

But what truly elevates the experience is having the right gear. Investing in a good quality flight stick, throttle quadrant, and rudder pedals is a game-changer. The tactile feedback and precision these peripherals offer add a level of immersion that's hard to put into words. It's not just a game; it's a full-fledged flight simulation.

Flight Simulator 2020 also has a strong community and a wealth of user-generated content, from mods to real-time weather integration. This creates an ever-evolving and dynamic experience, making each flight unique and challenging.

In conclusion, if you're passionate about aviation or have ever dreamt of taking to the skies, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is an absolute must-have. With the right gear, it's an exhilarating and authentic journey that will satisfy both novices and experienced aviators. The level of realism is unparalleled, and it's a testament to the incredible advances in flight simulation technology. Happy flying!

I guess if I hadn't played DCS, this would have been amazing. But I have played DCS and it makes this Microsoft Flight "Simulator" feel like cheap plastic. I love certain elements of MSFS. I love the graphical wonders achieved, the realism and scope of the world we live in, and also the live weather system. But damn it the entire thing feels as clunky as can be. And to be honest, the live weather system and satellite mapping are novelties that aren't likely to keep you all that interested for long. I flew around my hometown of Seattle/Everett; that was cool. What do I do now? I went to a couple of places I wanted to see but that was that. What do I do now exactly? 

 The entire experience is not even close to being optimized. DCS is made by a small developer, I give them a pass for the numerous issues they have. Microsoft, a mega corp, makes this flight sim and I just don't understand how it has so many little issues. I compare the camera system, the high fidelity controls, the actual flight simulation, and other things to DCS and MSFS just fails on everything. Again, it's super clunky. The only two things that MSFS beats DCS in are landscape visuals and the fact that you can fly airliners. Which, DCS could easily do and it would do it far better, but they are focused on military applications. Bottom line, if you want a flight sim, it's DCS. If you already have DCS, get this and you will get a bit of fun out of visiting places across the world. I didn't appreciate how truly special DCS is until I played MSFS. 

PS: There is maybe one white dude you can use as your avatar in MSFS. I'm not even sure if he is white to be honest. There are 20 avatars and us white devils can't even get one. So, it's just spitting in my face. I'm sorry that white men enjoy and are good at flying planes Microsoft. The commercial airlines are racially discriminating against white men in hiring for pilots.....that actually matters. Not sure what Microsoft is trying to accomplish with their crappy social engineering.

PPS: I just uninstalled through Steam and it only freed up 1.5gb of space. The game is almost 200gb.....they have the entire thing hidden in some folder. So, when you go to uninstall it, you aren't really uninstalling it. Just another awful bit of nonsense from Microsoft.

My feelings about FS2020 are very mixed.  

On the one hand it allows you to fly a wide variety of aircraft across the entire globe.  So if that was the one advertised feature, yes it achieves that.

Looking deeper into the sim though, it is quite a buggy experience.  I've posted in the forums to say that to be this game feels very much BETA quality, many of the basic mechanics don't work very well (stress damage, ground handling, Ai aircraft etc).   

Other features seem to be been implemented to please more of the casual simmer, such as multiplayer.  Unlike other sims like IL-2 or DCS (or even Elite Dangerous) it's not possible to form community groups and set individual rules around what type of flying is allowed.  So your left with too either play solo, having to manually setup groups (maximum 8 players I think) or accept that you have to live in a free-for-all world where your perfect approach you're trying to film is spoiled by some maverick in his F/A 18.  I've seen started to move to a more solo approach and relying on 3rd party addons to add the necessary "life" to the sim for these reasons which is a shame.

Part of these problems stem from the game being supported cross-platform for both PC and XBOX therefore Microsoft has to run the servers unlike the other sims I've mentioned which are PC only and in most cases require a 3rd party multiplayer server.  Elite Dangerous being the one having the nearest setup to MSFS with it's better implemented group mode.

No doubt Microsoft or Asobo will say, ah yes but this will be improved in FS2024 but at this time I don't see myself buying it at least until a couple of years after by which time they'll be announcing FS2028 for even more money.

I've played 50 hours right? Wrong. I have about 3 hours of gameplay before the game crashed and never worked again.
After the game crashed, i tried to play the game and had several issues. Went through A LOT of different troubleshooting I found online and here on Steam, and nothing seemed to fix it.

Then, I decided to reinstall the game. That's where most of my hours of """""gameplay""""" comes from. When you install the game, the downloading goes through a secondary launcher, so every hours downloading count as gameplay. On top of that, the speed for the download is incredibly slow, to the point I had to leave it downloading overnight, adding extra hours once the download finished just because the PC was sitting there waiting for me to come back.

After downloading, it got stuck in decompression. It would be something like Decompressing 100 out of 480 files. Then I paused the stuck decompression, closed the launcher and launched it again. Now it got stuck lets say on 30 out of 380 files, which means that the first 100 files were indeed decompressed. Well, that process happened around 20 times until I finally managed to decompress the whole game and play.

Nope. Textures were missing. My plane was pink and I couldn't see anything in "first person".
So I did the obvious, checked the integrity of the files which made the game, somehow, download another 20GB of content in the launcher.
Guess what, same problems with decompression after that.
Guess what again, textures still missing.

Asked for a refund. Nope. You already have 50 hours.

I spend 75AUD in something that doesn't work and I can't get a refund.
DON'T BUT HIS GAME. MAKING IT WORK IS A GAMBLE.

Note: I have a high end PC so hardware is not the issue.

I love this game to bits, but it DEMANDS a negative review simply because of how it installs itself.
All you get from Steam download is a 2-3 Gigabyte installer which take 10 times longer than Steam would to install the game! Then the rest of the add-ons are installed in-game at a snails pace too... Over 400 Gigabytes my total install adds up to; it takes over half a day to finish!  Ark: Survival Evolved at 400 Gigabyte took less than 2 hours to install‚ÄΩ And to add salt to the wound, guess what you can't do when 'this' game installs itself; play any other game on Steam!!!! Steam thinks your playing the game, when your actually watching a 12 hour -plus long DOWNLOAD SCREEN!!
And the final insult is that if you don't pay active attention to the installer it'll try to install the add-ons to an utterly stupid location no game or there installs have any business installing themselves! Especially if your C drive is intended for the OS ONLY! And don't even think about trying to Move, Migrate or god forbid Copy the install to a new place (Even with Steams own build in game moving tool), Cause "You've Guessed It!" It'll just re-download everything all over again instead, regardless of the fact that it's already there‚ÄΩ How much money are these Devs haemorrhaging on unnecessary server bandwidth alone‚ÄΩ Steams system does everything for you! The definitive flight sim for both casual and serious simmers alike. Either you can jump in with all assists and fly casually or turn off assists and do cold and dark start. 

I've played this in Game Pass before and I can attest that it has some significant flaws. Many parts of the world are not covered by photogrammetry so you would have default autogen. And if you fly offline, the default scenery is worse than you get in X Plane. 

But The biggest drawback for me is the overly complicated camera system and the tedious built in replay tool which makes capturing take-off/in flight and landing videos harder than it should be. Ideally we should have a replay and camera system very similar to X Plane.

Edit: dreading the "mandatory update" every time. The download speeds are too slow and painful.

This is a great game so lets start with others complains.

1. Game takes forever to download/file size too large -> Well what did you expect. This isn't flightgear, (Don't worry flightgear, I love you), it's an extremely realistic and detailed simulator. To get the quality you deserve you need large files. The base game is something around 150 GB's, which took me, on my essentially broadband internet roughly 38 hours. My install, with the addition of multiple addons, is around 230 GB's.
2. It runs horribly/my computer can't handle it -> Once again what did you expect its not flightgear (I promise I love you FG). It's not going to do to well on your Dell Inspiron laptop from 2012, however you don't need a supercomputer. I'm running a i5-6400, GTX 1050Ti, and 8 GB's of ram. Setting the game to low/medium setting resolves almost all performance issues with the exception everyone in a while of a little stuttering when close to the ground and surrounded by trees.
3. The game doesn't install properly/It's too hard -> Well for this I don't have anything except you did something wrong. There's very few steps to installing. You launch it, tell it where to install to, hit install and let it do the rest. 

MSFS is a great simulator, especially if you have friends to play with. There's little to say against it except the price of it and the addons in game but that is the price of having a simulator of this quality. You can always buy things when they go on sale. If you're interesting in flying or enjoy aviation then this is a great purchase, as long as you have something better than your childhood laptop.

Game itself is good, but it has the worst downloader ever devised for any program ever.  I'm not exaggerating, google it.  It is absolute garbage.  It does all of it's downloads inside the game engine, despite the fact that the initial download is so large and slow (it will be well below your max download speed.  Even if you have gigabit, it is going to do about 50 mbps) you'll need to do it overnight.  That means you have to run your computer all night in high CPU and GPU usage modes.  It is absolutely unnecessary, and the number one worst distribution system I've seen in my 30 Plus years as a PC gamer, and my 15+ years as an IT Analyst.  It is an embarrassment.  Asobo and Microsoft should be ashamed of themselves for not coming up with, for instance, a seperate downloader that you have to run OUTSIDE the game engine before you can play.  You know what I'm talking about, it's what every other game and large program does.  I don't care that it is prehistorically slow, I can deal with that, but it is both prehistorically slow AND resource intensive.  It is absolutely unnecessary.  When I upgraded to a new computer, one of the first things I thought was "Ugh, I'll have to download MSFS 2020 again."  I put it off for months because it was such a horrendous experience.  Microsoft has no shame so I'm not going to bother with them, but shame on you Asobo.  Just another example of how Microsoft is an awful, out of touch, megalithic symbol of mediocrity.  Asobo probably got enough revenue from this that they aren't super worried about follow up business, but I now have about as much faith in their engineers as I have in the Zambian Space Program.  That said, keep in mind that knowing how awful reinstall was going to be, I still downloaded it again.  Once you get it installed, it is impressive.  The thing that bothers me is that that impressiveness does not require a stupid updater.  It could be both a great game, and have a regular old game installer.  I understand this is a complicated program, but so is Starfield, and that downloaded just fine.  I understand it's maps are bigger, and it's going to take time, but why on earth does the game engine have to be running during the unusually slow download?  Swallow your pride, admit you made a mistake, and FIX IT.

UPDATE: Once I got it re-installed, and got up in the air, I am shocked how bad it looks.  I'm running an RX 7800 XT, 32 GB of 6000 MHZ RAM, a 7600x processor, my computer is a hotrod, and it's a new hotrod.  It routinely drops to 10 FPS in VR.  Once you start knocking down the graphics settings so you can get smooth framerates, it goes from looking decent to looking like a watercolor painting really quickly.  For some reason that was more acceptable to me when I was running this on a RTX 1070, or a RTX 2080, but my latest upgrade nearly doubled my system speed (GPU, RAM, CPU, HD all twice as fast) and it still looks like crap.  I'm going back to DCS.  The only reason I even tried this again is because I used to fly IRL, and I wanted to log some Cessna time.  The Cessna that comes with my game version is the Garmin glass cockpit version, so it didn't even spark nostalgia (it is VERY different from the Cessna 172SP that I used to fly.)  To get the plane I want I could spend 60 bucks on the deluxe version upgrade.  I only care about that one plane, and I'm not spending 60 bucks for it.  This is a bit of an FU from Microsoft to former pilots.  They know that very few of us had glass cockpits on the Cessna's we learned on so they try to gouge us for extra cash to get the less capable version of the airplane.  The only reason you would want it is that you used to fly it, otherwise the Garmin version is better.  DCS is a very different flight sim, but it has gorgeous maps that a high end system can render in VR with smooth frame rates.  There is no Cessna in DCS, but the Cessna in my version of MSFS is wrong anyway, so no huge loss there, and the overall experience in DCS is better.  The MSFS whole world map is cool, but if it's a whole world watercolor that's less cool.  This whole experience has made me appreciate the crisp, smooth, fast rendering of DCS even more.  DCS is a  combat simulator, but if you aren't interested in that aspect of flying you can create freeflight missions easily enough.  The plane choices are geared towards combat aircraft, but you can find a few unarmed trainers if that isn't your thing.  The base DCS package is free, so check it out before you buy this game.

One very important thing to note though is that, if you want to have more aircraft, look at more airports, or want to get liveries for your planes, be prepared to either spend lots of money on the In-Game purchases (some of which can cost from $2.50 - $90+) or be ready to go and download stuff from the community online (make sure you know that what you are downloading is safe.)

Absolutely fantastic, I have logged at least 500 hours with the MS Store version* and will never stop. Along with X-Plane, it's a must-have for all aviation enthusiasts - whether you like flying to explore, performing missions, flying for airlines, it's all there. Contains a large selection of very detailed planes. It's impossible to review it without writing a book, it's best if you watch YouTube reviews instead. 

It's for everyone, you can can enable all assists and have fun or use it to study for your licence and everything in between. There are many free and paid addons (scenery, aircraft, objects, etc.). 

In my experience, it'll run well on an older machine such as i7-6770 (4 cores) with RTX2060 and SATA SSD, however I'd strongly recommend at least a mid-range system with 8 cores/16 threads @ 4.5GHz, RTX4070 or equivalent AMD, NVME SSD and fast DDR4, ideally DDR5 memory.

Controller support is fantastic. Don't try it with a keyboard only, you wouldn't drive a car with a keyboard. Again, I'd recommend a joystick (with a throttle slider). However, the xbox/ps controller support is excellent once you master the basics of flying.

* - I highly recommend that you get the Steam version instead of Microsoft store to avoid installation problems.

i have been playing MSFS off 3.5" floppy disks when I was in my teens and had a Toshiba T1000 laptop with NO HDD and just 256KB (volatile) RAM!!  as they called it then.  We had a foldable chart of US airspace and VOR of airports and the only aircraft available was a Cessna172.
This is my Most favorite game since 1988 and will always remain one.

I'll come back and update this later if I see fit... but so far this has been my experience.

Buy game, marvel at it's small download size (~2Gb).
Launch game expecting some extra downloading, as 2gb would be on par with flight Sim 98!
Find there is a 160gb download to do, which requires the game to be running (not just the normal steam download process).
           - This gives problems if you want to play something else and Steam complains you're already 'playing'  Flight Sim.
Anyway, get it all downloaded (which over a 40mb/s connection wasn't quick).
Leave it for the weekend to come and play your newly purchased game, to find there is now a 12.5GB update to do (which you only get told about when you've launched the game - again rather than the standard steam installer).

So in summary, so far I've "played this game for 18 hours" which has been entirely downloading content and not actually launched the game.

Add into the mix you can't throttle the downloads in their installer so I expect my wife is plotting where to bury my body this point. (Oh the irony, I had to pause the download so I had enough bandwidth to post this!)

I have been running MSFS 2020 (Standard) for a couple of months and generally pleased with it.  I use a Gladiator Evo joystick which is a big factor in enjoying the experience (RTX2060 Super GPU).  I have owned various IL2 versions and some other older flight software.
Lots of depth in terms of aircraft and airport features and good options in levels of difficulty/realism.
Plenty of good freeware but other expansions can be expensive if not on sale.
Standard ground detail is very good with 'crafted' areas (Microsoft or other) and also good at higher altitudes but less good at low levels (e.g. cars caught in the map scans are flat and bridges often not rendered).  Using AI etc to improve these in future releases would be a big plus.
But overall good value for the Standard version (others versions seem over priced) and near endless scope for adventures and challenges.

For everything this does well, there are some issues that just never get fixed that ruin the entire experience.  This simulator is in disrepair, there are a number of things that are constantly overlooked.  All these people who develop and publish this care about is taking your money, the experience of flying is beyond messed up with all of the borked issues with the UI and controller profiles being deleted over and over, its ridiculous.  I can NOT honestly in good faith recommend this to anyone.  This simulator, in its current form, should cost NO MORE than $30 for the best version.  NOTHING in the in game market place should cost more than $20.

EDIT 9/12/23
IF you can wrap your head around the limitations of the software as well as your own hardware in relation to this flight sim, there is quite a bit of fun to be had.  It's far from a perfect experience to set everything up properly.  If you can get past that major hurdle of getting set up and also understand that there are many technical limitations separating this from the real life physics of flying, then you can have a decent experience flying the world from the comfort of your home.  Some aircraft ARE definitely better than others, and it would be a wise choice to look into these before spending your hard earned money on something in the store.

While I may have quite a bit of negative things to say, this sim is not without its redeeming factors.  I believe that what upsets me the most is the lack of transparency between the devs and the customer base regarding features and quality of life updates.  This is a decent sim, but it could have been executed much better.  There are still many ongoing issues that keep me from easily recommending this to just anyone.

TLDR:

If you really like aviation and have had fun flying in other simulators, give this a shot, it takes a pretty ridiculous long time to install and get set up, but once you get there and know what to do, its definitely fun to go exploring in an aircraft that you really like, even if the overall flight physics of the experience seem to favor the arcade style of flight simulation while the visuals aim for recreating that photo-realistic scenario.

Coming from prepar3d, I can say that as long as your hardware can handle the game, It's worth every cent. [h1] Microsoft Flight Sim 2020 (MSFS 2020): The Pinnacle of Close-to-Real-Life Flying [/h1]

[h2] Realism [/h2]
MSFS 2020 is mind-blowingly realistic. It's like sitting in a real airplane but in your living room. Everything in the cockpit, like buttons and switches, is exactly where it should be in a real plane. The way the planes move in the game feels just like they do in real life. It's like you're really flying.

It's not just the planes; everything in the game feels real. The way the sun shines into the cockpit, the reflections on the instruments, and the sound of the engines all make you feel like you're actually flying. Whether you love planes or you're new to this, you'll be amazed at how lifelike MSFS 2020 is.

[h2] World [/h2]
The world in MSFS 2020 is astonishing. [b]It's not just a made-up world; it's our world. The whole planet is recreated in incredible detail.[/b] Whether you want to fly over famous places like New York City or explore the Amazon rainforest, it's all there, and it looks incredibly real.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3008797845
The landscapes are so accurate. [b]You'll see busy cities, beautiful hills, and peaceful lakes, all looking just like the real thing.[/b] Even places you may not know about are recreated with amazing detail. It's not just about the big landmarks; it's about the whole world, and the level of detail is unbelievable.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3026094521
Plus, the world is alive. You'll see real weather happening, like rain, snow, and thunderstorms, which affect your flight just like in real life. The day turns into night, with beautiful sunsets and sunrises that make everything look stunningly real.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3001165113
[h2] Aircraft Variety [/h2]
MSFS 2020 has many different kinds of planes to choose from. Whether you like fast jets or classic propeller planes, there's something for everyone. Each plane is made with extreme care, inside and out, to make it look just like the real thing.
It's not just about the planes themselves; you can also customize your flights in many ways, like picking where you start and finish, choosing the time of day, and setting the weather. You have a lot of control over how you fly, making each flight special.

[h2] User-Friendly [/h2]
What makes MSFS 2020 special is that it's easy to play. Even though it's super realistic, it's made so that everyone, whether you're an expert or just starting, can have fun. If you're new to flying, you can start with simple controls and get better as you go. The game has tutorials and helpers that make sure you don't get overwhelmed and can enjoy the game.

[h1] MSFS Beyond Flying [/h1]
In addition to the freedom to fly anywhere in the world at your leisure, Microsoft Flight Simulator (MSFS) offers Landing Challenges and Bush Trips as its core content.

[b]Bush Trips[/b] are pre-designed flight adventures that replicate real-life journeys undertaken by bush pilots, known for navigating rugged and remote areas, often contending with challenging weather conditions and landing on unpaved airstrips. In MSFS, these bush trips provide you with an opportunity to experience these thrilling flights while putting your flying skills and navigation abilities to the test.

[b]Landing challenges[/b] in MSFS 2020 present thrilling scenarios that assess your piloting skills by demanding precise and safe landings at various airports worldwide. Each challenge offers a unique experience and situation to keep the gameplay engaging. There is a scoring system, rewards, and leaderboards associated with these landing challenges.


[h2] Cons of MSFS 2020 [/h2]
Long loading times and certain scenery in specific locations may appear unattractive and distorted, even after world updates. These are my primary concerns regarding the game.

[h2] Announcement of MSFS 2024 [/h2]
I do feel betrayed because they promised that MSFS 2020 would be supported for up to 10 years, and yet next year they plan to release a new game in the franchise. However, Microsoft has stated that MSFS 2020 will continue to receive updates. I'm skeptical of their word now, given their failure to uphold their promise.

[h2] Should you still buy MSFS 2020? [/h2]
[b]Yes, it's definitely worth it, especially when on discount. The game offers a wealth of content and quality of life updates, including major world updates since its release. If you decide to purchase it, you'll have access to substantial, high-quality content. Currently, it remains the only game that provides an experience close to real-life flying, with a 1:1 ratio of the entire world at your fingertips. Furthermore, we have yet to receive new information on the release date of MSFS 2024.[/b]

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
[b]In a nutshell, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is incredibly realistic, with a huge, detailed world to explore, lots of different planes, and an easy-to-play experience for all aviation enthusiasts. Its dedication to realism, dynamic world, and user-friendly design makes it a game that anyone interested in aviation or looking for an amazing virtual flying adventure should play.[/b]

It is with a raised eyebrow and a hint of whimsy that we contemplate the audacious claim that 'Microsoft Flight Simulator' stands as a ripoff of the illustrious 'Pilot Training Flight Simulator' within the enchanting realm of Roblox.

In the boundless skies of virtual aviation, 'Pilot Training Flight Simulator' has carved a niche as a celebrated gem, commanding the attention and admiration of aviators within Roblox. Meanwhile, 'Microsoft Flight Simulator' soars as a titan in the broader gaming cosmos, offering an unparalleled journey through the heavens.

The notion that one is an echo of the other invites contemplation on the intricate web of inspiration that shapes the gaming world. While they share the same canvas of the sky, their strokes of creativity differ markedly.

In this intriguing juxtaposition, one finds a delicate dance between emulation and innovation. 'Pilot Training Flight Simulator' thrives within the confines of Roblox, while 'Microsoft Flight Simulator' unfolds on a global stage.

Both games, each in their distinct fashion, pay homage to our enduring love for aviation in the digital age, offering diverse pathways to explore the limitless skies. It is a tale of two simulators, each with its own unique flight plan.

Flight simming has become my favourite hobby, using MSFS 2020 as simulator.

MSFS 2020 is a simulator which provides you with everything you need, such as real world and live weather, physics, the whole planet, airports, and so on... but not much more than, it can become boring quick enough if you don't plug in some career addons (Such as Neofly, A pilot life chapter 2, SkyPark, Onair) or simply joining a virtual airline.

As becoming a flight simmer, you will find what you like the most in aviation by touching and flying basics aircraft included the simulator, whether it's airliners, bush flying, military, sea planes, helicopters etc. From any of these, there is almost no limits on what you can do in order to push your experience in the direction you want. The flight simulation modding community is huge, there are tons and tons of addons and mods so you can customize your experience the way you want, to the immersion you want, to the degree of each you want.

The flight simulation community is huge and very helpful. I personally mostly fly Airliners on the VATSIM network (Real People doing the Air Trafic Control along with other players piloting their aircraft), I am part of a few Virtual Airlines (comparable to guilds/clans from other games) such as Ryanair, Virtual AirCanada, Southwest, Delta Airlines, EasyJet, they provide me with my flights which I complete for them in the most safely and realistic way possible. I use what they call ''Study Level'' aircraft, they are 3rd party developed planes very close to reality. I also uses addons which improve realism such as FSRalistic and FS2Crew (Last one adds a VIrtual First Officer to my airliners).

I just enjoy it so much, MSFS2020 is beautiful, I could not enjoy my flight simulation as much on a lower end simulator such as xPlane or P3D in regards of graphics.

The simulator as become much more stable over time, therefore always require some tweaking in order to find the perfect graphics for you. Its very, very cpu bound, think of getting a stronger CPU especially if doing airliners.  I will say that, the simulator (while for some not being a ''game'' but really a ''Simulator'') requires some technical skills, either because of addons and mods additions, but also tweaking of settings for your PC & Desired experience.

Happy flying

If you can grab this game on sale, by all means do it. It's come such a long way in 3 years. The load times are a bit long, the main menu is still a bit janky, but for most people, this is the perfect simulator, while die-hard realism fans will always prefer X Plane's superior flight model. I do a lot of flying in real life, so a superior flight model should be more important than graphics for me, yet I always seem drawn back to this instead. 

That said, if you're looking for your first sim, wait until Microsoft Flight Sim 2024 comes out. It will have more features, more missions, more "game" to go with your "simulator". It would be disappointing to spend money on MSFS 2020 and get invested in it, then feel like they're double dipping in your wallet when 2024 is released.

Latest Update:  TLDR-A disappointed flight student buys X-Plane 12.
I'm a flight student and would have loved to work on my takeoff and landing procedures BEFORE my lessons this weekend.  Unfortunately, I reached 70% after one week of not being able to use my PC.  Netlimiter had to be set under 350 KB/sec.  I thought I would make it, but TWICE it deleted 20GB and brought me back to 52%.  What a waste of 9 days.

I just bought X-Plane 12.  Don't waste your precious time/money for such a subpar product and company that will take both without regret.

First Update:  Its been about 36 hours and I'm back at 36MB out of 122GB.  I reinstalled Windows and it seems to have done nothing at all.  I tried downloading netlimiter as some people in the forums have suggested setting my download rate to under 2.3MB/s. I'll update if this works.

Original Review: This is a neat simulator if you can get past the initial "update" phase.  I let this thing run all night on a good internet connection, only to have it barely reach 8% of the download.

I had other work to do so I paused and restarted my computer.  Now I get to start over on the download!  Wow.  Not only that, but if you let MSFS2020 run in the background, you will LOSE DOWNLOAD PROGRESS.  I was just at 750MB.. I went to get some things on Amazon, and now I'm back down to 400MB out of 122GB.

This is the age we live in.  The great slowdown is upon us.  Multi-billion dollar companies can barely deliver you a software product.

as much as I love this game/simulation and the achievements it has produced with such outstanding clarity of the world and physic modelling, constant instability after each update, crashes and difficulty in just jumping in and flying when you want to rather than spending an hour trouble shooting, for me just does not justify a recommendation. Like most of Microsoft stuff, the right hand doesn't want to talk to the left and their lofty ambitions get caught up in delivery in what often feels like a Beta in terms of performance and stability. For a casual player who works seriously long hours, it becomes a choice between sitting down for an attempt at an enjoyable flight only to spend the next hour trying to sort out why my game is crashing, vs going and doing something productive with my limited and precious leisure time. Thanks for the efforts, but i cannot hand on heart recommend this to anyone who s not a serious enthusiast.

At the time I write this review, I have 15 hours in the game. I have never played it. This is because, despite the 1.9 GB download from Steam, there is an additional 122 GB that you need to download after you install it. So, supposing you don't end up liking the game, you can't actually refund it unless you have a god-tier internet connection that can download 122 GB in two hours. The installer was also a massive pain in the neck, slowing my PC down to a crawl, crashing constantly, and requiring me to pause and restart the game every few GB otherwise it'd, for some reason or another, go backwards. The game itself is fine, but just be aware: the installer is a pain in the ass and you cannot refund the game if you don't like it, so BE POSITIVE YOU WANT TO PURCHASE BEFORE YOU DO SO.

Eyecandy is implemented, plane computers and procedures are lacking. 

Good:

- Training lessons are kind-of approachable
- Various systems are in-game, like checklists, ATC, AI planes, map, etc. These would require additional plugins and money in other sim
- Weather is in-game and will never require a plugin
- You can fly low and actually look outside
- Photorealistic

Bad:

- Control mapping is inconsistent. Not everything in the plane can be mapped to external physical controls.
- Some existing features are broken, like holding mouse button will disable all joystick or flight control inputs. The bug was introduced with XBOX support, with no acknowledgment from the dev team.
- Team promised 10 year support, yet, they are already planning new game release.
- In-game ATC is stupid. Asks for traffic in-sight at FL330.
- Plugins and planes need to be developed in javascript, the most atrocious language ever. No wonder it takes took third-party developers so much time to release quality content.

In my original review, 3 years ago, I said "There are some things in this sim that are simply done right and promise a good foundation going forward". I expected a lot, because a lot was promised. This was supposed to be only the foundation.

The main additions since the release were content, VNAV implementation, and XBOX stuff that degraded mouse usage.

If we discount the content and look at the game itself, 3 years later, we still have foundation, with basically the same systems we had at the release. So much for expectations.

This confirms my old rule that what you see at game launch, is what you get in the end, no matter what promises are put forward.

Never buy the hype, never pre-order!

There is something very important that most people don't mention: This game does not auto update on it's own. You have to launch it and download updates through the launcher. Which wouldn't be a problem if the updates weren't 100+GB in size. My play hours are from me waiting overnight for updates to download.

UPDATE3:  Download manager is fiiiiiiiinaallyy fixed!

UPDATE2:  Even though progress has been made... the download manager is still the worst manager I've ever dealt with in my life.  Prepare to be infuriated with 1) just downloading the game in the first place and 2) getting hit with non-optional updates.

UPDATE1:  It looks like a lot of progress has been made to the data management and the general back-end of the sim.  I think this game is finally at a point where it's user friendly enough for folks without NASA grade PCs.

ORIGINAL:  The simulator itself is brilliant but don't waste your time on this until the download issue is fixed.  Updates are several gigs and you cannot choose to opt out.  Normally several gigs wouldn't be too much of an issue but this particular connection is just baffling me.  The download speed appears to be forced to excruciatingly small drip rate that will take (very literally, not an exaggeration) an entire week to get through with REGULAR restarts required to the download manager.  On top of that, there's a suspicious amount of GPU usage ALL the while this is running (WHYY!?).  It's just asinine, do not buy this until the download manager gets fixed, until then you cannot really use the product you're paying for.

I can't resist doing turns around a point over my house :))  I recently figured out how to get a smooth, consistent frame rate on 4K resolution.  Simply amazing!!  Even at 1080p setting the clarity is amazing.  It is fun to fly down local highways and be able to see some of the store front signs of my local shopping area.  VFR is absolutely possible using VFR charts.  Nearly everything road and obstacle is represented in the sim.  I keep finding new interesting things around my local airport from the air that i never knew were there.
I will say that I really want to enjoy VR more but I can't quite get the resolution I want with a smooth frame rate.  I can run almost everything at ultra/max on my monitor but not so much luck with my Quest 2.  It runs and it looks gorgeous but there is too much stuttering.  I assume it is my headset.  It usually shuts down after about 30-40 minutes, I believe from too much internal heat.  I wait about 20 minutes and it works just fine again.
X-Plane is smoother in VR for my headset but it lacks the amazing, accurate detail of MSFS.  Have yet to try a multi-monitor setup but I'll post again when I do.

After three "completed" flights with MS FS 2020, I have to say that, in all honesty, I cannot recommend MS FS 2020 at this time because the game is still very very defective and bug-riddled.  The developers at Asorbo Studio had obviously released the game far too early on Tuesday 18th August 2020 with not enough development having been done on the game, which is why the game is still very defective and bug-riddled.

Nothing ever works right, I managed to crash into Heathrow on the very first flight and I couldn't even fly anywhere with the AI co-pilot controlling the aircraft (Boeing 747-8i) which forced me to have to restart the flight - the failed flight still ended up in my logbook and there is no way of removing it from the logbook.

The AI co-pilot also did not follow the suggested path quite properly when taxiing to the departure runway,   On landing at Frankfurt am Main (EDDF), the aircraft also did not line up with the arrival runway properly, the AI co-pilot also did not follow the suggested route to the arrival gate quite properly, running over a stationary turboprop on the way.

With the second flight, the ATC controller kept telling the AI co-pilot to climb to flight level FL390 / FL410 / FL430, and the nav waypoints all had the distances to the next waypoint together with the expected altitude (e.g. FL430, using the IFR high altitude airways), but somehow the AI co-pilot kept ignoring all ATC instructions and all nav waypoints, opting to fly the plane at 36,000 to 38,000 ft isntead.  I would love to give the AI co-pilot the boot for ignoring all ATC instructions.

At the end of the second flight, the AI co-pilot overshot the airport (Dubai International, OMDB) because the aircraft was far too high, so the AI co-pilot then had to execute a missed approach but managed to crash the plane into the sea off the Dubai coast (which left me very disappointed and very underwhelmed) because he was far too late in bringing the landing wheels down and I had great difficulty in trying to pull the landing wheel down in the cockpit.

WIth the third flight which was at Singapore Changi (WSSS), the AI co-pilot managed to overshoot the airport again, had to go round and then around again to land into the airport but the AI co-pilot managed to miss the glidepath to the arrival runway, landing the aircraft on grass instead of the runway, managing to run over two stationary "follow me" trucks before they were forced to move off (the aircraft also narrowly missed running over a moving van that was moving along the runway when the aircraft was taxiing to a parking gate.

That was it.  MS FS 2020 is further evidence that all Microsh*t / Microscam / Micro$$$$$$$$$ software will all always be typical Microsh*t / Microscam / Micro$$$$$$$$$$ crapware, especially with the latest Windows 10 Insider Preview (version 20H2) being yet more evidence of Microsh*t / Microscam / Micro$$$$$$$$$$ crapware.  MS FS 2020 is one big fat complete lemon, like X-Plane, not worth the ¬£109.99 for the premium edition, because the people at Asorbo Studio are very clearly not the brightest lightbulbs on the face of the planet because the standard of their "development" is just very mediocre and very average.

In addition, there is no way of loading / unloading passengers, loading / unloading baggage and cargo, no way of allowing cleaners and caterers aboard to clean the aircraft and replenish the catering trolleys, no
way of loading fuel and no way of connecting / disconnecting ground power which would have made for
far more realistic experience, and there is also no way of loading / unloading passengers, loading / unloading baggage / cargo, no way of allowing cleaners and caterars aboard, and also no way of loading fuel in all
pilot checklists.  Why?

The minimum hardware reqirements for MS FS 2020 is very demanding, very unreasonable and very excessive.  If you do not have the latest hardware spec required to run MS FS 2020, just forget it.

That is the end of my "adventure" with MS FS 2020.  I have been conned and ripped off, and I now hate Microsh*t / Microscam / Micro$$$$$$$$.  The people at Microsh*t / Microscam / Micro$$$$$$$ all are very clearly brain-dead idiots.

MSFS is just complete rubbish and a sheer waste of time and money.  A big rip-off by the mediocre half-wit crooks at Asobo who obviously have caca for brains.

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a stunning triumph in virtual aviation. Its realism, attention to detail, and dynamic landscapes create an immersive experience that's both accessible to newcomers and deeply satisfying for aviation enthusiasts. From the meticulously recreated aircraft to the awe-inspiring views, every flight is a journey of wonder. With ongoing updates and a supportive community, this simulator is a testament to the beauty of virtual flight and the thrill of exploring the skies from the comfort of your own home.

Microsoft Flight Simulator Review

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

First and foremost, the graphics in Microsoft Flight Simulator are simply stunning. The level of detail in the landscapes, cities, and aircraft is truly awe-inspiring. From towering skyscrapers to lush forests and serene coastlines, the world feels alive and realistic. The weather effects, including rain, snow, and fog, only enhance the visual spectacle, making each flight feel like a true adventure.

One of the standout features of this simulator is the vastness of its world. With a data-driven platform, you can explore the entire globe with astonishing accuracy. From busy international airports to remote airstrips in the middle of nowhere, the world is your oyster. Whether you want to fly over your hometown or embark on a cross-continental journey, the possibilities are endless.

Where to start with all my disappointments? All I can say is 10 years for this S***!

I have 1150 hrs in FSX:SE, flying nothing but PMDG Study Level Aircraft. I am not a pilot, just enjoy simming it. When it was announced that Microsoft was rebooting the franchise from the disaster that was DTG, I was super stoked for a 64 bit rendition of the game‚Ä¶because let‚Äôs be honest, that‚Äôs what it is. A game! 

FSX was great, but we‚Äôve all been there‚Ä¶you know, on final approach after sitting at the computer for a non-time compressed flight, across the Pacific from Sydney to Los Angeles‚Ä¶and then ‚ÄúBoom‚Äù‚Ä¶CTD! Thank God FSX crashed more than planes do in real life, because that would suck bad‚Ä¶real bad. But tell that to my saddle sore backside after an 18 hour flight, only to have it CTD on the last 5 to 10 minutes‚Ä¶in my mind it may as well be real.

So, in the 1st days of MSFS 2020, truly in the 1st days, I was a good little sheep and bought the ‚ÄúPremium Deluxe‚Äù version. Spent the hours and hours of installation on those early days, I think it was 3 hours or more with the fastest internet in Canada. I started it up and it seemed ok, I tried a half hearted flight from Denver to Cheyenne, in a little single engine turbo prop, but as there were no PMDG products available (I hate Airbus), I put it aside.

I patiently waited as PMDG and MSFS worked out whatever issues continued to plague the 737, and when I felt the time was right, I bought the PMDG 737-800. But, I also needed‚Ä¶LOL‚Ä¶ ‚Äúneeded‚Äù the TCA Boeing Yoke & Throttle Quadrant ( I already had a perfectly good Logitech Yoke and Throttle Quadrant, as well as Rudders) and the Logitech Radio panels and Multi Panel to compliment my Switch Panel. I spent a lot of $$$ to be hooked up and running again. My last flight was more than 2 years ago, in FSX, and you guessed it‚Ä¶CTD on descent, after flying across the Atlantic! 

All the pundits went on and on‚Ä¶and on and on‚Ä¶about how GREAT MSFS 2020 is.

Fast Forward to 3 days into flying in MSFS‚Ä¶I have had more CTD in MSFS than I did in my last 20 flights with FSX. I have to run the game on the lowest settings, and it‚Äôs not like my machine is a crappy machine. My CPU is only at 4 to 5%, my VRam is at 49%, my RAM is at 41% and I was getting a decent 49 FPS throttled at 60 FPS and 60Hz refresh on two monitors capable of 165 each. However, my GPU kept spiking over 85% and at points into the 90‚Äôs, and I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs what crashed it every time. I have an RTX 3060 with 12GB VRAM‚Ä¶now I know that‚Äôs not the BEST card, but it‚Äôs well above the recommended specs for the game. I have a Ryzen 7 3700X 3.59GHz and 32 GB of RAM.

Back to the Pundits‚Ä¶You all have never flown in FSX obviously, because if you have/had you would realize that the following is TRUE:

-Who gives a crap about the level of detail of flora and fauna, boats and cars when you are at FL370  (wasted PC resources)‚Ä¶are you driving a F****** Car? No! You‚Äôre flying a plane!
- ASOBO basically copied everything from FSX and put LIPSTICK on THIS PIG!
- The AI Traffic is still just as S***** as it was in FSX
- The ATC is still just as S***** as it was in FSX (except now they don‚Äôt yell at you for flying a STAR approach, and you don‚Äôt need to use Edit Voicepack to get a VR Airline Name in the game)
- ATC makes you stop randomly during Taxi, when no one is around, or they make you wait endlessly behind a Cessna Skyhawk, that looks to be stalled on the Taxiway‚Ä¶Utter Bulls***!
- Even the airports for the most part are not completely updated (ahem!cough!sputter! CYVR, cough! ASOBO, there are more metropolitan cities in Canada than just Toronto) and if you do happen to purchase some DLC Airports, after the game CTD‚Äôs, on restart it‚Äôs going to tell you to make the community folder inactive‚Ä¶Why? If you made the game NOT so S***** in the 1st place, then maybe we, ‚ÄúTHE CUSTOMERS‚Äù wouldn‚Äôt need a computer that can run NASA, just to use the DLC that you shill on the Market Place‚Ä¶My guess is that you saw how wonderfully this works for DTG and Train Simulator, and decided to follow the road map.
- Whose stupid idea was it to STREAM the World over an internet connection, rather than have the files local on hard disk, saving possibly money in DATA and not having to rely on internet connections‚Ä¶because EVERYONE at some point has internet issues. What? Did ASOBO buy stock in AOL? I‚Äôd much rather have it all on my hard drive. I don‚Äôt see what was so terrible about the FSX world system. FSX allowed you to deactivate parts of the world that you were not flying in, essentially limiting RAM and CPU usage‚Ä¶I see you didn‚Äôt learn anything in 10 years.

- The only PRO I can find so far is the realistic Runways, unfortunately I can‚Äôt see them because my settings are too low, but I can feel them.

And finally, and possibly my biggest beef‚Ä¶No FS Passenger‚Ä¶oh the screams, the screams‚Ä¶and the money!!! I really miss the stewardess barging into the cockpit to tell me about the passenger in 4c with the rash‚Ä¶and who could forget that bloody light penalty, or the Radar gun that clocked you doing 254kts under 10k‚Ä¶oh what fun!...Oh OK...that's NOT ASOBO's fault...but, in my defense, they did basically take every great FSX Addon and implement it into the game..so why not FS Passenger...so it IS ASOBO's fault...LOL

In Conclusion, if you‚Äôre looking for a sim‚Ä¶don‚Äôt waste the money. They have already stated that they are abandoning MSFS 2020 and building a new one MSFS 2024. Unless you are committed to buying ALL the big shiny new computer parts‚Ä¶your system will probably not run this game as it is intended to run.

I just finished weighing the costs of purchasing a new Simulator(P3D) and replacing ALL of my PMDG aircraft from FSX and adding one, against the cost of an RTX 4070 Ti (not including new power supply) and The new sim and replacement planes comes in at $115 cheaper. It seems to me, that only having ‚ÄúReal Runways‚Äù as an advantage, doesn‚Äôt justify the cost of MSFS 2020, it certainly isn‚Äôt worth $115. Let alone the $160 CDN price tag for the game.
