COMPLETELY UNUSABLE NOW AFTER UPDATING, CRASHES UPON LOADING EVERY TIME! this started after yet another game UPDATE! Ran OK before. Internet searches show many others have had this problem but Microsoft have not sorted this out since the end of October (2020) and multiple complaints. 

The developer website (Xbox) has literally 'thousands' of trouble shooting posts. One single CTDs error post has 44K views? IS THIS NORMAL???

It loads the adverts, then asks for me to set up an Xbox live account but wont let me click on anything, it will sit like that for hours if I leave it. I uninstalled it and reinstalled it (taking all night and some of the next day to download) but it's exactly the same. Tried again some months later, still the same.  I've tried various fixes from internet sources but so far nothing has worked. MONTHS of fault finding. I give up! I requested a refund but Steam WON'T refund as I've played it for over two hours, even though the first 12 hours were the installation program running, (I spent ¬£79 on this game by the way)! The updates and loading time show as play time on Steam which is completely pointless. I'm not going to stop fighting to get my money back even though I'm already feeling the might of such a large company pushing me back, ¬£79 down the flipping drain. I've contacted Microsoft too but am still waiting for some communication. To say I'm not happy is an understatement. This is the first Microsoft game I've bought in a few years, and I WON'T be buying any more. This game has regular updates that seem to bugger up installations with absolutely no comeback on Microsoft. There are multiple examples on the internet of people with game issues. I would like Steam to send more feedback to Microsoft or even stop hosting this game all together. I've been waiting 14 years for the remake of FSX and I thought this was it! Sadly not. I'm so disappointed in this product. Even when it was working it had multiple flaws, like it isn't finished. The loading times are a joke, (and I've got a ¬£1200 Gaming PC). 5 to 10 minutes to load, then if you want to change world location or aircraft you have to do that 5-10 mins all over again. At maximum graphics settings it looks great and pushes my PC to the limit but sadly it does not run smoothly, it stutters/pauses randomly. I've lowered the graphics to the lowest settings but it still pauses. I have other more demanding games that do run smoothly, it doesn't make sense. Some aircraft could have more buttons that actually do something. There seems to be less actionable buttons in this version than FSX. The playability is good by how you look around the cockpit, but I never had much of a problem with that before. The world terrain photo scenery is good but FSX had add on scenery that was good 14 years ago! Sorry, but I've just had far too many problems in FS2020 and the fact that now it doesn't work at all, that I cant recommend this game. I'm going to try X-Plane instead, if I can still afford it!

You spend like 6 hours updating the game every time you load it up. Enough is enough.  You might as well just pay for actual flight school.

Right, where to begin with this steaming pile of cat turd of a flight simulator. I have been flying just about every installment of Microsoft Flight simulator to this date. ( and just about every other flight simulater out there ) Had fun with the flight sim. Practically learned flying with FS95. ( flew the ones before to ) But FLightsim 95 is where I truely started learning.  Flew 98, 2000 and FSX.  I think I logged most of my time on FSX. Upgraded that with the tileproxy. Actually got it to look pretty damn good. Closer to msfs2020 then the dev's care to admit. This is mostly down to bing maps being pretty mehh, when compared to other mapservices out there. Then for me came P3D with PMDG add-on planes. Now that was a treat. FLying the big birds. Airacs, SIDs and STARS. flightplans. REX. great flying to be had.  And then came MSFS2020. I was hyped. Everything we loved about FSX. But now better. looked amazing. And the talk about improving the flightmodel to something that has a bit more fluidity to it, instead of the "on rails" experience. Count me in I thought. Install was a breeze. But then..ohhhh boy,then the updating starts. Hours on hours worth of updating. And then the biggest disapointment. This is not a simulator. It's an X-box console arcade game looking like a flightsim. But dumbed down so thata 14 year old with a controller on an x-box can have a good time aswell. ( which is fine when you are a, lets say, 14 year old with an x-box controller ) But not when you are a 30+ year experience flightsim buff who would like a challenge. The planes are somtimes outright uncontrolable because of weird things going on in the flightmodel. ( looking at you A320 ) complete loss of elevator authority for no appearent reason. Adventure flights not registering landings. Or even worse. Showing empty nav logs. Meaning you can't finish the challenges. Endless updating. every time I think I would like to give this a try after a few months. It tells me I need to install some other patch. These are not small either. Just sat through a 9 Gigabyte patch. Meanwhile having to listen to this song droning on in the background. Why can't this game quitely update in the background. While I am bussy doing meaningfull stuff, without being bothered by the game. The previous time something was changed, and all of a sudden I could not click on things in the cockpit. After searching on forums, I found I had to go in a menu somewhere, and put a setting back to classic. Then it worked again. Again flying experience is subpar. Graphics that looked fine all of a sudden got "optimezed" And now it looks like someone has gone to town on all glass surfaces with a pencill, crosshatching it all in. reminds me of the old CGA graffics days. But then everything was magenta and cyan. And tonight, the final insult. Firt after the update the game refused to go to full screen. And buttons were not registering where the mouse hoovered. had to shut the game down because it froze. When I restarted, the game stated that it crashed earlyer, and that this was probably down to third party software. ( pointing fingers right away are we Asobo/Microsoft? ) Shamefull. nd then the final insult. It will not let me controll my aircraft. Again all the settings are gone and or reversed. But now I cannot move my aircraft. I see the throttle indicator move in de overlay hud in 3rd person view. But nothing happens. The game is frozen. I hear the engine running but nothing happens. ( I checked active pause..that is not it ) So now it has literally for the umptienth time become. UNFLYABLE!! This is the best looking piece of crap I have seen in a long time.  But a flightsimulater it is not. It is an update en fumble and try and restore your controll settings simulator. I paid full price for this what is a shame. It was actually better before they started updating the game. It has literally become unplayable. Maybe this is only on PC. But is an utter disgrace. I have not written many reviews. But here I feel I have to warn people. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!! Please, install DCS. It's free. It flies like a dream. Looks fantastic. has proper aerodynamics going on. And if you are done with the SU-25 and P51. Get yourself the F18 on discount. And enjoy what a real working flight simulater feels like. This pile of shit is a complete waste of your time.

~edit august 2023~ 
This just keeps getting worse and worse.10 gig update. 
All progression in lessons is gone. So I have to start that from scratch. Couple of basic steps into the first familiarization lesson. The lesson requires me to "hide" the yoke by pointing at the yoke, and pressing cockpit primary control lockable. No clue what that means. So i go to control settings, and find out that this key is not configured yet. Why Microsoft/Asobo, do you not make sure that buttons we need in our first lesson are at least configured. Then comes the job of selecting a particular button to press for this action. But then it tells you all most of the keys are allready assigned. I am already fed up with this. And why can't you spin the friggin globe on the worldmap!!!  The world means more then north america!!  Try and select an airfield in norway. Then just tried to fly the landing challenges.  I had this all on 100% and all A's. But now they added flights again. So now I need to fly some new ones.  Sure. No problem. First one. easy landings. Should be a piece of cake. Flight comes on in the dark. With a master caution on, and no primairy flight display. So I have no clue as to how fast I am going. ohh my word...this game. it is so broken. It literally throws everything at you to prevent you from actually flying the game and completing the challenges. Came back to see if anything changed. It is still not ok. And then the worst part is...they allready announced MSFS2024.  So now all of us that have 3rd party software are in for a treat.  We get to find out if our stuf works in the next iteration???  But with this trackrecord, I highly advise against getting MSFS2024 early.  Big disappointment.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Iv'e been Flight simming since FS 5 way back in the early 90's and have had nearly all versions since. My last version being FSX. I even dipped my toes into Xplane 11 and was amazed at the world environment that sim presented, but this new FS2020 version blows them all away.
Stunning scenery, even on low settings, real live traffic, a living breathing world, real time weather and, if your internet connection can handle it, streamed ground textures. Wow!
However, there are some bugs, like ATC not working properly.

But...................recently Microsoft/Asobo introduced FS2024, so all their actual promises of 10 years of continuous development have virtually gone out the window for FS2020. I can't see them splitting their teams in half to work on both sims, as is apparent with the lack of recent fixes, and indeed more bugs have been introduced with every update. A deliberate ploy?, to push everyone to buy FS2024. who knows, but it wouldn't surprise me from Microsoft/Asobo these days.

Bought the basic version on sale. I don't care about realism at all, but the detailed map is great for aerial tourism. I keep all the assists on, damage and fuel off, and just go hover around sightseeing all the places I've been in life. I just fly the Volocopter (quadcopter thing) - super slow but the computer makes it super easy to just hover in one spot - when sightseeing buildings etc up close. I fly the F-18 Hornet when I want something faster. Lots of fun and I'm going to bring my computer with me to show my friends and family the aerial views of the various places we've been to.

Others have covered the downsides - It's like a 50 GB Steam download to start, then it downloads another 150 GB with a non-functional progress bar. Then in-game you still want/need a fast internet connection to stream detailed map data, and Microsoft's servers suck and constantly give "disconnected" errors. Also you need at least a current mid-tier desktop PC to even run it at minimum settings, and you also need a Microsoft account. Also the game is technically playable with an xbox controller and I use one for my sightseeing flights in the Volocopter and Hornet just fine, but you'll want a real cockpit HOTAS setup if you're going to fly the big planes or try turning the assists off / damage on etc.

Even after all those annoyances it's still worth it - seems like the closest thing to your own personal helicopter tour ($$$$$), from the comfort of your couch

The gameplay's great, tho there are some other problems:

1 - You only install the launcher on steam. This means, you'll have to gain playtime just by installing the actual game, making it impossible to refund the game once it's actually installed, due to steam's 2 hour policy.

2 - The installation process is extremely annoying, with it having a high chance of corrupting mid-way.
The method I used to fix this, was to press "Windows + R", type "%appdata%", go to "C:\Users\XXXX\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft Flight Simulator\Packages\Official\Steam", right click and sort by date modified. Then simply delete fs-base files, restart the PC and start the download again.

The download also tends to break whenever windows defender has Real-Time-Protection enabled.

While these problems are extremely frustrating, especially because they happen right after opening the launcher, being able to play the game and putting hours after hours into it is absolutely worth it.

Its a great simulator when it works correctly. I have been playing it for about a year now with no issues until two days ago. Now it just crashes at the startup screen for no reason. It worked fine one day and not the next. I have made ZERO changes to my system, NOTHING.  I went through and updated every driver I could think of and still nothing. Now I can't fly and I'm pretty ticked off about it.
This is a large memory/heavy CPU game for me. I haven't tried it since I bought a new computer, but it seemed like a lot of fun if you're into flight simulators.

The good - A huge variety of aircraft and some of the most realistic scenery I have seen on PC.  Being able to fly over real cities and real landmarks and land on real airports with realistic weather is incredible.  Lots of fun activities.  Amazing graphics if you have the system to push it.  One of the best VR experiences available, the cockpits are very realistic.  A lot of DLC.

The bad - You have to log into the game to download most of the content.  This includes large world scenery updates, airports, traffic, and aircraft.  Would be nice if you could just automatically download all your DLC like most every other Steam game.  With the amount of world updates, and the fact you have to select them in-game means this game sometimes feels like download simulator.  MS said the next version of Flight Simulator will have better missions and support for multi-threading and I am wondering why they aren't providing that for this product.  It isn't like multi-core CPU's are new and we had some pretty awesome missions in past versions of the product, Flight Sim X especially.

Other - Setting up my CH Product HOTAS caused many blue screens of death on Win 11 pro.  I am pretty sure these crashes were due to the default inputs being replicated across devices, so the throttle and fighterstick had many buttons doing the same thing.  I was eventually able to get the buttons sorted and the blue screens stopped but it was pretty painful going through multiple reboots to do it.  Game also randomly crashes every so often but seems like every MS Flight Sim I have owned has done that.

Overall I can still recommend, especially if you have a VR headset.  One of the most immersive VR experiences available.

Edit: The game has become a lot more stable over the last few years, and I can happily recommend it for aviation nerds like me. Especially with third-party additions like the FBW A320N and Vatsim

When this game works, it's great. It looks stunning, sounds amazing, and can be genuinely immersive.

Which means I have to delete the content folder, and re-install, which genuinely takes most of the day.

Until the stability and updating issues are resolved, I cannot recommend people buy this game.

[h1]Important update[/h1]
There is one important thing that is basically not stated anywhere - you cannot use Steam functionality to move MSFS installation to another discs. It is because aside from one 2Gb general content all content like Mandatory updates, Word updates and your purchased content is installed via game client and not via Steam. So if you try to move MSFS installation to another disc, Steam moves only that 2Gb general content - and delete everything that was on original disc.
So you have to re-download everything, which might be a lot of data.So if you plan to move MSFS installation to another disc, do not use Steam function for this, but instead look for some video or article where is explained how to do that and how to avoid reinstalling everything again.

I have used Steam to move the MSGS files and now I have to re-download everything, which on my 10 megabit wi-fi will take ages.

I don't blame Steam for that, they just move the content they install, I blame Microsoft for not putting a warning somewhere and not providing instructions how to do it properly, if they decided to go with their own installer.


[h1]Update[/h1]

VR was released so it is time to update my review. I am playing with Oculus Rift and HOTAS. So far FS does not support motion controls, which are, at least from my experience with X-plane horrible way how to fly but for others it might be a huge setback.

From my point of view everything in VR is done right or at least acceptable. Swithches are operated by mouse similar to DS and windows can be positioned anywhere in the sphere around you similar to Flyinside. Both systems works very good and I am glad that Asobo did not try to reinvent the wheel and used them.

What is not so comfortable is, that mouse cursor has some 3d aspect and is in front of the switches and when properly positioned it somehow attaches to them. In DS the mouse cursos does not have this aspect and "touching" the switches is more smooth.
Another annoying issue is that currently is not possible to map trims into axis. But I suppose that this will be fixed, because it should be considered as a must have option for every simulator.

But back to the VR - performance wise you need a powerful rig, there is no doubt about it and if you do not play on bitcoin miner you will also spend some time with tuning the option, but given how awesome FS looks  it runs surprisingly good. With sacrificing resolution and details and setting up specific profile in card setting I now have very smooth performance almost without micro stuttering. I would say that performance is close to DC and definitely much batter than X-plane (but I didn't try X-plane with Vulcan, it might perform much better).

When playng in VR I recommend to read some MSFS performance tuning articles and try it yourself, you probably will be able to get at least slightly better performance. And some settings, like Windows accelerated GPU scheduling might be a real game changer.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

There are many awesome aspects of MSFS  but one recently added featuretook my breath away. They added actual snow coverage, so if snow is melting in your country exposing parts of ground while other places are still covered by snow you will see the same in game and if there is total snow coverage, same goes also for your virtual flying.  And it is not just ground texture, also vegetation has winter models and I have to say I was blown away when I saw it.

Lots of ground features are really amazing, like bridges, tunnels, windmills and many more. Also vegetation coverage seems to be spot on, I have landed on the meadow behind our house, and the line of trees along the road, edge of the forest, few trees around the lake and simply everything was spot on.

[h1]Warning[/h1]

First of all, MSFS is a huge game and problem is, that it is not installed via Steam, but via Game Client. And running the game client counts as playing the game so you will probably have several hours of game time just before you download the game. As far as I know Steam is aware of that and you can refund it anyway, but be warned and do not rely on that.

[h1]General conclusion[/h1]

Buy if
- you want beautiful landscape, weather and generally all the eye candy for your VFR flights
- have relatively powerful rack and and not absolutely horrible internet connection
- you are ok with small amount of default planes and poor support from 3rd party developers
- you are ok that VR version is still in beta

Do not buy if
- you are easily annoyed by Microsoft business model and it's attitude towards 3rd party developers
- you are expecting plenty of high quality 3rd party content
- you prefer to fly heavy metal, military jets, warbirds, floatplanes etc.

Generally this is  something what we have been waiting for almost a decade and now we have to hope that Microsoft will not let it die, because no sim can thrive without the support of 3rd party developers, no matter how great the base game is

Thought i'd give the game a go in the evening, but then it hit me with a 90GB download..
Thought i'd give it a go in the morning then, but the game still hadn't downloaded 9 hours later..
Now i won't even have a chance to refund the game if i don't like it...

Edit after about 30h of playtime:

The game is fun when it works. However there are constant little problems especially with the mouse (at least in VR. Haven't tried without). The cursor on many parts of most aircraft ends up *behind* the surface of the instrument panels so i have to close my right eye and "aim" the cursor with the left because it's not in focus anymore.
The cursor bugs out in other ways too, both in the cockpit and in the menus. Very often clicking a button/switch doesn't do anything and i have to click away from the thing that i'm trying click to "reset?" something. Sometimes it helps. Sometimes it doesn't and i have to go back to a previous menu, or click a different window or something.
The knobs are SUPER weird at times. 
Sometimes they work fine. Sometimes the knob only goes so far or even starts to rotate the other way and you have to repeatedly grab it again to move it another 30 degrees or so.
Sometimes trying to adjust the knob with the mouse freezes the game completely until you let go of it and only works if you adjust it with the scroll wheel.

Responding to ATC tower with number keys simply doesn't work. I have to take my hand off the stick to click on the response options with my mouse, which kills the immersion and puts the aircraft in a death spiral. (mostly because i'm lazy at trimming the plane though.)

Trying to trim the aircraft with an axis on my stick is a death sentence. The trim holds for a while, but sometimes "forgets" it and sends it to 20degrees which instantly stalls the plane.
Don't use any axis on your HOTAS for trims.

Running the game in VR requires either tolerance for reprojetion and pixelation or deep pockets for a RTX 4090 and an i9 13900 (or both if you really like pretty graphics and legible instruments like me)
You might get the performance to tolerable levels with time tinkering in the settings.
There are tutorials on the internet that help if you don't know the precise performance hit of each individual setting like me.

Now that FS24 is coming, i think that they'll put much effort into fixing the 2020 version.
Unless you don't mind endlessly tinkering with settings and fighting bugs, i can't recommend the game. I only got this because i don't have enough patience or self control to wait for FS24..
Recommended, but requires good PC specs to play with good graphics, not for potato pcs.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Remarkable engineering masterpiece.
The best non-military flight simulator.
Casual game about airplanes and detailed aircraft simulator in one game.
Must-have for all aviation enthusiasts, good choice for travellers waiting for their next trip.

[h1]Idea[/h1]
Sandbox focused on airplanes. Real-scale, real world, real machines. You are the pilot, and the world is yours to explore.

[h1]Story[/h1]
There is no real story in this game. You need to rely on your own imagination to decide what to do next.
The closest thing to a story mode in are the "Bush Trips". These are scenarios that require you to follow written directions to travel from one point to another. These missions are located in places around the world that offer beautiful views.

[h1]World[/h1]
You can go anywhere in the world and configure time and weather. Watch a sunrise from the cockpit of an airliner, or test your skills in a tiny propeller-driven plane during a thunderstorm. The possibilities are endless, and you are in control.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Most of the time in the game is spent in free mode, where you can choose an aircraft and spawn at any location. There are other game modes, such as landing challenges, bush trips, and discovery flights, but overall, the game does not offer a robust progression system.

However, the main activity of flying an airplane is very immersive. In each aircraft, most of the switches are operable and have an impact on the flight.

If the plane has an autopilot, you can use it. It may take some time to learn, but it is a very satisfying skill to use in the game.

Navigation in the game is also realistic. You can use the navigation radio for instrumented flight, including the Instrumented Landing System.

A software development kit (SDK) is available for this game. You can use it to write your own program to control the plane, integrate external hardware, and more. The SDK offers almost unlimited extensibility.

[h1]Graphics and Sound[/h1]
This game is beautiful. The graphics and sound are amazing. Running it on ultra settings requires decent hardware, but it is absolutely worth it.

Letting the plane fly on autopilot and just looking around is a joy. Raindrops, reflections, clouds, forests, seas, and cities all look amazing. Some objects even have actual 3D models.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
You can come back to it anytime you feel like flying. It never gets boring.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- Represents the real world accurately.
- Provides detailed aircraft models.
- Simulates autopilot and navigation systems.
- Offers an SDK for creating extensions.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Has only a simple achievements system with no micro-achievements.
- Lacks engaging scenarios.

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a breathtaking masterpiece that has redefined the way we experience virtual aviation. As an aviation enthusiast, this game has been an absolute dream come true for me, delivering an unparalleled flight simulation that rivals reality itself.

From the moment you launch the game, you'll be awestruck by the attention to detail and the sheer scale of the world that awaits you. The graphics are nothing short of stunning, with realistic landscapes, cities, and landmarks that make you feel like you're flying over the real thing. Whether it's soaring through the majestic Alps, skimming over New York City's skyline, or navigating the intricate maze of fjords in Norway, the level of realism is simply astounding.

The flight mechanics are incredibly accurate, making every takeoff, landing, and maneuver a true-to-life challenge. It's not just about pushing buttons and pulling levers; you'll need to consider weather conditions, aircraft weight, and other factors that real pilots face. The attention to detail extends to the aircraft themselves, each meticulously modeled with functioning systems and authentic cockpit layouts. Whether you're flying a tiny Cessna or a massive Boeing 747, the experience is deeply immersive.

One of the standout features of Microsoft Flight Simulator is the live weather system, which uses real-world weather data to simulate conditions. Flying through a thunderstorm with turbulent winds and dark clouds overhead is both thrilling and nerve-wracking, while clear skies and gentle sunsets are truly serene. The dynamic time of day and seasonal changes further enhance the realism, making each flight unique and rewarding.

Beyond the remarkable single-player experience, the online mode adds a whole new dimension to the game. Flying alongside other real players in a shared world creates a sense of camaraderie and excitement, and you can even team up for group flights or air races. The thriving community also provides an abundance of user-created content, from new aircraft and liveries to custom-made airports that expand the game even further.

As with any complex simulation, there is a learning curve, but the game provides an excellent set of tutorials and assists to ease newcomers into the world of flight. With time and practice, you'll find yourself mastering the art of flight and developing a deep appreciation for the skill and precision required by real pilots.

Microsfot Flight Simulator 2020, a really good flight simulator in my opinion. If you are interested in aviation (generally airplanes) MSFS is a very good flight simulator. In the game you will find planes for sale, many of which have really good graphics. But you should first think about whether it is worth the money for it. I recommend watching a video about the plane beforehand to see if this plane is really worth buying. Of course, tastes are different and I definitely don't advise against not buying the plane now, if you're having fun and want to buy you the plane, you're welcome to do so, because as long as it's fun everything is fine and that's what we want. In summary, MSFS2020 is a very, very good game and also beginner-friendly. In my opinion a top game and definitely worth the money. (also included in the Xbox game pass)

Microsoft has used a disgusting, dishonest trick to prevent us from being able to refund the game: you download only the launcher from Steam... then download 120 gigabytes from the launcher.

As a result, you are guaranteed to be ineligible for a refund by the time you can actually play the game, because all that download time IS COUNTED AS PLAY TIME BY STEAM, so you're over your two hours before you ever actually play. This is an unethical dodge that prevents any possibility of getting your money back unless you realize this before you finish the download. I consider it fraudulent and criminal.

Plus, downloads get more and more likely to be corrupted as they get larger. There will be more starts and stops, more interruptions, and each one is a fresh chance for corruption--software corruption, not the kind I talked about first--to creep in, forcing you to start over once you finally think you're done with it. I have no doubt it will take me multiple attempts to download this massive white elephant... and since I fell for Microsoft's refund dodge, I have no choice if I want to get anything out of it.

For shame, Microsoft.

Update:

Most of the "86 hours" I've spent on this game has been purely downloading that initial 120 gigabytes. Yeah, I have a slower connection than most. That's still absurd. So, I have only a couple hours of actual flight time. Issues so far:

[h1]Best flight simulator after 3 years of release[/h1]

[b]Preface[/b]

For 3 years since the release of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020, I have faced a mountain of criticism of the game. After 3 years, I can say with confidence that this is the best flight simulator for your comfortable game today.

[b]One big minus of the Steam version[/b]

If you buy the Steam version of this game, you can immediately forget about the refund ‚Äî in fact, you are buying a launcher through which you download the game. It will not be possible to return it. But I'm sure you won't want to :)

[b]Incomparable advantages of the game in comparison with other flight simulators[/b]

The biggest plus, as you know, is the graphics. For 3 years, so many additions and improvements have been released that screenshots with ultra graphics are almost indistinguishable from reality. In addition, there is an AI in the game, which is the most trained of all the AI in flight simulators (because there are none in other simulators, ahah).

[b]Disadvantages[/b]

Prepare your wallets ‚Äî after buying the game for comfortable flights, you will have to buy a few more planes and at least a few airports from the community. In addition, it would be worth buying a number of additions like well-developed regional traffic and improvements for graphics at standard airports.

[b]Response to standard criticism[/b]

I constantly hear about three main claims against MSFS. Let's analyze each of them.
1) [u]Problems with physics[/u]. Often these claims are made by adherents of X-Plane and Prepar3D, who for some reason decided that in their simulators the physics is close to ideal. Not really. MSFS has normal physics, don't listen to them.
2) [u]There are no planes[/u]. The claim was relevant in the first year after the simulator was released, now the community has developed a lot of cool and detailed aircraft.
3) [u]Too expensive[/u]. No, it's normal for a game of this level.

[b]Is it worth buying in 2023?[/b]

Microsoft recently announced the release of Flight Simulator 2024. I do not rule out that the new game will face the same problems that were at the release of the 2020 version. In the next few years, MSFS 2020 will remain the best flight simulator available on the market. By all means buy if you want to fly with a beautiful picture and pleasure. And you won't have to suffer with installing plugins, hello, X-Plane, with which I have suffered.

P.S. Do not buy a version higher than the standard one, spend this money on add-ons :)

Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is a revolutionary entry to the franchise that completely redefines the standard for flight sims. This is just about the best flight simulator money can buy and truly represents the cutting edge of the medium. However, there are a couple massive caveats to my praise, namely performance and new user friendliness. To be totally forthcoming I did not play much of the game due to the technical limitations of my set-up (i7-10700, 6650 XT, 32GB DDR4) so keep in mind that I am coming with limited knowledge of all the gameplay features.

[h1]Performance and Optimization[/h1]
Make no mistake, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is [b]by far[/b] the worst optimized game I've ever played. I am not exaggerating when I say that my GPU pulling upwards of 110 degrees Celsius in game (it might've gone higher if I hadn't force quitted the app to avoid heat damage). My graphics were set to medium for the entire time though I experimented with higher and lower settings during separate sessions. My game crashed many times throughout and it has the longest load up time of any game I own despite the fact that I am loading it off a modern SSD. A lot of these performance issues I could've chalked up to the revolutionary features and insane graphical capacity of MSFS [i]if[/i] it hadn't been for the fact that my GPU temps starts to climb into the high 90s while still on the main menu.

I eventually had to uninstall the game because I simply was not having fun and the over 100GB it took up on my hard drive was preventing me from downloading games I actually want to play. This is unfortunate as I was really excited to play it, yet the abysmal framerate and threat it posed to my GPU's health were deal-breakers.

[h1]Accessibility to New Players[/h1]
While I appreciate the commitment to realism I also wish that a more user friendly approach was taken with the default control scheme. It is jarring for players new to the franchise and very clearly shows the intended audience of developers to be focused on the hardcore simmers with multi-thousand dollar flight sim peripherals. I do have to give credit where credit is due though, the tutorial is quite comprehensive and helpful, if a little long. A variety of other factors play into the intimidation factor for new players (the 12+ hour installation process upon first-time start-up for one) and to be honest that is mostly do to the nature of these hyper-realistic simulators. Still, there are things the devs could have done to appeal to a wider audience while not detracting from the hardcore experience that veteran simmers crave.

[h1]Overall Score and Conclusion[/h1]
If you are a airplane fanatic with a large disposable income for a top-of-the-line pc and peripherals, this is the game for you, there simply is no comparison. However, if you are a casual player with sensible mid-range hardware who is either looking for an introduction to flight sims or is wanting a casual flying experience, this simply not the game for you. For these reasons I can't recommend in good faith to the general gaming community though I still give it a solid 7.5/10 overall.

Most disapointing flight simulator.
MSFS had the opportunity to truly become the best flight simulator of all time (and by default, it is the best civilian flight simulator). However it seems that Asobo and/or Microsoft are refusing to adress core issues in the game and prefer adding shallow content.
Before getting into the details, I have to say, MSFS is great in many ways. Its photorealistic terrain generation make for an amazing visual experience (in the summer time at least), the "CFD" they brag about seems to be working well and most importantly, the community of third-party devellopers for aircrafts, systems and scenery give the game its purpose.
But it somehow stops there. The game is in most aspects very bad :
- The launcher: it looks like it was put together in a hurry and never revised. I, and everyone I know, had to reinstall the game at some point because of bugs in the launcher, during a 150Gb download.
- The Multiplayer: this feature (or lack of feature) is ridiculous, for a game that sold itself on its multiplayer. This is the extent of MSFS's multiplayer: you can see in the world everyone that checked the option to be seen. And that's it. There is no model matching (you will see your friends in the correct plane only if it the same as yours, otherwise it is replaced by one of the lowpoly ugly fictionnal planes from the game), there is no matching of animation (gear position, flaps, etc), no collisions and worst of all, if your friend comes close to your plane, they simply disapear, making close formation flying impossible. Also, the netcode is terrible.
- Ground handling: Ground handling feels terrible, there is no real simulation of the ground. It is hard to describe.
- Water: There is no water, water is just ground you can sort of sink into. It can roll on water. This makes seaplane unusable, which is weird for a sim that keeps putting out ads and content about seaplane.
- General feeling: There is a general lack of directness in the simulation. Every input feels like it is dampened by the game and you feel weirdly disconnected from the plane. It is hard to wrap my head around this but the feeling is there and it makes flying with stick and rudder in MSFS sometimes disapointing, as good as the flight model can be.

I will stop my list there but there are still a lot of core feature that make the game look like an unfinished product. And the real problem here is the fact the dev seem to never adress this. Every update is about content and nothing is done to adress core issues. I wish asobo would focus on MSFS as a plateform and leave the content to third parties (Aircraft and Scenery). 
Microsoft just announced MSFS 2024 which seems to only improve on the already good terrain generation (not complaining, I just think there are other priorities) and more content. Let's hope Asobo improves the core experience with this.

After saying al that, I still recommend this game, and I will continue playing it because third party dev put out amazing work to make the experience interresting and it also the best you can get for civilian flight simulation. 
To those who want a taste of what great flight simulation can be, Eagle Dynamics' DCS World is free to try and is to me the best experience you can get on your PC.

Two years in, and I still have to rate this game down. It is a visual spectacle and achievement, I have to give them that. But as a piece of software, as a game, as a flight simulator, as everything else other than being Google Earth with airplanes, it is a complete disaster. Most of the airplanes are not even close to their real world counterparts based on planes I've personally flown or ones I know people have flown. They have drastically improved performance since launch. But that's it. You STILL can't set a starting point, altitude, heading, airspeed, etc. You know, basic flight simulator stuff. If you start in a jet, you're starting at 31,000'. Want to practice landings, and just want to set yourself on final south of the field. NO. In a program called FLIGHT SIMULATOR, you cannot do that. So you can spawn at 31,000'. OK sure, you can slew down. Well guess what happens then? Because of the magic of aerodynamics, suddenly you're overspeeding. And the moment you un slew the aircraft. BOOM. Overstressed. You die. If you want to fly over your house, sure, get it. Just keep in mind that your Steam return policy will burn up because this game downloads itself via its own installer, so unless you can download the 150 something odd GB in an hour, you'll never be able to actually see the game before you can't send it packing. I want to love this. Aviation IS MY LIFE. Video games are another part of my life. This thing sucks at fulfilling both. So take it or leave it, this is just my opinion. And the fact that they have not fixed certain glaring UI and other issues, tells me that they're just in it for the money.

I'm on the fence about this Flight Simulator.  WHEN you can fly (i7-12700, 64 GB RAM,  & GTX 4080 video are NOT the problem), it is beautiful.

First, there is the download of the content and then the updates.  If you have a 1 Gbps connection, it appears that you are throttled by the "Xbox Networking" (see the Xbox gaming settings in Windows 10 by searching for "Xbox Networking) to an average speed of 6 Mbps to 30 Mbps.  It takes DAYS to download the game and its updates.  Thinking you are unique you search the web and find that at 6 Mbps to 30 Mbps you are getting far better download speeds than the other people who are complaining.  Meanwhile, Steam games download and update at speeds of up to 800 Mbps.  If Xbox networking is an example of Microsoft's cloud computing, then I want no part of it.  

Second, a lot of the old keyboard commands of previous versions of Microsoft Flight Simulator no longer work, as they want you to use your mouse to interact with the virtual cockpit, which means if you want "free flight" and to avoid using the autopilot and setting up a complete flight plan, forget it because you have to take your hand off of the joystick to use the mouse to control the cockpit settings.  No more controlling the joystick with your right hand (assuming you are right handed) and using your left hand to press keys on your keyboard.  

Third, you load in an aircraft and set the flaps, adjust the trim to "in the green" settings, set the radios, etc., and finally release the parking brake, and you get a verbal error that tells you that you cannot fly.  Does it give any reason why?  NO!  So you search online for a couple of hours and verify a bunch of settings and everything checks out okay and you still can't fly.  

Fourth, when you want to set your departure and arrival airports, you discover that the search is basically a joke.  It is apparently case sensitive, and expects you to know the call sign/identifier for the airport.  Want to find airports in Virginia?  Want to find airports in Utah?  Want to find airports in Washington state?  Sorry, there is no drop down for selecting the country, no drop down for selecting the city, etc. and then selecting the airport.  Say you want to find an airport on the island of Maui in Hawaii.  Good luck!  Your best bet is to call a pilot friend and ask them to use their resources to find some airports in Maui.  The departure/arrival airport selection process is a nightmare.  

The one positive thing is that if you eventually do manage to get an aircraft off the ground, the graphics are very good and nice and smooth.  I'm using an i7-12700 with 64 GB RAM, 2TB Samsung 990 Pro system drive and 2 TB Samsung 980 Pro game drive with an ASUS Z690-E motherboard and an ASUS ROG STRIX RTX 4080 OC 16 GB card at a display resolution of 3840 x 2160 and it is beautiful.  

Ultimately the problem is that Flight Simulator is such a pain in the rear to download, update, and then fly, and so expensive, that you wonder it you should have stayed with Flight Simulator X.  

It is getting late here and with the amount of frustration (which leads to a large amount of cursing) involved with trying to get this aircraft to actually start a takeoff roll, I'd better stop and call it a night before I wake up the neighbors.  

If the situation improves, I'll post an update.  If I don't post an update, it means I've given up, written this new version of Flight Simulator off as a lost cause and a waste of money, and returned to flying with Flight Simulator X.

It's excellent! I haven't played a lot of other flight simulators, but this one has a good amount of depth and so far I'm still working through the tutorials (after 32 hours!).

UPDATE TO THE UPDATED UPDATE - 
 
Don't bother now (summer 2023) New sim being released later this year or next with many of the features we have been waiting to have added during the 10 year development window. Basically you would be buying the beta unless they dont include the whole earth sandbox aspect of 2020. Somehow I dont see that happening.

UPDATED REVIEW AFTER 200+ HOURS IN GAME - 

Amazing. It just keeps getting better and better.  Every update brings new functionality, upgrades to scenery and texture maps, more detailed cities and landmarks.... and there are still years to go in the promised development cycle. Running a mix of ultra and high settings at 5120x1440 on dual monitors I average 70fps with an RX 5600XT and Ryzen 3900X. I am overclocked and custom water cooled so your results may vary but its not as demanding as you might think.  If you are on the fence jump off and get in here!

Original Review - 

Let me get this out of the way.... IT SAY'S "SIMULATOR" IN THE FREAKING TITLE!!!

Ok, now that any recently upgraded peasantry has been silenced lets get into the good stuff.

THIS is the one we have waited for.  Its a little rough with older flight sticks/controllers but there is enough adjustment in the sensitivity and deadzone settings to make even the jitteriest stick settle the F down.  Honestly I had to turn the settings to -100 on my Logitech Force 3D Pro just to keep from flipping the Cessna 172 in an impossible to recover from snap roll.   It's not a pop the cartridge in and go experience. You will need to learn and adjust as you go. I have things working  decently now and have started spreading my wings (see what I did there) and exploring places around the world I've never been as well as places I know very well.

That brings me to scenery. Outstanding work on all levels. Yes there are some glitches  in places , but its the whole damn planet. When you get too close to the ground you can get some weird looking trees/buildings but from 1000 feet most everything looks damn good. The development window is wide open now as this software just dropped. It's only getting better from here.

Ok, I will get into it one more time. It's not a game in the traditional sense. There is no enemy to defeat, no puzzles to solve, no competition to be bested unless you do some group flying with your buddies and try to see who can fly under things (not all bridges are clear underneath FYI). This is a simulation of multiple aircraft and multiple locations. There will be more content added and improved as time goes on so quit sandbagging and get in here!!

Good sim. Although I wish there was more pilot training work than what is provided.  Impressive graphics engine with an equally impressive list of aircraft to fly.
Recommended if you are interested in flight.

Another one! This is DJ Khaled, and we're about to take to the skies with Microsoft Flight Simulator. Let's get it!

Microsoft Flight Simulator is a masterpiece. It's like stepping into the booth with the best equipment - the details are on point, the graphics are crisp, and the world is yours to explore. It's a next-level experience.

This simulator isn't playing games - it's serious about delivering a real flight experience. You got a full range of aircraft, real-world weather conditions, and dynamic day-night cycles. It's like producing a mixtape, you've got control of all the elements, and you can make it your own.

But, let's bring it back down to earth for a second. We gotta address the learning curve. It's steep, just like climbing to the top. But remember, the journey to more success starts with a single step, or in this case, a single flight. Stick with it, learn the controls, master the techniques, and you'll be cruising through the skies in no time.

All in all, Microsoft Flight Simulator is like a DJ Khaled track. It's high-quality, it's immersive, and it's all about living your best life. It's about the thrill of the flight, the beauty of the world, and the joy of exploration.

Remember, "We The Best!" and Microsoft Flight Simulator is definitely one of the best in the flight sim game. Get in the cockpit, take to the skies, and keep reaching for new heights. As for the finale, let's just say, don't just play the game - own the skies!

I love to fly, so overall, I love MSFS 2020. However, there's plenty of room for improvements and fixes.  Eight years ago, I stopped flying using MS 2004. Life got in the way, but now I'm back into the game relearning how to fly online, creating flight plans, etc. After spending 98 hours in the game and flying 25 hours, I love it. However, the two big improvements needed are to be able to adjust the horizon looking out front of the cockpit so that you can see the ground, airport, runway.  And two, the developers need to have flight panels, and give the user the ability to add flight deck panels to any and all aircraft like in MS 2004. Reason: it makes it a lot easier to see and read the instruments on my PC.

As a long-time flight sim enthusiast I would say that visually and in terms of world modelling MSFS is the best sim I have ever flown. I have no real world experience as a pilot but compared to other sims I have used the actual experience of piloting does seem to be as good if not better and is constantly improving.

I've only ever used high-end hardware with flight sims but with MSFS I can max out pretty much all the visual and world detail settings and still have smooth flight. This is something I couldn't say of earlier sims which always had some performance issues, even with the best hardware if you wanted everything to the max.

In the past 2 years I've toured a large part of the world which is something I never had the motivation to do before and which I think speaks for itself :-) There are a vast number of add-ons to choose from, both free and payware, many of which really enhance the sim and cover most of the world.

My only dislikes are the dependence on the on-line features (with very degraded local options) and the inability to control how and when the sim is updated. However, I recognise this is absolutely necessary to provide the full experience and problems are only occasional and usually soon fixed.

So I would definitely recommend MSFS but it does take a little commitment to get the best out of it.

I have spent 13h installing the software. The installation got stuck several times on different "decompressing" steps. The solution (or so I thought) was to pause the installation and remove the file it was trying to decompress, wait for it to re-download and try again. Sometimes it wasn't needed though. Just restarting the game fixed the issue a couple of times. This occurred about several times during the installation. 

After installation I boot up the latest and greatest Flight Simulator only to see that the plane in the hangar is missing textures, some menu items seem to have internal IDs showing and not the text intended for display. Also two of the three menu options at the top of the screen contain nothing.

Thought to myself "Well, things happen... I'll just verify the game files through Steam. The installation was a bit bumpy after all".

Since I still had the installation folder open on my second screen after manually removing undecompressable files, the horror was instant. 

!!!VERIFICATION OF GAME FILES REMOVES ALL DOWNLOADED CONTENT!!!

So at the moment at least I know for a fact what my issue is. The game is not downloaded anymore.

All this from a game that was released around 3 years ago. I had a better experience from the buggy Cyperpunk release than this shitshow. Can't even review the actual game because I need to beat the installation first. But it seems to be the hardest bossbattle of my life.

Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is an absolute marvel that redefines what it means to experience the joy and wonder of flight. As a passionate aviation enthusiast, I can confidently say that this game is a true masterpiece, pushing the boundaries of realism, graphical fidelity, and immersive gameplay. From the moment you take to the virtual skies, you'll be captivated by the awe-inspiring attention to detail and the unparalleled sense of freedom that Microsoft Flight Simulator delivers.

First and foremost, the level of realism in Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is nothing short of astonishing. The meticulously recreated aircraft, accurate flight physics, and dynamic weather systems combine to create an unparalleled simulation experience. From the smallest of details, such as the flickering instrument panel lights, to the vastness of the ever-changing landscapes, the game effortlessly captures the essence of real-world flying. Whether you're piloting a small Cessna or a jumbo jet, the level of authenticity is unparalleled and guarantees an immersive and rewarding flight experience.

The visual fidelity in Microsoft Flight Simulator is truly breathtaking. Powered by cutting-edge technology, the game boasts stunning graphics and meticulous attention to detail. The landscapes are rendered with astonishing accuracy, featuring realistic terrain, dynamic weather conditions, and lifelike lighting effects. From soaring above majestic mountain ranges to navigating through bustling cities, each flight feels like a window into the real world. The combination of advanced satellite imagery and artificial intelligence creates an ever-changing and visually stunning world that is simply awe-inspiring.

The world of Microsoft Flight Simulator is not only visually impressive but also vast and immersive. With a seamless and realistic representation of the entire planet, you can explore the world from the comfort of your own home. From bustling airports to remote airstrips, the game offers a vast array of locations to discover and conquer. The inclusion of real-time air traffic and live weather data further enhances the immersion, making each flight a dynamic and engaging experience.

The attention to detail extends beyond the visuals and world design to the intuitive and user-friendly interface. Microsoft Flight Simulator strikes a delicate balance between accessibility and realism, allowing both seasoned pilots and newcomers to enjoy the game at their own pace. With a wealth of training resources and a variety of control options, players can tailor their experience to match their skill level and preferred playstyle. The inclusion of a robust and supportive community further enhances the learning experience, providing a wealth of knowledge and assistance to newcomers.

In conclusion, Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary Edition is a remarkable achievement that sets a new standard for flight simulation games. With its astonishing realism, breathtaking visuals, and immersive gameplay, it offers an unrivaled experience for aviation enthusiasts and gamers alike. Whether you're a seasoned pilot or someone dreaming of taking flight, Microsoft Flight Simulator will transport you to new heights of wonder and excitement. Prepare to embark on a truly extraordinary journey and witness the beauty and grandeur of the world from a perspective like never before.

This game requires a huge in client update before you can play it. That's ok in and of itself, but the update is absurdly slow. Literally averaging 5Mbits/s, and it's 150 gigs. This means you can't play your Steam games on other devices, and you may or may not be eligible for a refund given your "play time" once it's actually installed.
If you buy this, get ready for a hopelessly archaic download experience.

UPDATE 07-10-23: This is MY opinion from MY experiences. After 482 additional hours (because of downloading times) of additional play since my last review, I have around 12 hours flying time. That's about 470 hours of download time that Steam counts as gameplay. Stupid, right? This is another reason why you guys (ASOBO) deserve an updated review. Is this the best flight simulator for GA and commercial on the market? Debatable. Looks great, sure. Does it still present significant issues at all times when flying 2d or VR? Absolutely. Why is it that my trim wheel (Honeycomb Bravo) is still being recognized as a button and not an axis? Why do I have to download three third-party applications just to get it running properly? MSFS 2020 has been out for years and this is an issue? Why? I cannot stand that some of my peripherals are being rendered obsolete from one update to the next? I understand there will be issues with programming; Fix one  thing and another breaks. I get that. But dang, is it frustrating. All I want to do is plug and play with all of my thousands of dollars worth of equipment I bought for flying in VR. But daggum! These updates make me cross my fingers after each one and its a gamble as to how many hours I will have to spend looking up solutions for my no-longer-functional sim hardware. I wish Asobo prioritized making sure our hardware works before releasing updates. It's not like everyone in the team can't afford to test one piece of hardware each before releasing it to the public. I am tired of spending countless hours on forums and videos to try and find solutions to each issue after an update. Often times, I don't find a solution and just have to put the sim down. 

All of this being said: The team is doing a good job at making the game look great. Great job all. Now can we please make sure all major hardware names work with this sim before releasing updates? I want to give this a recommendation, but if anyone else shares my frustration and disappointment, let me know. If anyone reads this and knows a fix to ongoing issues, let me know. I'll fly as often as I can with what I've got to work with. Clear skies, everyone. 

Original Review: Have spent weeks playing when first released. However, I prefer flying in VR so have waited for it for months. Finally, VR is released and its time to redownload MSFS2020. WEEKS. I spent weeks downloading this sim again because the last update did something. I'm no tech guy, but I can't get past 4mb/s download speed. Have tried every recommended action from their site and forums to no avail. I just downloaded Elite Dangerous through steam at 20gb in less than half an hour, yet can't even install MSFS. Once it downloads up to around 70g, it loops and I have to restart after troubleshooting without a fix. I had preordered the premium package, so once the base game is installed, I still have to download over 60gb of extra data for my planes and purchases. Would love to see what this game offers in VR as much as I enjoyed it when it first released. However, Asobo has let me down with this download method. HOT GARBAGE, even on gig connections. Would love to see this fixed so I could actually fly after spending over $1k in new hardware to include the HP Reverb G2, Honeycomb Yoke, and 10000 series processor for the sole purpose of bush flying in a Savage Cub over the PNW. For the love of all things holy, fix this trash download system so that flight sim loyalists can enjoy this near masterpiece.

I've been playing MSFS since version 9, which is a while back for those of you familiar with the franchise. This newest version is definitely a worthy successor to all of the versions that came before it. Unlike previous versions, this latest update has true to life, high fidelity airliners. In the past, you had to purchase this kind of accuracy from a 3rd party developer costing upwards of $80. 

For newbies, don't be intimidated. The training missions will get you flying in no time at all.

With its continual development, fixes, and free content, I will be keeping MSFS on my drive for years to come.

As far as "flight simulation" goes it's a pretty weak portrayal of aviation.
Whilst graphically the game is stunning but the overall flight physics are substandard, especially in the domain of the tail draggers; which ends up being the most arcade like take of a tail dragger I've ever experienced.
There are some factors that are modelled well such as the navigational systems (on select aircraft), visual effects, and weather effects.

Overall if you're just wanting a bit of eye candy, to understand the basics of aviation, or to maybe hash over a VFR route prior to flying the real thing it's okay.
But if you're wanting a more substantiated "flight simulator" in your home, best to stick with X-Plane for a more realistic experience.

Probably a good game if the Downloader wasnt so damn bad and my game wouldve worked. Issue was i downloaded the game for about 21 Hours. EXTREMELY Disappointed.  I have a very good, top notch PC with a 3080 graphics card that I spent a lot of money on and it has worked perfectly for well over a year on every game I've played.  BUT with this darn game, it took over 12 hours to download and sometimes went backwards.... which honestly I was okay with because I know its a heavy graphic game and there's alot of smarts to it underneath the hood.  BUT then I started playing and nothing worked.  I hit every button on my keyboard and mouse and nothing (YES, I made sure that the controls were set to keyboard and mouse!!!).  So I tried existing and restarting the game..... AND THEN THE BAD NEWS CAME - ALL OF A SUDDEN I HAD TO DOWNLOAD IT AGAIN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! So I actually did and I made sure it was in the correct place and folder..... it took another 12 hours to install and then I started playing .... THIS TIME is actually worked and the controls were working, I played about 15 minutes of the tutorial then had to go.  I came back 30 minutes later after I ate food AND I HAD TO INSTALL THE F-ING GAME AGAIN!!!!!!!!! therefore, I refuse to wait another 10-12 hours to install it so I want a refund and hence my very negative review.  don't waste your time

MSFS literally changed my life. I had zero interest in aviation as a hobby or career before this. I decided why not? Let's see what keeps these flight sim nerds coming back to these games over and over and over again. I decided to try my hand at the training portion of the game and see if I could get the highest passing grade on all of it (A). I did. So I thought to myself, why not go see how this applies to the real world? I'm now balls deep in PPL training in real life and this simulator kick started all of that. This is the closest thing you'll get to flying real planes in real places short of really doing it.

Ok, I gave this game another chance after a friend of mine insisted in trying it again.

This game in VR is simply mind-blowing. It gave me so many emotions all together, which I never experienced in any other game. 

The Darkstar challenge left me speechless. I almost cried when I flew over my parent's house where I grew up. I was incredibly excited when I flew in the grand canyon and passed under the tower bridge in London. 

Overall, an incredible experience. Worth every single penny.
